comm_body: Luke -  Thank you for taking a few minutes to chat today.  We discussed the following things: 1) You verified that the request is for a /23 block in each of the listed regions (us-west-2, us-east-1, eu-west-1, eu-west-2 and ap-northeast-1) for a total of 2,625 IP addresses. 2) You are considering using NAT Gateway as a solution coupled with your existing IP blocks, and/or smaller new blocks. 3) You would like to pause efforts on this request for 2-3 days until you regroup with your team and examine the NAT Gateway option, and consider bandwidth needs.  I look forward to hearing from you once you have met with your team and determined your next step.    You can feel free to update this case, or reach out to me directly - I will send an email direct to you with informational links.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Allen Nearing PLUS TAM Amazon Web Services

comm_body: Hey Sasikumar  Thanks for explaining the difference. I have one query here, that Cloudwatch merics are not proving accurate for planning capacity?   So for example in my current case we are running Elasticsearch on EC2 instance. The thing is Cloudwatch shows my CPU utilisation is just 20-30% and my host level metrics show its 80-100%. Beyond 100% on my host, i cannot utilize compute anymore irrespective thats its just 20-30% on hypervisor. If i consider the hypervisor stats i have room to scale down my instance to half. I did tried that in past but that reduced the performance and instances got unresponsive due to load.   Any suggestion for such case as Cloudwatch metrics are not proving accurate/helpful for capacity planning.  Thanks & Regards Harsimran Singh

Also we are facing below issue while fetching repos, Please find the error detail, [root@ua5nbp001 yum.repos.d]# yum update Loaded plugins: amazon-id, rhui-lb, search-disabled-repos Could not retrieve mirrorlist https://rhui3.eu-central-1.aws.ce.redhat.com/pulp/mirror/content/dist/rhel/rhui/server/7/7Server/x86_64/rh-common/os error was 12: Timeout on https://rhui3.eu-central-1.aws.ce.redhat.com/pulp/mirror/content/dist/rhel/rhui/server/7/7Server/x86_64/rh-common/os: (28, 'Connection timed out after 30000 milliseconds')    One of the configured repositories failed (Unknown),  and yum doesn't have enough cached data to continue. At this point the only  safe thing yum can do is fail. There are a few ways to work "fix" this:       1. Contact the upstream for the repository and get them to fix the problem.       2. Reconfigure the baseurl/etc. for the repository, to point to a working         upstream. This is most often useful if you are using a newer         distribution release than is supported by the repository (and the         packages for the previous distribution release still work).       3. Run the command with the repository temporarily disabled             yum --disablerepo=<repoid> ...       4. Disable the repository permanently, so yum won't use it by default. Yum         will then just ignore the repository until you permanently enable it         again or use --enablerepo for temporary usage:              yum-config-manager --disable <repoid>         or             subscription-manager repos --disable=<repoid>       5. Configure the failing repository to be skipped, if it is unavailable.         Note that yum will try to contact the repo. when it runs most commands,         so will have to try and fail each time (and thus. yum will be be much         slower). If it is a very temporary problem though, this is often a nice

comm_body: Hi Sumit,     Please check the below AWS FAQ and it's mentioned AWS support can work with microsoft support directly. can you please let me know why you asked me to work with microsoft directly any specific reason for this ?   What is the expanded support agreement between Amazon and Microsoft, and how does it benefit me?  For customers that have purchased AWS Support at the Business or Enterprise tier, AWS Support is able to work directly with Microsoft support engineers to resolve issues related to customers running Microsoft Windows Server, SQL Server, or Windows desktop (via Amazon Workspaces) on AWS. As a result of this expanded support agreement, AWS can engage directly with Microsoft to create the best possible support experience. If necessary, AWS Support can escalate issues directly to Microsoft and work with dedicated Microsoft support engineers to help ensure issues are addressed and resolved.     Can AWS open a support case with Microsoft on issues I might encounter? Yes, AWS Support can work directly with Microsoft support engineers to escalate a support case if necessary to resolve issues encountered by AWS Support customers at the Business or Enterprise tier. AWS will not share any Customer information or specific details without your permission.  https://aws.amazon.com/windows/faq/

comm_body: Hello Anil,  Thanks for writing back to us. Please find the quick summary for the chat session.  You discussed below point with my colleague Sohaib :  - The instance i-04b6c49211713957a got auto-recovered and is moved to new & healthy underlying hardware/host. - No need to perform stop/start operation onto the instance and no action is required from your end. - While performing stop/start operation onto the instance, only the Public IP will change (not private/EIP[1]) and the data residing in the instance-store [2] volumes would be lost (& not from EBS volumes).  I hope this helps. As discussed earlier, I'll be marking this case as resolved. However, In case you have any additional queries/concerns, feel free to open a new case/chat we shall be happy to assist you further.  Have a nice day ahead.  Stay safe :)  Reference :  ------------- [1] Elastic IP addresses https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-addresses-eip.html  [2] Instance store volumes | No ISV in r4.xlarge instance https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Shantanu P. comm_body: Hello Manjunatha,      Alex here from AWS Support in Sydney. Thank you for reaching out. Below you'll find a quick summary and next steps.      In a nutshell, you were experiencing issues to run "yum repolist" from Red Hat OS running on EC2 instance i-0bfc988e4d8aab795. I've double checked the security groups, NACLs, and route-table but I didn't observe anything that would stand out. You have rules to allow outbound connection to the internet so it seems.      The only thing I'm not too sure is that the default gateway in your VPC points to vgw-ca1cfea3, which could be a firewall in your infrastructure. However, we tried a couple commands with curl to make sure that this instance could establish an outbound connection to the following addresses:          rhui2-cds01.us-east-1.aws.ce.redhat.com / 54.211.52.203         rhui2-cds02.us-east-1.aws.ce.redhat.com / 35.175.60.178         rhui3.us-east-1.aws.ce.redhat.com / 52.200.186.197      During the troubleshooting, it appears to me that you might have a transparent proxy. Therefore, although curl command for the addresses above worked out, I would recommend you to check out with the network team whether those addresses above are whitelisted just to confirm. For more details about RHUI 2 and RHUI 3 changes, please check out the following links [1][2] that contains more details about Red Hat changes that I talked about it.      Since we observed a different result for the certificate issuer when trying to connect to RHUI repositories with curl, we are not too sure about the integrity of the files that come with package rh-amazon-rhui-client. So, going forward, also experiment downloading that package from a working instance using yumdownloader.          # yumdownloader rh-amazon-rhui-client      This is going to fetch the latest version of the package named rh-amazon-rhui-client-3.0.32-1.el7.noarch.rpm. Next, create a backup of the EC2 instance i-0bfc988e4d8aab795 using EBS snapshot or any other method that you have available. Then, copy the downloaded file over to t

comm_body: Hello Rohan,   I checked the details of the setup in production environment and found the following -   Bucket owner - 008300461057  caller -  arn:aws:iam::008300461057:role/S3_Read_only  This configuration is expected to work as the caller is from the bucket owner account and satisfies the evaluation logic for ACL as per [1].  This does not work in current implementation in control tower because -    bucket - aws-landing-zone-logs-612474255603-ap-south-1 - owner - arn:aws:iam::902425822529:role/Qradar_SIEM_ReadOnly  caller - arn:aws:iam::902425822529:role/Qradar_SIEM_ReadOnly  This will not work as objects are uploaded by cloudtrail, hence cloudtrail is the object owner. Hence, the bucket owner cannot control access to log objects using bucket policy. To resolve this issue, one solution is to assume a role in bucket owner account 612474255603 and then make the API calls.  Since QRadar does not allow assume role directly with instance profile role, you need to configure access keys from infosec account and provide the role ARN of role in bucket account.  Also, since QRadar also supports directly providing access keys, you can also create a user in bucket owner account, configure credentials and then configure them with QRadar.  I'll be reaching out to Lakhvinder to set up time where we can connect over call and drive this to resolution.  Please let me know if you have queries for me in the meanwhile.  References  ========== [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/how-s3-evaluates-access-control.html  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Kunal J. comm_body: Hello team,  Thanks for writing back to us. Sorry to hear that you are still facing issues while integrating with QRadar.  As we don't haveany visibility into QRadar end configuration, can you please collaborate with QRadar support and fetch the detailed error message thrown by AWS APIs. Please get back to us with the following information -    1. The complete error message (This should be the error message thrown by AWS API and not the one displayed on QRadar, can be obtained using auditing debug level logs in client application, which is QRadat in this case).  2. The exact AWS API call which failed.  3. Failed request ID and timestamp.  4. Principal of the API - the identity / role which was used to make the call.  5. Parameters provided in the API call (if any).  Please work with Qradar team to get the above requested information. Once more context is available in the failed requests, we can troubleshoot the AWS end of configuration to see what causing the error.  Also, if you have any queries to add in the meantime, please feel free to list them out.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Aashish,   Thanks for reaching AWS Premium Support. This is Amrutha and it was nice speaking to you. Let me quickly recap of what we discussed.  You contacted us as you were unable to access your EC2 instance 'i-0300138e96c48a33b' due to below errors in the console logs and wanted assistance on the same. Please correct me if I am wrong.  "[  184.657672] dracut-initqueue[243]: Warning: dracut-initqueue timeout - starting timeout scripts [  185.164964] dracut-initqueue[243]: Warning: dracut-initqueue timeout - starting timeout scripts [  185.165203] dracut-initqueue[243]: Warning: Could not boot. [  186.275042] dracut-initqueue[243]: Warning: /dev/disk/by-uuid/e9643aa4-b339-43c4-afc5-fcac22af1584 does not exist          Starting Dracut Emergency Shell... [  187.641028] audit_printk_skb: 3 callbacks suppressed Warning: /dev/disk/by-uuid/e9643aa4-b339-43c4-afc5-fcac22af1584 does not exist"  Further, you informed that you were trying to change the subnet of the 'i-0837f79b6e5955f1d' and encountered the above issue, on the instance 'i-0300138e96c48a33b' which was launched from the AMI taken of the instance 'i-0837f79b6e5955f1d'. Also we noticed that instance 'i-0837f79b6e5955f1d' was running perfectly fine post reboot and restart.   In order to troubleshoot and isolate the issue further, we commented all the entries in the fstab except for the root volume, created an image and launched a t3a.small instance 'i-08fbfe775bfb832f7', but unfortunately we still encountered same issue. On checking both the instances, I noticed that there was change in the instance type of old and new instances. Thus you went ahead and changed the instance type from t3a.small to t2.large, post which instance was able to boot successfully and you were able to access the instance without any issue.  Further, as discussed on the call, C5 and T3a instance type uses Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) and we need to install ENA, nvme drivers and have other prerequisites in-place in order to change the instance type from T2 to T3a/C5. comm_body: Hello Praveen,  It was a pleasure talking to you today on our chat. As you know you initiated the chat today because you are experiencing slowness on your instance.  Instance ID: i-09183c975ad1e3bd1  On reviewing the instance I could see that the root volumes burst credit was depleted which would explain as to why you are experiencing slowness. [1] Due to the root volume having no credits you are operating at the baseline of the volume. As the instance would try to request more IO then what is allocated this would cause the slowness.  I explained that to resolve the issue there are three things you can do. 1. Increase the volume size. 2. Change volume type. 3. Narrow down the application on the instance over utilizing the volume.  For your volume types you can see here. -- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-volume-types.html#ebs-volume-characteristics  As you are using a GP2 volume the performance scales as the volume size increases, the option here would be to increase volume size.  Second option would be to change to a IO1 volume type where you can select the amount of IO that you wish to use.  With regards to changing and scaling a volume.  You will need to modify the volume. -- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-modify-volume.html  After modification you will need to modify the filesystem on the volume if you have changed its size. -- https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/recognize-expanded-volume-linux.html  More information on this. -- https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/expand-root-ebs-linux/  I hope this is of help to you.  If you have any questions or queries regarding your case, please feel free to ask.  Have a great day.  [1] BurstBalance: https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=~%28region~%27ap-south-1~metrics~%28~%28~%27AWS*2fEBS~%27BurstBalance~%27VolumeId~%27vol-043a6a17bb70caaed%29%29~period~300~stat~%27Minimum~start~%272020-09-07T14*3a02*3a57Z~end~%272020-09-08T14*3a02*3a57Z%29  We

comm_body: Hello Ravi,  Kumar here from AWS Premium Support. Thank you for your time over the call today. It was a pleasure assisting you.  Below you'll find a short summary of our conversation:  You reached out as you were not able to SSH into the instance 'i-0f318e2a6374795ae' as you no longer had the SSH key-pair along with you. Hence, you were looking for an assistance on the same.  Upon our conversation, we went ahead and injected a new SSH public key pair inside the instance using the user-data script.  =========================== Creating a new Key-Pair ===========================  Step 1: Downloading the Key-pair from E2 Console:  Go to the AWS EC2 Management Console (where you can see the instances running) > On the left console, youll find Key Pairs under the Network and Security Section (as shown in screenshot 1) > Click on the Key Pairs > Now, youll see on the right Create key pair > Click on it > provide a name (for eg: test) > Create key-pair  Once you have created the key-pair, itll be downloaded in your local machine.   Step 2: Generating the public key for your private key:  1. Open PuTTYkeygen using PuTTY 2. In the 'Actions' pane, select 'Load an existing private key file'. 3. Select the file that you had downloaded from the console.             Note: A confirmation displays after PuTTYgen successfully imports the private key. Click OK to dismiss the message. 4. Enter a 'Key Passphrase'. Confirm it.  5. Save private key. Save public key.   Now, You'll have a private key and a public key with you.  3. You need to copy this key and save it in a file or a text editor for the time being.  4. Now stop the instance, click on Actions, Instance settings, Edit User-data and add the following script by including the public key inside the script:  ===========================  Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="//" MIME-Version: 1.0  --// Content-Type: text/cloud-config; charset="us-ascii" MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="cloud-config.txt"

comm_body: Hello Ankit,  Thank you for your time in chat today. Please find summary of our discussion below.   You were trying to change instance type from m4.4xlarge to m5a.4xlarge however that instance was unable to boot successfully.   I tried to check the instance details from my side and from console logs of the instance I noticed that network interface of the instance is not up. See 'systemctl status network.service' for details. ci-info: +++++++++++++++++++++++Net device info++++++++++++++++++++++++ [    8.525372] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: +--------+-------+-----------+-----------+-------------------+ [    8.527420] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: | Device |   Up  |  Address  |    Mask   |     Hw-Address    | [    8.543404] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: +--------+-------+-----------+-----------+-------------------+ [    8.545411] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: | ens5:  | False |     .     |     .     | 0a:56:54:25:34:ff | [    8.547622] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: |  lo:   |  True | 127.0.0.1 | 255.0.0.0 |         .         | [    8.563472] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: +--------+-------+-----------+-----------+-------------------+ [    8.565542] cloud-init[1228]: ci-info: !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Route info failed!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- As we could see from the output the ens5 interface failed to come up successfully.   We started a screenshare session and first checked if nvme and ena drivers are installed using "modinfo" command. Later we verified "nofail" option is added in /etc/fstab as well.  Now to disable the predictable device naming, we suggest adding "net.ifnames=0" option on kernel command line. The command to do so was  $ sudo sed -i '/^GRUB\_CMDLINE\_LINUX

comm_body: Hello Lakshmi,  Checking the 3 instances they all show similar boot logs on the backend. This is the same issue that we noticed on the previous instance. From the Errors we have seen, the Issue may have been caused because the AMI was Sysprepped using the Microsoft Sysprep tool. Here are the Logs:  - 2020/09/12 21:35:19Z: EC2ConfigMonitorState: 0 - 2020/09/12 21:35:19Z: Windows is being configured. SysprepState=IMAGE_STATE_UNDEPLOYABLE - 2020/09/12 21:35:22Z: Driver: AWS NVMe Driver v1.3.2.53  - 2020/09/12 21:35:22Z: Driver: AWS PV Driver Package v8.3.2  - 2020/09/12 21:35:22Z: Driver: Amazon Elastic Network Adapter v2.1.5.0 - 2020/09/12 21:36:19Z: Windows is still being configured. SysprepState=IMAGE_STATE_UNDEPLOYABLE  The preferred way of doing Sysprep is using the EC2Config Service. The EC2Config Service is by default installed on all EC2 instances. It is installed under C:\Program Files\Amazon\Ec2ConfigService. However, since images are BYOL they may not have EC2Config installed. I would recommend to install EC2Config on one of the instances and run Sysprep with the tool. These links can be used as reference for this [1][2]. Once the process completes, save the new AMI as the base Image and test launching an additional Instance from the new AMI to see if the issue is solved.   As an alternative, this issue can be fixed with the same Registry Keys that we changed previously from the following path:  - HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Setup\State - Change the values from "IMAGE_STATE_UNDEPLOYABLE" to IMAGE_STATE_COMPLETE"  I hope that the information provided may assist you. If you need any further support or have any additional questions please feel free to contact us back anytime.  References:  [1] Installing the Latest Version of EC2Config https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/UsingConfig_Install.html  [2] Using Sysprep with EC2Config https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ami-create-standard.html#sysprep-using  We value your feedback. Please sh

comm_body: Hello,      Alex here from AWS Support in Sydney. Thank you for reaching out to EC2 Linux. Below you'll find a quick summary.      In a nutshell, I've confirmed that your limit request submitted via case number 7391337531 was applied correctly. The new limit for nu.general is 17804, and not 228 per wording found in the original case.      Later, I've found out that you've got an automated message from the system about the limit increase request. Discussing internally with the CS team, sounds like the tool by default will increase according to the value requested, and not set a new limit to what was requested. In this case, as we confirmed, it was increased from 17576 to 17804 as expected.      I'm logging an internal ticket here to have someone to review the automated message to avoid confusion in the future. However, we here at AWS Support don't have an ETA to provide, as this falls outside of our control. For now, you can expect someone to rectify the message in the original case.      Hope this was helpful, and should you need further assistance feel free to reach out. Happy to help you.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Sujai  Warm greetings from AWS Premium Support. I am Sunny and it was my pleasure to assist you on chat today. Below I am posting a quick summary of our chat today.  From the case notes I can understand that you were seeing high load average value for the Instance  i-08857c414bff91648 after which the instance became unresponsive and you need to manually stop start the instance to bring it up and running.  I checked the Instance  i-08857c414bff91648 using my internal tools and could see that the instance failed System status check on 2020-09-12 at 12:37 UTC [1]. Upon further checking the issue I can confirm that the underlying hardware on which the Instance was running became unavailable for the same timestamp when the Instance failed System status check. Further I can confirm that the underlying hardware became available after a while and the Instance started passing 2/2 status check and was running up and healthy.  Moving further I can see from the attached screenshot that you were experiencing a high load average for the instance i-08857c414bff91648 after which the instance became unresponsive and you need to manually stop start the instance to bring it up and running.  For this issue I checked the CPU Utilization for the Instance and could see that the CPU Utilization was quite low during the same timestamp when a high load average was experienced. [2]  Please allow me explain about the load average and its relation with CPU Utilization  In Linux, the load average is basically the combination of threads running on the CPU, threads waiting in the run queue to get on the CPU and process waiting for IO to complete. The three numbers in the load average is the average of these parameters over 1, 5 and 15 minute respectively.  Whereas the CPU utilization is basically an indication that how much percentage of time in a given time interval the CPU was busy doing some work.  So, considering above definition, it can be interpreted that we can have high load average even when CPU utilization of the server is low.

comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for being patience on this case.  As discussed over the call, I checked the network between EC2 instances and the ECR repositories but did not find any anomalies.  Also the resource utilization on the EC2 instances and underlying host did not show any high utilization. comm_body: Hi,    Welcome to AWS Premium Support. I'm Maureen and I'll be assisting you on your case.  From what I understand, you have faced exceptions when connecting to your Redis cluster mode disabled cluster (Replication group ID: snd-dp-session) from your client (EC2 Instance ID: i-00f702c0823542167).   Thank you from providing the snippet of logs showing the exception stack traces. From it, I can see that there were two issues:   - On 2020-09-13 at 15:22 UTC, the client was not able to connect to the Redis cluster and was throwing an exception "java.net.UnknownHostException: storefront-p-sid-redis-read.swiggyint.in".    This error means that the application was unable to resolve the DNS name "storefront-p-sid-redis-read.swiggyint.in" at that time.     Depending on which endpoint is being used in the application to reach the cluster (reader, node, primary endpoints), changes in the cluster can result in the application temporarily being unable to resolve the endpoint [1]. Additionally, if the client has a DNS caching mechanism built in, it is recommended to have a lower TTL (as low as 510 seconds) as having a higher TTL poses a risk of your application not reaching the desired node. It is also recommended to not use the cache forever option.     - On 2020-09-17 from 11:00 - 12:20 UTC, the application was unable to connect to the cluster and throwing an exception "JedisConnectionException: java.net.SocketException: Too many open files".   This error means that the application reached the maximum number of open files (connections) allowed on the operating system (ulimit) and due to this, any additional connections past that were closed. I have found additional information from the Redis cluster that enforce these findings.   I first checked the EC2 instance for the timeframe indicated (from 2020-09-13 at 00:00 UTC to 2020-09-17 at 23:59 UTC) and I can confirm that it has been running, passing all health checks and that there were no issues with its underlying hardware nor any networking issues nor DNS issues that c

comm_body: Hello Vinayak,  Thanks for reaching AWS Premium Support. This is Amrutha and it was nice speaking to you. Let me quickly recap of what we discussed.  You initiated the chat as your EC2 instance 'i-06dbb9111eb25bbbe' status checks were getting stuck automatically at times and you wanted assistance on the same.   I did a quick check on the instance and observed that the underlying hardware on which the instance is running was healthy [1]. However, instance was failing its instance status check on 2020-09-22 15:33:00 UTC [2].  As informed on the call, Instance status checks monitor the software and network configuration of your individual instance. These checks detect problems that require your involvement to repair. When an instance status check fails, you typically must address the problem yourself (for example, by rebooting the instance or by making instance configuration changes) [3], as AWS Support Engineers do not have access to customer data..   Further, I reviewed CPU utilization, Network usage in and out and their values are also well below any values that would be of concerns. However, on checking the EBS root volume attached to the instance, I observed that the volume was driving around ~3000 iops constantly on 22-Sep-2020 from ~14:44 UTC to ~15:14 UTC due to which the volume burst balance [4] depleted to zero and performance was hampered. This can be a possible cause for the instance to fail its instance status check.  Detailed Explanation: -----------------------------------  Firstly, I would like to give you the brief idea about the IOPS. For an EBS volume, the number of IOPS that you will get is calculated using formula  -> IOPS(Input Output Per Second) = Read Operations Per Second + Write Operations Per Second -> "IOPS on GP2 volume = Volume Size in GB * 3",    minimum of 100 IOPS irrespective of the volume size.   Let's consider the volume of size 50GB, then the number of IOPS that you will get is 150 IOPS. The GP2 volume comes with the Burst balance concept. It means that when your volume drives a

comm_body: Hello,  It was really nice talking to you.  Here is the summary of our call:  You reached out today as you observed errors in the autoscaling group where Auto scaling group "HS-Imp-ASG" failed to launch instance.  I would like to thank you for sharing the screen shots it helped to look into the errors.  Using internal tools, I checked the auto scaling group and noticed that the instances were unable to launch between 2020-09-23 13:09 UTC and 2020-09-23 13:18 UTC. From the error messages it can be seen that there was no Spot capacity available in the region for c5.4xlarge instance type. This is the expected behavior from the Auto scaling group where launch configuration is being used with just spot instances and one instance type. Auto scaling group will keep trying to launch c5.4xlarge instances until it successfully does. I can see the launch configuration was later modified and on-demand instances were launched. Please note that there is no direct way to find out how much spot capacity is available in the region. We do have a tool called Spot advisor which shows the instance types with less interruption percentage.  https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/spot/instance-advisor/  Now to efficiently manage the auto scaling group I would like to make some recommendations. You can use Launch template instead of using launch configuration. With launch template you get the Purchase options where you can specify different instance types and ratio of On-demand Instances and Spot instances.  With this you can control the number of on-demand instances and spot instances running at any time. In a case where spot instance is not available, production environment will still be up and running with on-demand instances spread across the availability zones. It is also easy to switch to Launch template. You can edit the auto scaling group and click on switch to Launch template.  For more information on creating launch template: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/create-launch-template.html  Please note that in the launch

comm_body: Good Day Thank you for contacting AWS Support, my name is Craven and I will be assisting you with this case. I understand you would like to find out if PostgreSQL12 is supported on Amazon Linux.  Currently PostgreSQL12 repositories have not been added to the Amazon Linux AMIs and instances and as such you will need to add the repos manually before you are able to install PostgressSQL12. To install PostgressSQL on my Amazon Linux 2 instance I followed the instructions below -:  1. Since Postgress rpms are found in the amazon extras repo I ran "sudo  amazon-linux-extras | grep postgre" to check and found only PostgreSQL9, 10 and 11. 2. Created the Postgress12 repo by creating a file /etc/yum.repos.d/pgsql12.repo and added the contents outlined below    [pgdg12]    name=PostgreSQL 12 for RHEL/CentOS 7 - x86_64    baseurl=https://download.postgresql.org/pub/repos/yum/12/redhat/rhel-7-x86_64    enabled=1    gpgcheck=0 3. Once the repo was added I was able to install the PostgreSQL server and client packages by running "sudo yum install postgresql12 postgresql12-server" 4. I then was able to initialize the database, enable it and start it without any issues.  Please use the above steps to set up the PostgreSQL12 repos and you will be able to install it on Amazon Linux 2. I hope this answers your question, please let me know if there is anything else you would like me to assist you with. Have a good day.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Craven N. comm_body: Hello,  I hope you're doing well.  My name is Aravind and I am from AWS Premium Support. I will be assisting you with this case today.   PROBLEM STATEMENT ################## From the case description, I understand that you tried to launch an instance in ap-south-1c availability zone using AMI - ami-0bf24570bfaa1e006. However, you get the error saying Your requested instance type is not supported in your requested Availability Zone. Please correct me if I have misunderstood anything or missed out any details.  ANALYSIS ######## I apologize for the inconvenience caused. However, I would like to add that not all instances are available in all Availability zones. The error you received does not correlate with your AMI. If you try to launch any t2.xlarge instance instance into the ap-south-1c availability zone, it will give the same error.   To check which availability zones you can launch t2.xlarge in, please follow the below steps (If you would just like to know it for ap-south-1 region, the zones are ap-south-1b and ap-south-1a.   1. Open the AWS EC2 Console in the region you want to launch the instance in.  2. Click on Instance Types from the left side menu 3. You will get a table of all instance types. Type in t2.xlarge into the search bar 4. Click on t2.xlarge blue hyperlink to open the page for that instance type 5. Scroll down to the Networking tab. You will have a section called Availability Zones. This will tell you which zones the instance is available to launch in.    ACTION PLAN ########### To get past this error, you must choose a different combination of instance type - availability zone. You do not have to change both instance type and availability zone - one of them is good enough.   To change availability Zone -   1. While launching the instance, you will be offered to choose a subnet 2. Choose a subnet that is in ap-south-1a or ap-south-1b. You can check Subnet regions from the VPC section of the AWS Console 3. If you do not have a subnet in these regions, create a new subnet with the Availabilit

comm_body: Hello Harsimran Singh,  Thanks for reaching AWS Premium Support. Myself Sasikumar from AWS EC2 Linux team, and I am glad to assist you today.  I understand that you have found discrepancy between the data shown in the CloudWatch CPU metric and the data shown from the other tools such as New Relic, Elasticvue and OS level 'top' command. You are concerned about the data and you are facing difficulty in the capacity planning. Please correct me if I misunderstood your problem.  First, I appreciate you for providing a clear problem statement and relevant screenshot outputs.  The CloudWatch metrics for the CPU utilization are derived from the Hypervisor showing how much the instance is using and as such this is the recommended metric for the actual usage of the CPU from your instance compared to the other tools.  The CPUUtilization metric reported via CloudWatch is from the underlying host perspective and may not always match OS provided tools and the third-party monitoring tools. The CPUUtilization in CloudWatch displays the percentage of allocated EC2 compute units that are currently in use by the instance. The OS will report based on how many CPU cycles it is using from the underlying host. As the host will have other workloads running, the CloudWatch metrics provide a true insight into the actual CPU usage of the instance compared to the total allocated CPU from the host. The CloudWatch metric identifies the processing power required to run an application on a selected instance. Refer[1].  Linux 'top' utility will show you the CPU utilization of the underlying host whereas CloudWatch will show you the CPU utilization of your actual instance. This is why you will see large differences. Due to the fact that we AWS Engineers have very limited knowledge on other third-party tools, I cannot compare or comment on the behavior of those utilities.  It is highly recommended for the most accurate reporting, always use CloudWatch for making decision in planning the capacity for your application work-load.  So in short seeing

comm_body: Hello Atin,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Mainak. It was nice talking to you today.? I hope you are doing great!   You initiated a chat as you were unable to launch the instance i-056c17d6daf1e9306 in ap-south-1 region and wanted to know what could be the issue.  I have reviewed the backend log and noticed that there was not enough capacity available at that moment for On-Demand capacity to complete your request. However after few seconds the capacity space came back and you were able to launch the instance.  I am really sorry for the inconvenience this issue is causing you.  ? Unfortunately, capacity is not guaranteed as customer demand keeps changing unless you have an existing On-Demand Capacity Reservation for your Ec2 instances. By creating Capacity Reservations, you will ensure that you will always have access to your EC2 capacity when you need it, for as long as you need it.  If in future you face similar kind of issues then please try the following:   - Wait a few minutes and then submit your request again; capacity can shift frequently.   - Try changing the instance type for time being and revert to desired instance type, when capacity is available( Which you has done recently)   - For a long term solution, please consider using On-Demand Capacity reservation which enables you to reserve Amazon EC2 capacity for any duration. For more information, see On-Demand Capacity Reservations.     https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-capacity-reservations.html  On-Demand Capacity Reservations enable you to reserve capacity for your Amazon EC2 instances in a specific Availability Zone for any duration. This gives you the ability to create and manage capacity reservations independently from the billing discounts offered by Savings Plans or regional Reserved Instances. By creating Capacity Reservations, you ensure that you always have access to EC2 capacity when you need it, for as long as you need it. comm_body: Hello Vivek,  This is Millicent from AWS Premium support again. It was a pleasure talking with you on chat a moment ago.  You reached out to us as you are in the process of upgrading your c4 instance  to c5 type and m4 instances to m5 type and you needed to know whether to upgrade kernel only or run yum update.  Just to further clarify the link shared in your correspondence below , only applies for RHEL 7 lower than 7.4 and requires running yum upgrade kernel :  https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/install-ena-driver-rhel-ec2/  However , for RHEL 7.4 and other Amazon Linux 2 AMIs come pre-installed with the module needed for enhanced networking with ENA as our guide here [1].   If you launched your instance using an older Amazon Linux AMI and it does not have enhanced networking enabled already, please run 'yum update' to update your instance with the newest kernel and kernel modules, including ena as here [1].  Finally we agreed that you would implement the changes on your staging environment before rolling out to production.  However, should you have any other questions or need additional clarification, please feel free to get back to us and we will be more than happy to assist you.  References [1] Enabling enhanced networking with the Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) on Linux instances  - Testing whether enhanced networking is enabled - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/enhanced-networking-ena.html#test-enhanced-networking-ena  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Nandeesh,  Thank you for your time over chat. It was pleasure to have worked with you.   This is a summary of our chat session.  You had reached out regarding instance: i-053df7fd8bf533ff4 failing its 1/2 status checks intermittently and getting fixed on every stop start.  On checking we found that the issue was with the attached root volume: vol-036b9d19ca718b7fd depleting its burstbalance to 0 and hence freezing the volume after that.  The burst balance [1] of your EBS instance was getting depleted and was reduced to zero which means a lot of read and write operations were being done. Depletion of burst balance hinders performance and only GP2 EBS volumes have the concept of burst balance. This goes hand in hand with the size of the volume as well. The volume size determines the baseline performance level of the volume and how quickly it accumulates I/O credits; larger volumes have higher baseline performance levels and accumulate I/O credits faster. Volumes earn I/O credits at the baseline performance rate of 3 IOPS per GiB of volume size. For example, a 100 GiB gp2 volume has a baseline performance of 300 IOPS. However, all volumes with 33.33 GiB and below have a minimum baseline performance of 100 IOPS.  Now since your volume size is 50 GiB, the baseline for your volume is 150 IOPS. As soon as you start to operate above this 150 IOPS mark, you would be utilizing your burst balance. Once the burst balance depletes completely and reaches 0, your IOPS will be throttled. In your case, the volume went above 3000 IOPS [2] [3]. This caused it to go above the baseline (150 IOPS for 50 GiB) as a result of which burst balance was depleted and was reduced to zero which resulted in the instance getting stuck because application was pushing more than baseline IOPS(150 IOPS) even after zero burst-balance. Further, once the instance was stop-started again, the burst balance was restored and instance became reachable again.   Thus, to ensure proper performance of the EBS volume and prevent burst balance depletion, I

comm_body: Hello Ravi/Sagar/Sathya,  Thank you for your time on the call/chime screenshare. It was a pleasure working with you.  While on the call/chime screenshare we went through the reason the instance i-06e7dcd54f70238b1 was going into a stopped state right after launching as well as the new ami taken also having issues launching.  This was due to an access denied error on the CreateGrant API call due to:  errorCode   AccessDenied errorMessage   User: arn:aws:sts::997200155612:assumed-role/techm_iam_role_application_engineer/MP00636420@TechMahindra.com is not authorized to perform: kms:CreateGrant on resource: arn:aws:kms:ap-south-1:997200155612:key/5d55923a-7960-4782-aef1-e8c4b57680d4   This meant the role did not have permissions in order to use the key that the EBS Volume was encrypted with. Your colleague Sathya had changed the permissions on the KMS key to allow the role to access the KMS key that the EBS root volume was protected by.  After this was done the instance was able to be launched in a new subnet as desired. Next we attempted to connect with the openvpn client which was throwing a few errors as TLS key negotiation failed[1]. I had a suspicion the client config needed to be updated to point to the new Elastic IP attached to the newly launched instance i-07d2c1465be932123 which was confirmed on the client configs still pointing to vpn.zee5.com and not updated in the client config. After a new entry was made in the client configs to point to the elastic IP it was working as intended.  Next we went ahead to update the DNS entry for vpn-stg.zee5.com on Azure. Then we tested it out to verify the client config could be used for connecting to the staging vpn.  After this was done we went ahead to update the vpn load balancer in order to use the staging server instead of the currently unhealthy i-06e7dcd54f70238b1. After this was done the target groups were updated for port 22 and port 1194 forwarding.  It was noticed the UDP 1194 was marking the instance as unhealthy. This is a known issue for Network Load Bala

comm_body: Hello Uttam,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Neha and I will be assisting you on this case.  I understand the instance i-078302c4cfc00a439  was unavailable between  02 Oct 2020, 18:00 Hrs to 03 Oct 2020 16:00 Hrs.  I did review the instance metrics and could see the instance was failing its Instance level status checks(StatusCheckFailed_Instances[1]) between 2020-10-02 around 12:29 to 2020-10-03 around 10:39 UTC, but was passing its System level Status checks(StatusCheckFailed_System [2]).The CPUUtilization[3] of the instance was also within limits during the above time frame.Investigating the EBS metrics for the volumes I could see the volumes working as expected.  I did review the underlying hardware of the instance and it is currently healthy and does not show any packet loss. Since the instance started passing its status check after a stop/start the console logs also do not show any errors. From the above metrics it seems there was no AWS infrastructure related issues that could have caused the instance to fail its status check and we would have to further troubleshoot the issue from the Operating System level/application level.   There are several reason a instance may fail its Instance level status checks as mentioned in document [4], memory level congestion being one of them.You can identify if the system is running low on memory using the 'free -m' command.Also, consider analyzing or providing the OS level logs during the above time frame to identify any issue at the OS level that may have caused the instance status check to fail.The Os level logs are generally located under /var/log. Reviewing the AMI, it seems its an amazon linux based AMI and the log files to reviewed during the above time frame are   /var/log/messages /var/log/dmesg /var/log/boot.log  Further, if you are not already using, you may also consider using "atop" so as to determine if the instance is running into any resource level congestion. Atop is a linux utility that monitors the performance of cpu, memory an

comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for your patience while waiting for my return.  I have reviewed the instances i-0157a555aee0bfae8 and i-0ddc5ffc207080fc5, and understand that you have rebooted then around 03:40AM UTC of October 07th. The Operating System got stuck during the boot process and only completed the boot after you stop/start the instances. Please correct if I am wrong.  The user-data script execution apparently stopped during the restart of the codedeploy agent. I would need to review the logs from the agent to see if we can confirm an issue with it. However, it is important to mention that your instance are running Red Hat 6, which is not officially supported to run the codedeploy agent[1]. It is not possible to guarantee that a fix will be provided if confirmed an issue caused by Operating System incompatibility.  In order to isolate the issue and narrow down the investigation I would like to ask a few questions and suggest some tests: - By default, user-data scripts only run on the first boot after the instance launch. Your instances were configured to execute a relatively extensive script at every boot. Why do you need all those routines to be executed during the boot? - I haven't identified any modification on the CodeDeploy agent configuration, why do you need to restart it at the end of every boot? - Your instances have the SSM agent running and online, have you considered moving some of your user-data routines to Systems Manager? Among other advantages, Systems Manager provides the State Manger feature that is a secure and scalable service way to keeping your EC2 instances in a state that you define.[2]   - Please update your user-data script and temporarily remove the "service codedeploy-agent restart" command. - Reboot your instances a few times and see if the problem is resolved. - If confirmed that the issue is caused by the codedeploy agent, reproduce the issue again, collect the logs in  /var/log/aws/codedeploy-agent and provide them for review. comm_body: Hello! Jason again and I had wanted to send you a followup from our chat!  You were looking into ways to work around the issues you were having with launching your instances in us-east-1f.  The error you are getting is what we call an Insufficient Capacity Error (ICE for short)[1], and simply means that the instance type you are trying to launch is simply not readily available within the AZ you are trying to launch it in. As a note to make as well, this has nothing to do with the limits on your account or otherwise any normal settings there within. The doc reference prior has steps you can take to try and mitigate this, but of the options you initially noted simply avoiding that AZ would be one of them. There are other ways to help ensure availability in this zone should you wish to stay in it as well, such as reserved instances[2] or capacity reservations[3], which may fit your use case as well.  Let me know if you have any followup questions and I'll see what I can do.  1) https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/troubleshooting-launch.html#troubleshooting-launch-capacity 2) https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/pricing/reserved-instances/ 3) https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-capacity-reservations.html  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Jason M. comm_body: Hello Manish,  This is Sajid from AWS Premium Support. It was nice having a chat session with you today, and here I would like to share the summary of our conversation.  As per the discussion, your clients are trying to access the application which is running on the EC2 Instance i-07843388432fb943d over its Public IP address 3.1.98.104, but they are unable to connect. Hence you wanted to know if there is any blockage on this Instance which may be causing the issue. Hence needed our assistance regarding the same.  As you mentioned that the clients are trying to access the application which is on the Ec2 Instance over 443(HTTPS). Therefore, using our internal tools, I checked the Security groups of this Instance from my side and was able to see that port 443 for open to all IPv4 addresses in the Inbound rules of SG sg-051ab7ee24a040dd4. Also, I couldn't see any restriction in the Outbound rules of the same. Moreover, I checked the Network ACL rules of this Instance and was able to see that you have blocked some IPs in the Inbound rules, rest of all the IPs are allowed. Also, there was no restriction in the Outbound rules in NACL.   Moving further I checked the route table of this Instance and was able to see that it was having Internet gateway which is allowing all traffic. Also, you mentioned that the firewall within the Debian based Instance is disabled.  I tried to check the connectivity over 443 to the Instance IP address using telnet command from the local machine and below is the result of the same;  --- # telnet  3.1.98.104 443 Trying 3.1.98.104... Connected to 3.1.98.104. Escape character is '^]'. ---  Also, from the nmap result we were able to see that port 443 is open for TCP connection and service is listening on this port without any issue; --- # nmap -PN -p 443 3.1.98.104  Starting Nmap 6.40 ( http://nmap.org ) at 2020-10-16 05:40 UTC Nmap scan report for ec2-3-1-98-104.ap-southeast-1.compute.amazonaws.com (3.1.98.104) Host is up (0.23s latency). PORT    STATE SERVICE 443/tcp open  https  Nmap done: 1

comm_body: Good day,  Thank you for reaching out to AWS Premium Support. My name is Philip and I will assist you with this case.  I understand that you would like to set IST as the default timezone for all new EC2 instance launches.  EC2 instances in all regions launch with UTC as their timezone. You may change the timezone setting during launch with a User Data [1] bash script with the timedatectl command [2]. Please view my example script below. To launch an instance with this script you need to define it on the "Configure Instance" step of the launch wizard, or alternatively in the launch template that you intend to use.  In the instance launch wizard, step 3 "Configure Instance" contains a User Data field. For Launch Templates, the User Data field is in the "Advanced details" section of the Create Launch Template form.  I have tested this script to successfully change the timezone to IST on     # Amazon Linux 2   # RHEL 7.6   # RHEL 8   # Ubuntu 20.04 LTS  in the ap-south-1 region.  To test this, copy and paste all the text between the dashed lines, into the User Data field as described above.  ------------------------- Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="//" MIME-Version: 1.0  --// Content-Type: text/cloud-config; charset="us-ascii" MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="cloud-config.txt"  #cloud-config cloud_final_modules: - [scripts-user, once]  --// Content-Type: text/x-shellscript; charset="us-ascii" MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="userdata.txt"  #!/bin/bash timedatectl status timedatectl set-timezone 'Asia/Kolkata' timedatectl status -------------------------  To check the time, and time zone on your instance, you can run     $ timedatectl status  If you have any further questions or queries, you are welcome to reply to to this case, or to initiate a chat or call from within this case.  References: ========= [1] Instance metadata and user data - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuid

comm_body: Hello,  Greetings of the day !  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Abhishek here and I am glad to assist you with this case.  From the case correspondence, i understand that one of the instance is having a spikes in memory utilisation on the instance and you would like to know the reason behind it.  Please correct me if my understanding of the issue is not accurate.  Thank you for providing the instance id i-0f4eea456c0321ecd. Using internal tools i confirm that this instance is of t2.micro (x86_64) which has 1 vCPU and 1.0 GiB memory. Using internal tools i confirm that the instance is running with the CentOS 7.   Before proceeding further according to Data Privacy Policy [1], AWS engineers are not allowed to directly access customer's instance/data since data privacy and security is our top priority.  Hence, we do not have the access to the memory utilization details of the instance and I wont be able to check inside the Instance about what caused the memory to exhaust.   To start understand the issue, please provide us the exact timing when you saw the memory spikes. A screenshot of these graphs will be a great help. These timestamps will help us relate these memory usage with other components like CPU and Volume IO.  Please run the below commands when you see the high memory usage in the graphs, to check the current memory usage during the time of issue  # cat /proc/meminfo # free -k # vmstat # top -o %MEM -b -n 10 > /tmp/topresult  Run the above command and attach the /tmp/topresult file.  To check, which process taking memory over a period of time we need to install monitoring tool like "sar" which will give us more info.  SAR is a system activity report provided by the "sysstat" package [1].  If it is already installed and running please get us the, below sar report files,  where sar15 and sar 16 are for values on October 15th and 16th, 2020 respectively.  # /var/log/sa/sar15 # /var/log/sa/sar16  If you could not find those files, then try running these # sar -r -f /var/log/sa/sa15 # s

comm_body: Hi Prathamesh,  This is Jose from the EC2 Linux team at AWS Premium Support and it was a pleasure working with you today. Here is a recap of our call/screenshare.  Today you reached out to us because you were unable to reach yum repository on instance i-070fefb25630d1485  From our troubleshooting session today, we found that you are unable to reach the yum repositories.  When you tried doing command 'telnet subscription.rhn.redhat.com 443' it showed that the domain 'subscription.rhn.redhat.com' was correctly resolved to IP 209.132.183.107 but it failed/timeout to establish the connection which leads me to believe that your VPN/Proxy doesn't allow the connection.   Sample of the output you got:    # telnet subscription.rhn.redhat.com 443   Trying 209.132.183.107...  We also checked the following and there was nothing that could account for the issue you are experiencing:   - yum configuration  - no firewall running on the instance  - SELinux   - security group   - sg-0c58ce7ae5a4d6758   - you had network connectivity as you successfully executed command 'wget google.com'  As I can see you are using transit gateway 'tgw-0a5bd66421d35e9e1' for internet connectivity on your RouteTable 'rtb-05a31ca2edc717983' I would recommend checking with your networking team to make sure that the RHEL endpoints can be reached.  Lastly, from the output you provided from the yum log, we saw that you also need to configure the proxy settings in your instance   https://access.redhat.com/solutions/65300    2020-10-20T11:17:43Z DEBUG error: Curl error (51): SSL peer certificate or SSH remote key was not OK for https://rhui3.ap-south-1.aws.ce.redhat.com/pulp/mirror/protected/rhui-client-config/rhel/server/8/x86_64/os [SSL: no alternative certificate subject name matches target host name '185.46.212.88'] (https://rhui3.ap-south-1.aws.ce.redhat.com/pulp/mirror/protected/rhui-client-config/rhel/server/8/x86_64/os). comm_body: Hello Anitha,  This is Millicent from AWS Premium support again. It was a pleasure talking with you on call  a moment ago.  You reached out to us today as you were not able to curl to your http end point hosted on instance ID 'i-0e2b8f26fdb3e948b'  from an Azure Machine on a public subnet.  During our call, you mentioned that you were able to reach the endpoint on your production instance 'i-0c9e50e3f3386cabc ' and not staging 'i-0e2b8f26fdb3e948b'.  1. The working instance  'i-0c9e50e3f3386cabc '  is on a public subnet with a public IP '13.232.17.25' and running a telnet from Azure instance was successful as below:    [z5adminroot@test-searchproject ~]$ telnet 13.232.17.25 80  Trying 13.232.17.25...  Connected to 13.232.17.25.  Escape character is '^]'.    As mentioned subnet is public if it has a default route pointing to an Internet Gateway. In this way, any EC2 instances from the public subnet can access the Internet and can be reached from internet based on security group rules.   2. The second instance ID 'i-0e2b8f26fdb3e948b' which is staging is on a private subnet and therefore will not be reachable from the public subnet for Azure as explained.    [z5adminroot@test-searchproject ~]$ telnet 10.141.51.134 80  Trying 10.141.51.134...  ^C     Therefore to resolve the connection issue, we agreed that you would talk to your network team to  allow the staging instance to be reachable from Azure on the VPN setup.    Please also see below a good third party link that could help understand how the VPN setup works: https://cloudmonix.com/blog/connect-amazon-vpc-to-azure/   I trust this correspondence proves useful. However, should you have any other questions or need additional clarification, please feel free to get back to us and we will be happy to assist you.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hey Rexeena,  It was a pleasure chatting with you earlier today.  You opened a chat with us today as you were still experiencing issues with your instance not appearing as managed by SSM.  While on the chat with you I was able to take a look at the instance and I had a look over the document you provided with the screenshots. From the document I was able to see that when you executed the following command:  Invoke-RestMethod "http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/info"  You received an error message which you confirmed I asked you to connect to the instance and try to access 169.254.169.254 from the browser within your instance. You were unable to successfully connect to the IP from your browser.  We decided to go on screenshare together so that I could see the errors and better guide you in resolving the issue. I asked you to run the command route print so I could check the routes configured on your instance from here I was able to see that the routes were incorrectly configured.  The routes you had for the following IP's 169.254.169.251, 169.254.169.250 and 169.254.169.254 were pointing to the gateway address 10.160.17.1 were as your actual gate way is 10.160.16.1. We tried to modify the routes using the Script Add-Routes.ps1 unfortunately the script was not correctly executing so we had to manually modify the routes.  We used the following command to modify the routes to remove the incorrect routes and add the correct routes back in.  route DELETE 169.254.169.251 route DELETE 169.254.169.250 route DELETE 169.254.169.254  route -p ADD 169.254.169.254 MASK 255.255.255.0 10.160.16.1 route -p ADD 169.254.169.251 MASK 255.255.255.0 10.160.16.1 route -p ADD 169.254.169.250 MASK 255.255.255.0 10.160.16.1  After we did this you were able to successfully access 169.254.169.254 from your browser we then restarted the SSM agent service and saw the instance now appearing as managed by SSM.  We also looked into trying to resolve the issue with the CloudWatch Agent and I was able to see that you were missing the Clou

comm_body: Hello Mitch,  Welcome to AWS Support, my name is Joel.  From the case details, I see that when you filter under "Owned by me" in the AMIs page of the EC2 console, you get a "Read timed out" error.  What you are experiencing is a known issue that can occur when an account has several thousands of AMIs. Viewing your AMIs, at the time of writing, you have 39,787 in your US-EAST-1 Region.  I completely understand how frustrating this issue is. The most recent update I see is that the EC2 User Experience team is working on a fix, and at this time AWS Support doesn't have an ETA to share. I will push for another update and add your case and sentiment.  In the meanwhile, a workaround would be to use the AWS CLI to retrieve the AMIs you're looking for. For example:  Filtering for AMIs with names starting with Digital*: $ aws ec2 describe-images --owners self --query 'Images[].{Name:Name,ImageID:ImageId}' --filters Name=name,Values=Digital* --cli-read-timeout 0  Filtering for AMIs with names starting with Splunk*: $ aws ec2 describe-images --owners self --query 'Images[].{Name:Name,ImageID:ImageId}' --filters Name=name,Values=Splunk* --cli-read-timeout 0  Please note that filter values (e.g., "Digital") are case sensitive.  I've also attached two txt files to the case (describe-images-Digital.txt, describe-images-Splunk.txt) with the output of the above read-only commands - I hope this can help a little bit.  I'll update you again when I hear back from the internal team.  References: [1] AWS CLI - https://aws.amazon.com/cli/  To see the file named 'describe-images-Digital.txt,describe-images-Splunk.txt' included with this correspondence, please use the case link given below the signature.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Joel K. Amazon Web Services  ======

comm_body: Hi Leon,  Thanks for your time on the chat, it's great to see that you've managed to restore the instance.  Following is a short summary about what we've discussed:  A. The instance health check issue with i-0dd0d422e9e4fccc0 -- The issue with the instance i-0dd0d422e9e4fccc0 failed to boot is that, the instance has additional EBS volume /dev/sdg (volume ID vol-095047021645f3890), the volume /dev/sdg also has root partition configured, so when the instance is rebooting, there are 2 volumes presenting as root : /dev/xvda and /dev/sdg. Although /dev/xvda is perfectly fine, the instance might randomly pick one root to boot from, since the root in /dev/sdg does not have proper network configuration, the instance could not start its network stack, hence the instance failed the health check. The issue was fixed by Stop/Start the instance (and luckily the OS booted from /dev/xvda this time around). -- In future, if the instance is rebooted again, the same issue may happen again, when that happens, Stop/Start the instance a few times will eventually let the instance boot from the right root. -- In a longer term, removing the duplicate root from /dev/sdg will be the permanent fix.  B. The instance health check issue with i-0fd295e7a31df960e -- From the instance console log, it appears the instance runs out of space. Once the root volume of the instance has space increased, the instance was able to pass health check in next Stop/Start.  C. The upgrade path for DLAMI -- For instances running DLAMI, the recommended path of upgrading is to launch a new instance with latest DLAMI, then move the EBS volumes from old DLAMI to new one. More details can be found in this link: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/dlami/latest/devguide/upgrading-dlami.html  Please let us know if you need further assistance. Have a good evening!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in

comm_body: Hello Ashok, I understand you have questions about setup of SQL Clients specifically .NET applications and linux applications.   The guide I mentioned will work work on all applications that communicate with the SQL Server. As for .NET applications, the application will automatically take advantage of TLS1.2 provided you have the necessary patches. I have included some Microsoft Blogs which highlight these steps and necessary registry changes to force the .NET applications to use TLS. The usage of TLS is more or less on an application by application basis and is to be enabled client side. There is no single step that can enable TLS for all.  * https://blog.coeo.com/securing-connections-to-sql-server-with-tls * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/network-programming/tls * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/configmgr/core/plan-design/security/enable-tls-1-2-client (This will ensure the system uses TLS1.2 by default)  Thank you! If you have any further questions within the scope of Premium Support, please do not hesitate to ask. Have a good day!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Greetings Revanth,   I've checked the EFS resources (I wasn't positive which one was attached to the instance, so I went ahead and checked all 4) as well, and do not see any performance bottleneck occurring.    To restate from the chat, we've checked EBS metrics, CPU Utilization, and now EFS metrics and do not see any performance bottlenecks occurring at the times mentioned. Additionally, I've checked the NetworkIn and Out metrics,and while there's a fair amount of traffic occurring around 0300-0400 UTC, this is not during the time allotted, nor does it follow hte "slowly become unresponsive after a reboot" behavior we are seeing.   That brings me to the following. There are a couple things that I do not have access to that we can check, so I would therefore need your assistance. We can check the dmesg and /var/log/messages log, as well as any memory statistics.   1. Logs:   I've attached an S3 bucket to this case, the link is at the end of the correspondence. We would want to check the dmesg log and messages for any possible errors or log entries that would direct us to the cause of this slowness. Also, if the users are accessing the instance through any sort of program or application, those application logs would be useful as well.    In short, the logs we would be looking for would be dmesg, messages, and application logs. The commands to provide them and locations are noted below:   For dmesg:   $ dmesg   - Will print out the log.   Also located in /var/log/boot.log    For Messages:   'journalctl' will print out the current syslog, and although it is slightly different than the messages log it should still contain all the details.    The log is located in /var/log/messages.    I am unsure of your current applications, as I do not have instance level access. Please provide any applicable logs as well.    2. Memory statistics:    If there is any resource monitoring applications on your instance,those would be beneficial. By default, CloudWatch does not record memory statistics, so we would want to check those

comm_body: Hi Vivek,  This is Jeannot again, from AWS Premium Support (Linux). I am writing to give you a summary of our chat.  After you tried the first and second options as our documentation [1], you were not still able to launch your EC2 instances. I advised that you should try to change the instance type as the third option. However, R4 instance types belong to Xen platform, you needed to change the instance type to Nitro-based.  Having said that, I recommended this AWS knowledge center article, Why is my Linux instance not booting after I changed its type to a Nitro-based instance type? - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/boot-error-linux-nitro-instance/.  Here are some instance types that you can use instead of r4.8xlarge [2]:   Instance   vCPU Memory (GiB) Instance Storage (GiB) Networking Performance (Gbps) EBS Bandwidth (Mbps)  r5.8xlarge  32  256    EBS-Only    10        6,800  r5a.8xlarge  32  256    EBS-Only    Up to 10      4,750  r5n.8xlarge  32  256    EBS-Only    25        6,800  As agreed, I will be marking the case resolved. If you have other queries, please feel free to open up new case.   Have a good day!  References: [1] Troubleshooting instance launch issues - Insufficient instance capacity - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/troubleshooting-launch.html#troubleshooting-launch-capacity [2] Amazon EC2 Instance Types - https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello,   Sean here in AWS Premium Support. I hope you're keeping well.   As per your message I understand you're running into "RequestLimitExceeded" error when calling the DescribeInstances operation.   I reached out to the Service team with the api limit increase request. However, the Service team have responded and advised that when you're been affected by throttled API calls,  we first require for you to put measures in place like an 'exponential backoff' logic to your applications and only after measures have been taken then would a limit increase be considered by ourinternal team, but do note that this is not guaranteed.   This policy was created in order to be able to provide a reliable service which prevents a single customer from affecting other customers inside our infrastructure:  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/api-retries.html  Thus, Your best bet to resolve throttling entirely is to spread your calls out over a longer period, instead of making almost all of them in the same second.  I have located a blog on Exponential Backoff And Jitter which you may find useful here:   https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/architecture/exponential-backoff-and-jitter/ https://www.baeldung.com/resilience4j-backoff-jitter  Once the recommendations are implemented, please let me know if you still face the errors and rest assured I can further investigate.   I hope this information helps.     We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Sean M. comm_body: Hi Vivek,  Thank you for your valuable time on chat today. Please find a brief summary of our discussion below:  You reached out to us as you were unable to launch r4.8xlarge, m4.10xlarge and r4.4xlarge instance types in ap-south-1c. I informed that these instance types are not supported in ap-south-1c. I also mentioned that you can get a list of all supported instance types in an AZ by running: "describe-instance-type-offerings" command. On running the command, you found that ap-south-1c supports only nitro based instances and you need to launch either r4.4xlarge or similar instance type in ap-south-1c AZ only .   I informed you that r5 provides better performance than r4 and it is supported in ap-south-1c, so you may consider launching r5 instead of r4 (if your application allows). You mentioned that the AMI is an old AMI and hence, I suspected that the AMI may not have required drivers for nitro based instances. I added that, since ap-south-1c does not support r4.4xlarge there is no way to launch this instance type in ap-south-1c. Hence, you can launch r4 instance from the AMI in any other AZ and then install nvme and ena drivers on that instance (if not already present). Then, create an AMI from that instance and launch r5 instance from the new AMI in ap-south-1c AZ. However, I also mentioned that due to lack of visibility I am not sure about the configuration of AMI and hence I cannot be sure about whether the instance will come up as r5 or not.  Please accept our apologies for the trouble caused due to lack of instance type in the required Availability Zone.  Further, as discussed, I would be marking this case as resolved and in case you have any other concerns, you can always reach out to us via a new support case and we would be more than glad to assist you.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Good day,  Thank you for contacting me via chat.  You came through as you spot instance was stopped due to capacity shortage in the availability zone.  Spot Instances are spare compute capacity in the AWS Cloud. Spot Instance capacity is interrupted when Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) needs the capacity back. The no Spot capacity available error occurs when there isn't enough spare capacity to fulfill your Spot Instance or Spot Fleet request.  As capacity becomes available, Amazon EC2 fulfills requests in the following order:  * Reserved Instances * On-Demand Instances * Spot Instances  The Spot request continues to automatically make the launch request until capacity becomes available. When capacity becomes available, Amazon EC2 fulfills the Spot request. More information can be found from the following link:  Why am I receiving a "no Spot capacity available" error when trying to launch an Amazon EC2 Spot Instance?: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-spot-instance-insufficient-capacity/#:~:text=Spot%20Instances%20are%20spare%20compute,Instance%20or%20Spot%20Fleet%20request.  Unfortunately the only way to guarantee that there will be capacity available for the new instance type when you require it would be to purchase reserved instances, as regular on-demand instance launches are subject to the available capacity in the Availability Zone they are requested on being enough to accommodate them at the time of the request. Further information on Reserved Instances can be found here [2].  [2] Reserved Instances -  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-reserved-instances.html  We understand that you may need the required capacity anytime you want. If there is a strict requirement for a given fixed period, you may consider using zonal instance reservation which also provides reserved capacity for the entire fixed duration[3].   [3] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/reserved-instances-scope.html  To overcome this situation you can also purchase the r

comm_body: Greetings,    It was a pleasure working with you on this case today. We investigated an issue with 522 errors from https://plugins.gradle.org/m2/ and the URLs beneath it (for example, https://plugins.gradle.org/m2/com/google/cloud/tools/jib/com.google.cloud.tools.jib.gradle.plugin/1.8.0/com.google.cloud.tools.jib.gradle.plugin-1.8.0.pom) when retrieving the hosted file from the Mumbai Region.   I can confirm, through testing, that this appears specific to the Mumbai Region, as Sydney, Singapore, Northern Virginia and Ohio all were able to download the file. However, all attempts through Mumbai receive a 522 error.    Unfortunately, 522 errors occur when a TCP connection to the webserver could not be established, in this case between  Cloudflare and the Gradle webserver. This occurs when the origin web server (Gradle's) does not send a SYN+ACK within 15 seconds or acknowledge Cloudflare's resource request within 90 seconds; therefore, it cannot complete the three-way handshake required for a TCP connection. With that being the case, I do not have any control over Gradle's webservers. I do have additional information for your reference on 522 errors here:  [1] 522 Errors: https://community.cloudflare.com/t/community-tip-fixing-error-522-connection-timed-out/42325  [2] Additional information on 522 Errors: https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003011431-Troubleshooting-Cloudflare-5XX-errors#522error   Additionally, it appears that other Gradle customers are currently experiencing the same issue:  [3] Gradle 522 errors: https://discuss.gradle.org/t/bombay-region-gradle-plugins-returns-522-https-plugins-gradle-org-m2/38156   There are a couple of workarounds for this issue that may be able to alleviate the issue temporarily.    1. Simply, we can scp or ftp the file from your local machine to the EC2 instance.  There tons of alternative file transferring options available as well. SCP, if you already use SSH in a terminal (for example if you use a Mac or Linux device locally) is likely the easiest to set
