comm_body: Dear Sourabh,  This is Dean from the AWS Premium Support Linux Team, it was a pleasure speaking to you over chat earlier.  Our chat was prematurely terminated before I could provide you with more information. However I can confirm that I have the information that you requested.  During our chat I spent time researching a possible reason as to why the Gravitron instance types were unavailable, and I believed it be the fact that they were not populating due to the AMI in the launch configuration/template for your spot requests.   Afterward you had questions regarding the spot-interruption rates for ap-south-1 (Mumbai) I tried to determine this from my side however there was/is no data for these instance types, the Spot Instance interruption rate data is based on the Frequency of interruption represents the rate at which Spot has reclaimed capacity during the trailing month. They are in ranges of < 5%, 5-10%,10-15%,15-20% and >20%.   In this case, if instances are not in the table it means there is no data on spot instance interruptions for a given region, I checked for other regions (af-south-1, Cape Town and eu-south-1, Milan) and I see that some Gravitron instance family types do not reflect here either along with other instance types, so here we see its not specific to the instance type but rather the data required to generate interruption rates, the values of these rates depend on the usage/launches of spot instances over time i a particular region.   I do however thank you for allowing me to look into this for you, and allowing you to answer your question.   If you have any additional followup questions on this matter then please feel free to revert back to me.   References:  https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/spot/instance-advisor/ https://spot-bid-advisor.s3.amazonaws.com/spot-advisor-data.json https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61523868/how-to-obtain-amazon-ec2-spot-instance-interruption-rates  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at

comm_body: Greetings, Thank you for reaching out to us.  As per the discussion on the chat, the instance was failing status check. On checking the error message in System log, it was seen that the OS was waiting for device /dev/nvme1n1 but it was not attached. We detached attached the root volume to the recovery instance, mounted the volume and commented the faulty fstab entry. Then we booted from the volume and it worked.  As discussed, I have marked the case as closed. If you have other issues or concerns, please do  reach out to us.  Have a good one !!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Satyam S. comm_body: Hello Kailas,  This is Siya and this serves as a summary of our chat earlier on.  You reached out as you were having issues with your instance "i-07aa006dbca33ce40" which Starts but suddenly goes to Stop state with an error "Client.InstanceInitiatedShutdown"  Upon doing a thorough research and investigation on this issue, I was able to narrow this issue to an action being triggered from the OS of the instance. In particular, the "Client.InstanceInitiatedShutdown" occurs when there is a $shutdown -h commands that is triggered from the OS of this instance.  Please note, as AWS engineers we do not have access to the OS level of your instances due to strict security constraints, so I am therefore unable to see what or who exactly runs this $shutdown -h inside the instance. However, as a way to mitigate and find the root cause of this issue, we need to have  access to the OS level of this instance to be able to see what triggers the $shutdown -h command. To do this, you would have to    1. Detach the root volume of the instance "i-07aa006dbca33ce40" and attach it to another instance test instance as secondary volume.   2. Mount the volume to be able to have access to its OS shell.   3. Execute the following to check what triggers the shutdowm i.e     3.1.  Please check which Target is the default target in your instance. It could be that the default target on th instance is set to 0     $ systemctl get-default     $ systemctl set-default graphical.target    3.2 You can execute the following commands to display the list of last reboots/shutdowns. However this does not point out who has initiated it. But we can get an overview of it.       $ last reboot | less     $ last -x | less     3.3 Check on the /etc/fstab     - In here you looking to see all entries are referenced properly and that there are no typos     3.4. I see from the instance startup up logs at time of booting up initially, the instance Networking Service is not started. eth0 device  status is false. It would be worth checking as to why the instance netwo

comm_body: Hi Ruby,  This is Duc again from AWS Premium Support, I just wanted to follow up with you about this ticket.  You reached out to us because when you run command "/apollo/env/MusicPersonalizationPlatformAdmiralWorkflows/python3.6/bin/real/python3.6 ", you ran into errors with:   /lib64/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.25' not found (required by /apollo/env/MusicPersonalizationPlatformAdmiralWorkflows/python3.6/lib/libpython3.6m.so.1.0)  This error indicates the issues is python 3.6 in your machine compiled/linked against GLIBC-2.25 (or later). To check the version of GLIBC, you can run the following command:  $ ldd --version . Since you will have to drop the chat, and I am not 100% sure about your environment ( Your AMI is private ), it's hard for me to suggest the next steps, because upgrading GLIBC can break a lot of programs running within your instance that relies on the current GLIBC. Moving forward, please feel free to initiate another chat/call with us, and the available engineer will be able to help you with troubleshooting further.   I hope you found these information useful. Should you have further questions, please let me know. I will be more than happy to help.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Good day,  Parker here and a pleasure to be working this case.  The instance appears healthy and reachable. I will need further information give the exact problem however, I noticed the instance was managed by Systems Manager. There is an option of using an automation document for automated troubleshooting with the details in the link below: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/troubleshoot-connect-windows-instance.html#Troubleshooting-Remote-Desktop-Connection-issues-using-AWS-Systems-Manager  The document will fix common issues such as administrator password reset and OS-level firewalls. Alternatively, refer to the manual steps here: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/troubleshoot-connect-windows-instance.html#rdp-issues   These are the details from my end:  - There are no status check failures and the instance screenshot shows a boot screen. - There is an RDP certificate in the system log[2] indicating RDP is set and the default Administrator is in-use. - The instance is in a private subnet and it must be accessed by a bastion host. - The security group has 180.190.3.170/32, 180.190.3.171/32 and AD CIDRs on sg-0a1fa5f4f6a78ce49 for RDP access. However, there is a 446 - 65535 (0.0.0.0/0) rule allowing all IP addresses. If this were to be an issue I would suggest running the following command from the bastion hosts:  Test-NetConnection 10.160.55.21 -port 3389  The SourceAddress field indicates the bastion outgoing address. Additionally, this command tells if you are able to make a connection to the host. - There is a NACL blocking access to the 172.31.0.0/20 CIDR block.  In summary, the instance appears reachable and more information is needed for an answer. Namely: 1. The RDP screenshot error. At a glance, a screenshot indicates if it is a networking, OS-level or password issue. 2. Does Test-NetConnection return true for bastion hosts? If so, may I have the full output? 3. Has the automation document been attempted? If so, what is the commandID?  I trust there is enough in

comm_body: Hello,  Greetings for the day!  Thank you for reaching back. I understand that you have some further queries related to EC2 and subnets.  Regarding your query about instance only having a Public IP and not a private IP, I want to explain that and EC2 instances require private IP to interact with resources in within the VPC and AWS infrastructure. We cannot also remove the private IP as it will be like removing the Network Interface of the instance in which the instance will stop communicating with the AWS environment and will result into 1/2 checks failing. The public IP however, is required to interact with the internet such that the internet is publically accessible from the internet.  Regarding your query "is there a way to convert/move the current IP from Private VPC to Public IP Subnet?" The Private IP cannot be moved to another subnet/VPC because the Private IP is assigned within a CIDR range and each subnet has a different CIDR range. Thus, we will not be able to assign same Private IP in a different subnet.  Now, coming to your query on how to assign a Public IP to the instance or move the instance to a public subnet. You can achieve this via either of the two methods given below:  A. Convert the existing Private Subnet into a Public Subnet: ==========================================  1. Create an Internet gateway for your current VPC (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Internet_Gateway.html#Add_IGW_Attach_Gateway).  2. Add a route in the route table/ Replace the route for destination "0.0.0.0/0" and add your Internet Gateway instead of NAT gateway "nat-0b9b37f465aac79e0".(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Internet_Gateway.html#Add_IGW_Routing)  3. Now create/Allocate an Elastic IP.(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-addresses-eip.html#using-instance-addressing-eips-allocating)  4. Now associate this Elastic IP address with the Network Interface "eni-06d24536"of your instance.(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-a
comm_subject: RE:[CASE 8024212371] Request details to allow internet access to EC2

comm_body: Hello James,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Priyanka and I will be assisting you with the case today.  I understand that you would like to know the instance status check failure details which occurred at 12:45:00 - 01:15:00 UTC 2021-02-21. Feel free to correct me if I am wrong.  I have reviewed the instance i-06468fc5b908d8815 performance metrics and could see that there was no issue reported with the underlying host[1] during the same time. On further investigation on this, I didn't find evidences of an underlying host issue/failure and therefore you may need to review the OS level logs to understand why this has occurred at instance/OS level.  Further, I checked the other performance metrics of the instance like the CPU Utilization [2] and EBS volume performance, and I could see both are operating normally. Unfortunately, we do not have access to the memory usage of your instance, hence I will not be able to comment on that part. Also, I didn't find anything unusual from the instance console logs like OOM killer (as the logs are older) but I can see that the various services have failed to start.  Generally, the instance status check failure detect problems that require your involvement to repair from your end. Instance status check failure can be caused by many reasons such as :          - Startup configuration         - Exhausted resources likes memory, CPU, disk etc.         - Corrupted file system         - Incompatible kernel (Operating System itself)         - Some custom-script causing the issue  https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/system-reachability-check/          Please allow me to convey to you that under AWS data privacy[3] and our Shared responsibility model[4], AWS Support engineers do not have any access or visibility to the data, configurations, processes or applications running inside the instance. The data within the EC2 instances is completely owned by the customers and only they can access or control it.  As we AWS Engineers do not have any vis

comm_body: Hello Kiran,  Vediyappan here from AWS Premium support. It was my absolute pleasure assisting you on this case today.  Please refer to the brief summary of our discussion.  You have contacted us that EC2 instances running SUSE 15 SP 2 (e.g i-0a9ff84002259131d ) will not registered to SUSE Public Cloud Update infrastructure.  You had mentioned that, you have already tried to re-register using the "registercloudguest --force-new" command, however, the instance wasn't registered yet.  Further, you confirmed the yast and zypper commands are not working due to the registration issue. Here are some possible reasons for the SUSE registration fails.  1- EC2 instance is in a private subnet without internet connection 2 - EC2 instance is in a public subnet but without a public IP address, or without proper internal routing 3 - Missing billingProducts code:  # curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/dynamic/instance-identity/document | grep -i billing billingProducts" : [ "bp-6ca54005" ], This is can happen if the customer creates a snapshot from the root volume and manually register an AMI  Upon checking the instance details, I have noticed that instance was launched in the public subnet, however, there is no public IP assigned to that. Therefore, I advised to assign the public IP address and re-register the instance, after that, everything was started working fine.  At this moment, I shall mark this case as resolved. Should you have any queries or clarification, please feel free to contact us back. We'll be happy to assist you.  Have a wonderful day ahead!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Vediyappan K. comm_body: Hi Shravan & Mangesh,  Thank you for your time today. It was nice talking to you.  To summarize our discussion on the session : You were unable to connect to the instance via Session Manager.   The instances were in a private subnet and thus, I mentioned that we would need to create VPC endpoints[1] so that instances can connect to SSM and we can then access them via Session Manager. Once we created the endpoints and configured the relevant security group with subnet CIDR of the subnet to which instances belonged, you were able to access them via Session Manager.  However, this broke the session manager access for other instances in this VPC. I requested my colleague Romesh to join the call for further assistance and he was able to point out that instead of adding subnet CIDR in the security group of VPC endpoint, we should add the VPC CIDR. Once we did that, the access to instances via Session Manager was restored for all the instances.   As discussed on call, I am marking the case as resolved. In case of any queries/concerns in future, please do reach out to us again via Support Centre.  We are always happy to help. Have a great day ahead!  References :-  [1] https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-systems-manager-vpc-endpoints/  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Nagaraju,  It's Mawande here from AWS Support, thank you for your time on the chat today.  For enabling your instance for enhanced networking so it can be changed to a nitro based instance, we've performed the following additional commands while the instance is T2 type:  $ sudo yum upgrade kernel -y && sudo reboot $ sudo yum install kernel-devel-$(uname -r) gcc git patch rpm-build wget -y $ cd /usr/src/ $ sudo wget https://github.com/amzn/amzn-drivers/archive/master.zip $ sudo unzip master.zip $ cd amzn-drivers-master/kernel/linux/ena $ sudo make  $ sudo cp ena.ko /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/ $ sudo depmod $ modinfo ena $ sudo sed -i '/^kernel/s/$/ net.ifnames=0/' /boot/grub/grub.conf $ ethtool -i eth0  $ sudo depmod $ dracut -f -v $ rpm -qa | grep -e '^systemd-[0-9]\+\|^udev-[0-9]\+' $ sudo sed -i '/^GRUB\_CMDLINE\_LINUX/s/\"$/\ net\.ifnames\=0\"/' /etc/default/grub $ sudo grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg  If the below command shows "false": $ aws ec2 describe-instances --instance-ids i-09076e6ffd5e1e91c --query "Reservations[].Instances[].EnaSupport"  Stop the instance and run this command on the CLI then start instance on new type: $ aws ec2 modify-instance-attribute --instance-id i-09076e6ffd5e1e91c --ena-support  The issue is resolved now as you can connect to the T3A instance type. But, please feel free to reach back in case of any issues.  Have a pleasant day!  # https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/enhanced-networking-ena.html#enhanced-networking-ena-linux # https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/boot-error-linux-nitro-instance/ # https://github.com/awslabs/aws-support-tools/blob/master/EC2/NitroInstanceChecks/nitro_check_script.sh  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Mawande M. Amazon Web Services  ====

comm_body: Hello Faijal, it was a pleasure talking with you today. Following the call session, I'm sending you the recap of our conversation.   You reached us because the instance ID "i-0869f68a0fa9bfa75" was reporting 1/2 health status checks after an OS patch operation.  During the call, we successfully solved this issue by replacing its root volume (Problematic: vol-08c4a13ded1c85892) from the AMI backup (vol-01d2d572f8d2173e1).  After some minutes, the instance started successfully and you successfully RDP into it.  As this issue has been solved, I am archiving this case.  I hope this information is helpful, Should you have any concerns or questions please do not hesitate to contact us.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Santosh,  John here from AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure to assist you on the chat session. Please find a summary below.   You reached out to us as you were seeing some stale env variable entries in your instance after you had removed it from the /etc/profile and then sourced the file. You wanted to remove it without a reboot.   As mentioned over the chat session, if removing parameters from /etc/profile and sourcing the file is not working, then there are two option   - create a new session  - unset the env variable  -  unset http_proxy  Both these options don't need a reboot and you should see the effect immediately  There are some scenarios when removing the parameters from the /etc/profile and running source /etc/profile may not work and in such cases the above methods need to be used. In your case, using unset has removed the env variable and the new session also worked.   As discussed on the chat, I am marking the case as resolved. Please feel free to create a new case and raise a chat/call anytime as per your convenience.   Have a great day ahead !  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, John D. comm_body: Hello Rakesh,  Thank you for contacting Premium Support. I am Achilles and I would be one of the engineers assisting you with this case.  Thank you for your time on the call. During the call you mentioned that you got a notification where you're hitting CVE-2021-3177 and you would like to know how to resolve this. You would like this to be documented on the case as well.  Please let me know if I missed out on anything.  This CVE is applicable to Amazon Linux 1.  To fix the issues you will have to update the python packages on your Amazon Linux 1 instances.  1. To do this you will have to run the following command on your instances:       # yum -y update python27 python36 python38   2. Then you've to confirm that the version that python has installed is the one mentioned in the list below [2]:    You can check the version by using the following command:       # rpm -qa | egrep -e "python27" -e python36 -e python38       Example, you will have to check for the output `python27-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.x86_64` should be 2.7.18-2.141 or higher.  i686:     python38-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-libs-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-devel-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-debuginfo-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-debug-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-test-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python38-tools-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.i686     python27-tools-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python27-test-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python27-libs-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python27-debuginfo-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python27-devel-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python27-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.i686     python36-debug-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-devel-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-test-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-debuginfo-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-tools-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686     python36-libs-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.i686  src:     python38-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.src     python27-2.7.18-2.141.amzn1.src     python36-3.6.12-1.20.amzn1.src  x86_64:     python38-test-3.8.5-1.5.amzn1.x86_64     pytho

comm_body: Hello,  Greetings for the day!  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Rohit and I'll be assisting you with this case today.  From the case description, I infer that you have requested insight regarding getting details of your EC2 instances after they have been terminated. As you have intended to collect the IP and tags of these instances, you have inquired regarding the feasibility of this procedure. Please correct me if I misunderstood your query.  As per your concern, since the instances will be terminated, it will be removed from the console. Hence, there is no direct procedure to obtain the details regarding the instance using an API call such as DescribeTags or DescribeInstances.   However, I was able to check that, if enabled, AWS CloudWatch records and monitors the AWS API calls made to the resources. Here, the instance is provisioned with all these specification right from the launch time, you may be able to retrieve these details using CloudTrail logs here.   Using CloudTrail, if the instance was created in the last 90 days, you can get the information you want from Cloudtrail dashboard itself by searching for the RunInstances API call for the time the instance was created. You can query the Cloudtrail logs using Athena as discussed in the reference below:    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/athena/latest/ug/cloudtrail-logs.html  This procedure enhances your analysis of AWS service activity. For example, you can use queries to identify trends and further isolate activity by attributes.  However, if the instance was started more than 90 days ago, it will not be a feasible option to retrieve these details from the CloudTrail dashboard.  You can only retrieve these details if you have CloudTrail enabled and configured to write to S3 bucket. You can then go through the Cloudtrail logs and isolate for events related the instance id. Once you are able to locate the RunInstances API call for the instance id in discussion, you can then get all information about that instance from this event.  You

comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for your time on the chat.  You explained that you created an AMI from an existing t3a.medium EC2 instance, though new instances launched from this AMI was failing Instance Health checks.  Further review of EC2 instance (ID  i-0363863dcba28b477) indicated that CloudInit failed to bring up the networking interface:  [ FAILED ] Failed to start Initial cloud-init job (pre-networking). See 'systemctl status cloud-init-local.service' for details. [  OK   ] Reached target Network (Pre).          Starting LSB: Bring up/down networking... [   46.786891] random: crng init done [ FAILED ] Failed to start LSB: Bring up/down networking. See 'systemctl status network.service' for details.  I found that this is due to the following error:  [   43.714132] cloud-init[570]: OSError: [Errno 21] Is a directory: '/var/lib/cloud/instance'  When looking at the source EC2 instance from which the AMI was created, you confirmed that it was in fact a directory, and not a symbolic link:  $ file /var/lib/cloud/instance /var/lib/cloud/instance: directory   You removed this specific directory and created a new AMI, from which you launched new EC2 instances. These booted as expected, with networking being configured and passing health checks.  As discussed on the chat, I'm marking this as resolved for you.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hello Prashant,  Greetings! Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. I'm Tejas from EC2 Linux team and I will be assisting you with the case today.  I understand that you want to know if it is possible to install packages in the Linux system by creating any endpoint without opening port 80 to the internet (no internet connection). Please correct me if I am wrong.  This is possible in Amazon Linux 1/ 2 as Amazon Linux repositories are hosted in Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) buckets which can be reached via VPC endpoints, please refer [1] for details. (this will only work for the default repo, not for any custom or third party repos such as EPEL)  For other distribution, you do need one of these:  1) Route to the internet (IGW attached) [2] 2) VPN/Direct Connect connection to your data center that routes the yum request through the public internet [3] 3) NAT gateway [4] 4) NAT instance [5]  If there are some specific packages needed (telnet), I would suggest to create an AMI of your instance, launch it in public subnet, install what ever is needed and then create a final AMI of this instance and then launch that instance in private subnet with no internet, this will gave you the required packages installed in the instance.   I trust the aforementioned information was helpful to you.  In the meantime, If you have any follow-up questions/queries, please do not hesitate to reach out and we will be happy to assist. I wish you a safe and a pleasant day ahead!  References:  [1] https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-al1-al2-update-yum-without-internet/  [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Internet_Gateway.html  [3] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/whitepapers/latest/aws-vpc-connectivity-options/aws-direct-connect-vpn.html  [4] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-nat-gateway.html  [5] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_NAT_Instance.html  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi James,  Thank you for your patience.  Firstly, I would like to inform that this is third party application and I do not have expertise on it, hence I will try to help on my best effort basis.  From the error "The Module DLL C:\opt\shibboleth-sp\lib\shibboleth\iis7_shib.dll failed to load", I'm assuming "iis7_shib.dll" file is failing to load. From the operating system perspective, this generally occurs if the DLL is not registered or file is missing or corrupted.  I would request you to check the following configuration as per below articles :  - Verify that the Shibboleth ISAPI filter is installed - Verify that the handler mapping inheritance properly cascaded down to the website level. To verify, other settings, please follow the below article:  [+] Install and Configure Shibboleth for SAML on Windows and IIS : https://documentation.its.umich.edu/node/354  I'm assuming you are registering the DLL, However, I would request you to please re-registered the DLL as per below article :  Configuring the IIS7 DLL From the C:\Windows\System32\InetSrv directory, run the following lines:  appcmd install module /name:ShibNative32 /image:"c:\opt\shibboleth-sp\lib\shibboleth\iis7_shib.dll" /precondition:bitness32 appcmd install module /name:ShibNative /image:"c:\opt\shibboleth-sp\lib64\shibboleth\iis7_shib.dll" /precondition:bitness64  [+] Configuring the IIS7 DLL: https://www2.microstrategy.com/producthelp/2019/SystemAdmin/WebHelp/Lang_1033/Content/enabling_single_sign_on_with_saml_authentication_asp.htm  I found some articles which can be helpful, please check the blow articles : [+] https://nikokiuru.com/2014/02/iis7-and-shibboleth-sp-isapi-filter-problem-solved/ [+] https://wiki.shibboleth.net/confluence/display/SP3/Upgrading+Older+ISAPI+Configuration  After following the above steps and configuration, If you still facing the issue, please contact the application provider vendor.  Please let me know in case of any other query or concerns. Have a nice day!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by ratin

comm_body: Hello,  Thanks for contacting AWS Support. My name is Ryan and I will assist you today.  I understand the you wanted to know the cause of the slowness you observed on your EC2 instance i-052626c80f61de1eb for the past week. And, you wanted to know the IOPS performance on the EBS volumes you mentioned.  I reviewed the EBS metrics of the EC2 instance together with the volumes you mentioned between 2021-03-01 to 2021-03-08. While there are indications of possible EC2 instance level EBS throughput limit hit (e.g. r4.8xlarge is 875MBps), however, I can not confirm this yet because I do not have the exact timeframe when the slowness was observed from your end. Same with the EBS volumes mentioned, I can see some of the volumes going beyond their baseline IOPS but again, I'm not sure whether these had impacts and/or coincide to the time of the slowness you experienced.  That being said, kindly provide the below information. This will help us analyze further and narrow down the investigation.  1. Exact time, date and timezone when the slowness was observed. If the slowness was experienced several date or time, please send it as well. 2. If you have iostat metrics output in 1-second granularity taken during the time of the slowness, that would be great. Please send it as well, but if none then it should be okay.  Moreover, I did not find any underlying hardware issues affecting the EC2 instance in the past week.  Kindly reply back to the case so that we can continue the analysis on the EC2 instance and the volumes mentioned. I hope to hear back from you soon.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Ryan P. comm_body: Hi, Balaji,  This is Francisco, and I would like to thank you for your time on the chat today. It was a pleasure. Here is a recap of our conversation.  You opened the case looking for help changing the time zone settings on your instance. Your domain user, even being administrator, wasnt able to change the setting in the GUI.  During our screen share session, I noticed that the server was a domain joined server and that the settings console for time was managed by your domain.  I asked you to run the following command using powershell as administrator: Set-TimeZone -Name "India Standard Time"  The above command successfully changed the Time Zone of your server.  Then I informed that you can review the TZ settings in powershell by running Get-TimeZone.  Finally, you can check with your domain admin if the TZ settings (in the Windows settings) could be enabled for your servers if you wish to use the GUI next time [1]. Otherwise, you could just use the commands I shared with you above.  Again, it was a pleasure working with you in this request, and as I informed in the chat, I will mark this case as resolved, but if you have any related question, feel free to contact me. I will be happy to help.  Have a great day ahead!  [1] https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windows/en-US/4301b940-a9e5-42bd-bdb7-a49bdbb7cf7d/prevent-users-from-changing-time-zone?forum=winserverGP  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Francisco F. comm_body: Hi there,   Thank you very much for the meeting.   As per discussion, there are some info in the instance  i-0c68498b654180b03 console which indeicate Trend micro security software has been installed, and there were some old info about that the process have been blocked and, a module with a proprietary license has been loaded, i.e. a module that is not licensed under the GNU General Public License (GPL) or a compatible license . Those issues are possible to cause system performance issue and network issue.   We have tried to login the system and check the up to date info but you will need to attend another meeting, we have finished the discussion.   You have arranged another meeting at 5PM IST today, will need an AWS engineer to join the meeting. You also need updates from AWS service team, if there is any AWS network and hardware issue have caused the high latency issue.  I have ended of my today shift. I will update the ticket notes for what's the current situation and what should be the next.   Thank you again for your time, you have a great rest of the day!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi,  This is Mithun again from AWS Premium Support. Thank you for your time over the chat today. It was my pleasure assisting you.  You reached out to as you faced issues with the below mentioned instance during the mentioned timestamps.  2nd march - 04 pm to 5.30 pm UTC 2rd March  10.00  pm to 10.40 pm UTC 5th March - 5 pm UTC time 6th to 7th March -> All the time.  i-0c68498b654180b03, i-0361ccfa63e49aa4f, i-066e5f0038c1b3487, i-0b525f5106eebb334, i-052626c80f61de1eb, i-08421be9607866774  2nd march - 04 pm to 5.30 pm UTC  -> i-0c68498b654180b03 faced latency higher than usual at 2021-03-02 17:00 UTC. 2nd march - 04 pm to 5.30 pm UTC -> i-052626c80f61de1eb faced latency higher between 16:20 to 19:55 UTC  On 5th March - 5 pm UTC -> i-0c68498b654180b03, i-0b525f5106eebb334 faced slightly higher latency than the other timestamps at 2021-03-05 16:57 UTC and 16:59 UTC respectively and this shouldn't have caused any issues are instance level.  On 6th March -> i-066e5f0038c1b3487 had issue with network bandwidth at host level at 2021-03-06 19:38 UTC.  Other than the above time stamps, all the instance were running fine and there were no issues found with host network. Further, I have reached to my internal team to get more details about the above issues. Here please allow me to inform you that as the queries are handled by different team, I don't have any ETA on when they will revert back to me. However, I assure that I'll make sure that it gets the attention it needed. Till then, I'll put this case under 'Pending Amazon Action'.  That said, above issues occurred at host only during the above time stamps and now I can see that host network of the above mentioned six instances is fine and no issues are found.  With that said, you wanted to know more details of NetworkIn, NetworkOut metrics of EC2 instances.   NetworkIn - The number of bytes received by the instance on all network interfaces. This metric identifies the volume of incoming network traffic to a single instance.  NetworkOut - The number of bytes sent out b

comm_body: Greetings Aswin,  It was my utmost pleasure working with you today. Kindly find below summary of our discussion.  You were concerned about executing the following command, where it succeeds when executed at the CFN Stack creation, but fails with the below error when executed during the stack update:  !Join ["", ["hostnamectl set-hostname --static", " ", !Ref InstanceName, ".AIRVISTARA.COM"]] Could not set property: Connection timed out  In this regard, I recommended you reach out to our CFN Team for more effective assistance in this regard. Reviewing the other case, I could see that the command executes successfully with no errors when run directly through an SSH Terminal. Hence, my colleague Ali would be performing some tests form their side, and will reach you back through the other case.[1] Kindly find below references, discussing how to assign a static hostname to an Amazon EC2 instance running RHEL.[2-4]   I have linked both cases with each other. I will keep this case opened for now, to offer further assistance from our side if required. I hope the provided information prove useful to you. Should you have any other queries or concerns, please feel free to reach us back.  Always here for your convenience!  ========= References ========= [1]https://console.aws.amazon.com/support/home#/case/?displayId=8085323311&language=en  [2]https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/rhel-8-change-hostname-computer-name-command  [3]https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/linux-static-hostname-rhel7-centos7/  [4]https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/set-hostname.html#set-hostname-system  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Sriharsha,   Thank you for the time on the chat today. I would like to give you a summary of our interaction.   You contacted AWS when you mentioned you were not able to reach some ports on your instance [i-0707baad96252acdb] from instances even in the same VPC.  On the chat, we found out that the ports were reachable internally as the services were running appropriately. However, when you tried reaching the IP and ports from your bastion host [ i-08baf9f97e71d7fd0] in subnet-67c7730e you were unable to connect although the security groups were configured correctly.  On the chat I suggested we confirmed from the Windows firewall configuration if no incoming ports were being blocked. We confirmed that although the Private network profile was off, the Guest and Public network profile was turned on. You went ahead to turn off this profile on the Windows Firewall and you were able to successfully reach your instance on the desired ports from the other subnets.   As agreed on the chat, I will kindly resolve this case. However, if you have any issues in relation with this case, you may kindly reach out to us and we will be glad to assist you.   Thank you.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Nukunu K. comm_body: Hi Team,  Greetings!  Thank you for your time on chat . I would like to summarize the discussion we had.  Query :After upgrade windows 2012 to 2019 unable to see the task scheduler in the user login.  As we discussed Verifying the behavior after upgrade users/Author cannot see Tasks under task scheduler library where administrator can. Found observed issue associated with OS . However in order to Isolate the Issue with Tasks and User profile . We verified All Tasks are present under "C:\windows\system32\Tasks" . We went ahead check with other Userprofiles found similar Behavior. We tried enable hidden tasks ,Find similar pattern .  We went ahead tried creating new tasks . Can confirm they are visible to users. As mentioned as we at AWS do not have support and Visibility on OS as per the shared responsibility Model[1] therefore could not able to provide you the cause , However in order to track and isolate the issue further in order to proceed with our troubleshooting . We would suggest you to launch Instance from same 2012 AMI verify the current status of User/Authors and scheduled tasks . Perform In place upgrade verify this behaviour on 2019 OS.   I also went ahead and check the following articles that you can refer pertain to Scheduled Task[2][3].  [1]: https://aws.amazon.com/compliance/shared-responsibility-model/  [2]: https://superuser.com/questions/1140754/scheduled-task-is-not-running-or-showing-up-in-task-scheduler-windows-10  [3]: https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/windows_vista-performance/cant-find-task-in-task-scheduler/f76d43fd-f73d-43a5-a1b1-d42489b839aa  In the Meanwhile in case of any further assistance you can always revert back or engage TAM . We will be happy to assist you.  Have a great day ahead!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support, my name is Michael and I'll be assisting you today. It's my understanding that you have extended the root EBS volume vol-0a51ca65d447402cc of instance i-022f447bd3b1dceee and now the instance is unreachable.  Taking a look at Cloud Watch, I can see instance status check failure events logged starting at 2021-03-16 13:30 UTC [1]. This is what I can see from the latest console output:  BIG-IQ 7.1.0 Build 0.0.1511 Kernel 2.6.32-431.56.1.el6.f5.x86_64 on an x86_64 ip-172-10-88-113 login:  Recommendation: Instance status check failures in this case indicate an OS-level configuration issue (networking configuration, ssh keys, etc.). The only visibility I have currently into the state of the OS is the console output since last reboot. Please review the following log directories and files during the times above for potential causes: /var/log, /var/log/messages  These are the common reasons for failed system checks [2]:      * Failed system status checks     * Incorrect networking or startup configuration     * Exhausted memory     * Corrupted file system     * Incompatible kernel      1. Revert to a recent snapshot of the instance if one is available to return to an operation state     2. If no snapshot is available, try rebooting the instance to see if services start     3. Recover access to the instance by mounting the volume to another instance [3]         3.1 Stop the instance         3.2 Detach the root volume [4]         3.3 Attach it on to a different instance as a secondary volume [5]         3.4 Mount the secondary volume and review the system logs  If you have additional questions as youre going through this process, please feel free to contact us. As an Enterprise Support customer, chat and phone support is available to you, which may be necessary to work through individual troubleshooting steps.  References: ========= [1] https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=~(view~'timeSeries~stacked~false~metrics~(

comm_body: Good day Nasreen,  Christian here again.  You reached out because you are unable to retrieve the EC2 console password i-0fe82c1f5b5ab9532.  After investigation I saw that the instance was created from a custom AMI "ami-007c7de6d1f716f78" and I've explained that when a new instance is launched from an Amazon provided AMI's, EC2Launch service is configured to generate a random password from the console.  However, after you launch the instance, this setting will be disabled on EC2Launch and you will need to enable it before creating a custom AMI. If this setting is not enabled on EC2Launch before creating the AMI, the old password is captured as part of the AMI creation process and that password cannot be retrieved from the console.  Please refer to the article [1] for recommended process of creating Windows based AMIs.   If you don't have the password of the parent instance, you'll have to reset the password.  You can reset the password using AWS System Manager, however this requires the instance to be managed by Systems Manager and refer to article [2] for AWS Systems Manager prerequisites.  Alternatively you can use the EC2Recsue tool for offline method:  EC2Rescue(Offline) []: 1. Stop the problematic instance. 2. Launch temporary Windows instance (Helper instances) in the same subnet with i-0fe82c1f5b5ab9532 3. Detach the root volume from problematic instance and attach it with your newly created instance as secondary volume (device: xvdf). 4. Connect to the helper instance using RDP . 5. Download and extract EC2rescue tool. You can download the EC2Rescue software using link [3].  6. Click through until you see the choices for Current Instance or Offline Instance. 7. Select Offline Instance. 8. Select the affected disk. Ideally this will be the only other disk besides the root volume and as such should be the only option to select. 9. Once the volume is successfully loaded, select Diagnose and Rescue. 10. You'll see a list of things that can be fixed. 11. Select Next and you'll then see a list of checkboxes for

comm_body: Hi, Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Qaisar from the Cloud Support team. I understand your instance i-08c79aef57db2fa2a had a status check failed alert and you would like to know the reason behind it.   I had a look at the underlying hardware first to see if there were any issues at the underlying hardware level that would have generated the status check failed alert. I found out that the underlying hardware went into unhealthy state at the time you mentioned and caused the instance to fail status checks. I got the CloudWatch graph of the underlying hardware and it shows the status check failure.   https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=~(metrics~(~(~'AWS*2fEC2~'StatusCheckFailed_System~'InstanceId~'i-08c79aef57db2fa2a))~stat~'Sum~period~300~start~'2021-03-18T01*3a44*3a13.247Z~end~'2021-03-19T01*3a44*3a13.247Z~region~'ap-south-1)  Since the instance was stopped and started, it has now moved on to a new and healthy host. Here is the CloudWatch graph for the instance showing the Instance status check failure.   https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=~(metrics~(~(~'AWS*2fEC2~'StatusCheckFailed_Instance~'InstanceId~'i-08c79aef57db2fa2a))~stat~'Sum~period~300~start~'2021-03-18T01*3a52*3a17.185Z~end~'2021-03-19T01*3a52*3a17.185Z~region~'ap-south-1)  I do apologize for any inconvenience caused. We sent out regular emails for scheduled events, but this was an unscheduled event.   To prevent this from happening again, you can setup EC2 Auto Recovery.   EC2 Auto-Recovery is an Amazon CloudWatch alarm that monitors an Amazon EC2 instance and automatically recovers the instance if it becomes impaired due to an underlying hardware failure or a problem that requires AWS involvement to repair. I have added the document below that shows how to set it up.   https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/automatic-recovery-ec2-cloudwatch/  Let me know if you need further information on this case.

comm_body: Hi Raushan,  It was a nice discussion with you today. I'm glad to know that log restoration is working fine now.  Regarding to copy backup file slowness, I would suggest you follow below instruction to optimize your instances:  - You can try enabling the jumbo frame at source and destination servers.    [+] Network maximum transmission unit (MTU) for your EC2 instance  - Check and set the MTU on your Windows instance - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/network_mtu.html#set_mtu_windows   - To achieve the maximum network performance on instances with enhanced networking, you may need to modify the default operating system configuration. We recommend the following configuration changes for applications that require high network performance. Other optimizations (such as turning on checksum offloading and enabling RSS, for example) are already in place on official Windows AMIs.  [+] Operating system optimizations - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/enhanced-networking-os.html  I would like to confirm that the speed you are getting is expected. However I will suggest you to please confirm with AWS network team, You can raise another case and confirm the same.  Please let me know in case of any other query or concerns. Have a nice day! comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for reaching out.   I have provided steps for modifying the launch template. Once you have modified the launch template, it will create a new version of the current launch template and you will have to create an autoscaling group from the latest/updated version of the launch template.   Modifying the launch template to set the value of 'delete on termination' to true:  1) Access EC2 console -> Select Launch template under 'Instances' section 2) Click on the launch template that requires modification -> Action -> Modify template ( Create new version) 3) Under Storage (Volumes) section, expand the volume details -> Select the dropdown menu for 'Delete on Termination' ( I have attached screenshot of my aws console for reference) 4) Create template version and note the new version 5) On the same navigation pane under launch template select the launch template      Action -> Create Autoscaling group-> select the latest version (modified) from the dropdown and create a new autoscaling group for the updated version of launch template.   Please let me know if you have additional questions.  Reference: [+] Creating a launch template for an Auto Scaling group Delete on termination ( point 7.g )  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/create-launch-template.html#create-launch-template-for-auto-scaling Creating launch template via AWS CLI : https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/create-launch-template.html#create-launch-template-aws-cli  To see the file named 'Screen Shot 2021-03-24 at 12.34.06 PM.png' included with this correspondence, please use the case link given below the signature.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hi Team,  Thank you for your time on the call today, it was a pleasure working with you.  While on the call, you mentioned that you were having issues logging into your instance (i-04027804dc00cd444) when trying to use the local Administrator account with the password generated from the Key Pair.  To resolve this issue, we were able to modify the EC2Config settings manually and regenerate the password using the Key Pair. A recap of the steps are below:  1. Create/Use a recovery instance in the same availability zone as your affected instance. 2. Stop the instance and detach the root volume. 3. Attach the root volume of the affected instance to your recovery instance. 4. Open Disk management by running Start > Run > diskmgmt.msc. 5. Right click on the volume and bring the volume online. 6. Edit the config.xml located on offline volume in D:\Program Files\Amazon\Ec2ConfigService\Settings 7. Change Ec2SetPassword from Disabled to Enabled. Save and close the file. This value is set to Disabled after the next boot of the instance. 8. To avoid disk signature collision issue, you may have to run EC2Rescue tool from https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2rescue-windows-troubleshoot/ and simply run      through the wizard until you see the EC2Rescue exit window with an option to Fix disk signature. 9. Detach the offline root volume and attach it to your instance as /dev/sda1. 10. Start the instance and use Get Windows Password to decrypt the new default Administrator password.  It seemed at first this method failed, and even EC2Rescue[1] did not seem to enable this option. After doing it for a second time it seemed to take the setting, and finally we were able to log in.  I am glad we were able to resolve this issue. As per our call, I will go ahead and resolve this case.  In the meantime, if you have any further questions or concerns please don't hesitate to reach back out to us.  Have a great day!  Resources: [1] Use EC2Rescue for Windows Server GUI - Analyze an offline instance - https://docs.aws.am

comm_body: Hello Athira,  This is Divya again from AWS Support. Thank you for your response. I apologize for the delay in my response as I was thoroughly analysing all the logs and the reports that were sent previously.   To reiterate, you mentioned that you were unable to see the memory utilization reported for the instance i-006fb0e6eca439bd2 and it was not captured from 16:34 UTC to 1:49 UTC on 29th March 2021. As all other metrics were captured and only the memory utilization wasnt, I requested you to send the atop logs captured during that time frame.   Since the historical atop results and the log uploaded only consists the information about the CPU Utilization and not memory consumption, Im unable to further analyse the memory consumption during that time frame to debug further. Thats correct, I just installed atop on my test instance and replicated and for only live monitoring, we run the command $ atop -m which would launch the memory information.  I further analysed the complete /var/log/messages file and did not notice any Out of memory messages too that would depict that the system was under memory pressure.   As I mentioned in my responses previously, I can confirm that there were no AWS Infrastructure issues too during that time frame. Hence from my analyzation so far, I believe that the Instance was unresponsive during the time frame due to a resource glitch due to which the memory utilization metrics werent reported. However as the atop logs does not report the memory utilization then, I am still unable to confirm this.  Hence we would have to wait for the issue if it occurs again, to capture the atop -m live memory utilization and if the message logs reflect Out of memory messages to analyse further. Please feel free to let me know if you still have questions or require a callback to explain this further in detail with your contact number and a convenient time frame and Ill be glad to clarify further. comm_body: Hi again Prakash,  Thanks for your time earlier on chat. This is Jason with a recap of our conversation.  You got in touch as you could not see the GPU listed in Task Manager on your G4DN instance with the Tesla drivers installed.  The documentation contains the steps for installing the public Tesla drivers and some steps to take after installation:  Install NVIDIA drivers on Windows instances  - Option 2: Public NVIDIA drivers - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/install-nvidia-driver.html#public-nvidia-driver   After installing the NVIDIA drivers, it should be noted that if you are connecting to the instance with RDP (mstsc), the GPU will not be available through RDP.  In order to see the GPU, you need to connect with another remote desktop tool, such as TightVNC:  TightVNC download - http://tightvnc.com/download.php  This is also covered in the documentation here:  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/accelerated-computing-instances.html  "When using Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP), GPUs that use the WDDM driver model are replaced with a non-accelerated Remote Desktop display driver. We recommend that you use a different remote access tool to access your GPU, such as Teradici Cloud Access Software, NICE Desktop Cloud Visualization (DCV), or VNC. You can also use one of the GPU AMIs from the AWS Marketplace because they provide remote access tools that support 3D acceleration."   So please ensure you are not connecting with Microsoft RDP, as the GPU will not be available using this connection method.  It appeared that we disconnected on the chat earlier, but please review this and feel free to let me know if you need anything else.  Thanks again for getting in touch, and have a nice day. comm_body: Hello,  I have heard back from the internal team on this issue. There is no specific recommendation for timeouts from the team, as timeouts for a large number of snapshots is the expected behavior. However the internal team has recommended the following:  "suggested to use pagination in Boto3. ( Pagination is the the process of sending subsequent requests to continue where a previous request left off. ) Describing an excessive amount of EBS snapshots in an account should be done using pagination to avoid timeout here. See following example:  def getSnapshots(token = ""):          response=client.describe_snapshots(OwnerIds=['0123456789'],MaxResults=5,NextToken=token)     fileWrite(json.dumps(response, indent=4, sort_keys=True, default=str))      try:         NextToken = response['NextToken']         if(NextToken!=""):             getSnapshots(NextToken)     except:         return  There is no optimal timeout value, it is expected to see the timeout with so many EBS snapshots."  Please keep in mind that the above is only an example. As we discussed on the call this issue should be handled by the Veritas team, as there is no issue from the AWS end. Do feel free to reach out if you have any additional questions or concerns and I will be happy to assist.   We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Joshua K. comm_body: Hi Ashish  Michael here from AWS, thanks for reaching out today.  You were experiencing instance status check failures with your instance - i-0c0f01f63d0f1630e.  Checking the instance status check CloudWatch metric, I saw that there were failures between 2021-03-30 11:25 UTC - 12:35 UTC [1]. Instance status check failures are an indication that an issue at the OS level has resulted in your instance becoming unreachable [2]. Looking further into the metrics we noticed a spike in disk read/write activity on the root EBS volume - vol-01c2cb53397e7f1e4 [3] during the above time frame.  Using my internal tools to check further into the issue, I identified that the EBS volume faced issues around the same time that the instance failed instance status checks. When your OS processes/services faced issues writing to the root volume due to the issue facing the underlying EBS volume, they may have timed out and caused system instability and resulting in the instance status check failing. As I mentioned at the end of our chat, I've reached out to our internal EBS team to review the EBS volume - vol-01c2cb53397e7f1e4. I'll provide their feedback to you via this case as soon as I hear back from them. comm_body: Hi Arjun,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Taha. It was nice working with you. I am following up regarding our discussion earlier.  To summarize, you mentioned that you were unable to change the instance type of the instance i-007a06878ff1752c4. You were suspecting it might be related to a pending AMI creation of the instance.  I had a look at the instance. The instance was stopped. A pending AMI creation should not be preventing you from changing the instance type of a stopped instance. However, you mentioned that you had hibernation enabled for the instance. Please note that it is not possible to change the instance type of an instance with hibernation enabled. Please refer to this link [1] for reference. Furthermore, it is not possible to disable hibernation on an instance [2].  You will have to restore a new instance from your AMI with a larger size. The AMI has finished completion and is now available.  As discussed, I am going to mark this case as resolved. However, please feel free to reach out again in case of any other questions or concerns.  Have a good day!  ----- References ----- [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-instance-resize.html#resize-requirements [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Hibernate.html#enabling-hibernation  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hello Hemant,  Thank you for contacting AWS premium support. It was nice talking to you today. This is a summary of our session.  Instance i-0952ef1900da9fbc4 created from AMI ami-0822233427aa2f3e1 is unreachable.   Upon checking the instance console, I noticed that the OS is reaching emergency mode due to issues mounting /mnt filesystem  ... Dependency failed for /mnt. Dependency failed for Local File Systems. Dependency failed for File System Check on /dev/xvdb. Welcome to emergency mode! After logging in, type "journalctl -xb" to view system logs, "systemctl reboot" to reboot, "systemctl default" to try again to boot into default mode. sulogin: root account is locked, starting shell root@ip-10-0-15-94:~#  Image ami-0822233427aa2f3e1 was created from 3.2xlarge instance i-0f5a96c28d7b4a1ac (Express_SDB_Celery_SMS_Worker). We checked mentioned instance and we confirmed the invalid line on /etc/fstab:  /dev/xvdb   /mnt    auto    defaults,nofail,comment=cloudconfig 0   2  As I explained on the meeting, some instance types comes with ephemeral volumes which are disk attached to the host where your instance is running. Main difference with the EBS volumes is that the ephemeral volumes data persist only while the instance is running on the same hardware, if you stop/start the instance the data on ephemeral disk is lost.  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html  In order to fix this, we commented out the line on /etc/fstab:  #/dev/xvdb   /mnt    auto    defaults,nofail,comment=cloudconfig 0   2  Then you created new AMI ami-0e5a89144b60d9586 and launched m4.2xlarge i-08dd06410f710f0a4. You were successfully able to connect to this instance.  As we agreed over the chime meeting, I'm marking this case as resolved. If you have any question please let me know. Have a good day Hemant  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the s

comm_body: Hi Sachin and team,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support, it was really nice chatting and talking with you today and below the summary of our conversation. You contacted the support line as even though you had path based rule for your Application Load Balancer (ALB), some queries were failing after appending anything to v1.  Reviewing your ALB rqi1stop-qa-use1-alb, I found out that you had a path based rule to forward any traffics with /v1* to rqi1stop-qa-use1-tg-https and rqi1stop-qa-use1-cron-api-https, however it was only working for v1 alone and failing with 404 after adding any characters after v1.  I have explained that was the case because the server didnt know where to find the requested page and suggested having rewrite rules on the server side to send the queries to the right location which you did to solve this.  With your approval, I am placing this case in Pending Merchant Action in case you need further assistance with this, and we will be more than happy to assist.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Pitshou A. comm_body: Hi Amrit,  It was a pleasure chatting with you today. I just wanted to send a short follow up summarizing what we spoke about today on chat.  You opened the chat because you still not able to connect to address outlook.office365.com port 993 via your proxy/squid instance [ i-0495796bcddc30edb ], even after added port 993 to Squid Safe_ports configuration.  Before we proceed with the troubleshoot, I pointed out that troubleshooting 3rd party applications (like Squid) is considered system administration tasks, which is not covered under AWS Premium support scope [01].  Even though troubleshooting 3rd party application is out of AWS support scope, I was very happy to help in troubleshooting the issue, as best effort basis.  Moving forward, since you are connecting to IMAP on port 993, which utilizes SSL/TLS, you also had to allow port 993 in Squid SSL_ports configuration.  Additionally, after you add the configuration "acl SSL_ports port 993" to Squid "/etc/squid/squid.conf", I asked you to check and reconfigure squid in order to apply new config. For your reference I'm sharing the command:    # Display Squid configuration "squid.conf"   sudo grep -v ^# /etc/squid/squid.conf |grep .    # Check if there are any error in squid.conf ( useful to validate squid config before reload )   sudo squid -k check    # Reload Squid configuration ( It will apply the configuration without need to restart Squid service )   sudo squid -k reconfigure   Moreover, after reconfigure Squid, we checked Squid logs "/var/log/squid/access.log" while run curl command in the instance i-0a883e4fcb5cf895a, and we confirmed that curl was using proxy to successfully access outlook.office365.com on port 993.    # Watch Squid logs in order to confirm that outlook.office365.com port 993 is allowed (run this command in proxy instance)   sudo tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log |grep office365    # While command above is running, we tested connection in the instance i-0a883e4fcb5cf895a using curl command   curl -Ik https://outlook.office365.com:993   Las

comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Arti from Linux Support Team and I will be assisting you today.   From the case notes I understand that you would like to apply password while launching EC2 instances from the images(AMIs) which are created using lambda function. Please correct me if I have misunderstood your use case.  In order to assist you with your query I did some research and I found that you can use multi-factor authentication (MFA) to achieve your use case. That is you can enable multi-factor authentication [1] for the users and then you can configure MFA-protected API access for those users [2]. This will provide an additional security of requiring users to be authenticated with AWS multi-factor authentication (MFA) before you allow them to perform particularly sensitive actions (like launching, stopping or terminating instances).   Since in your use case you want to restrict EC2 launch instances access and as you might be aware that for launching EC2 instances RunInstances API operations is being called therefore you can create an IAM policy which will explicitly Deny RunInstnaces API operations if the user is not authenticated using multi-factor authentication (MFA). Further you can refer this document [3] which shows an example of an IAM policy providing MFA-protected API access.  I hope you have found above information helpful. In case of any additional queries or concerns please feel free to revert back and I will be happy to assist you further.  Thank You! Have a nice day ahead!   Reference: ======================== [1] Using multi-factor authentication (MFA) in AWS: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_mfa.html [2] Configuring MFA-protected API access: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_mfa_configure-api-require.html [3] Amazon EC2: Requires MFA (GetSessionToken) for specific EC2 operations: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/reference_policies_examples_ec2_require-mfa.html  We value your feed

comm_body: Hi Amrutha,  As discussed please update the PV (NIC) driver on this instance i-0a920eca5c445c9c0. As the current driver is from 2018.  1. Download the driver from: https://s3.amazonaws.com/ec2-windows-drivers-downloads/AWSPV/Latest/AWSPVDriver.zip 2. Extract the zip file and run AWSPVDriverSetup.msi as an admin 3. The instance should automatically restart, if not restart it manually 4. Log back into the instance and check device manger and see if the driver version has been updated to 8.4 and has year 2021  Once the driver has been updated attempt to connect to your on-prem ADFS server. If the problem persists then please start a new chat.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Sam A. comm_body: Hello Janardhan,   Kyler here from AWS Premium Support. Thank you for your time on Chat today.   You reached out because your instance i-0cd325021dfc8e4d6 was in a stopped state from yesterday, and you would like to know the root cause for this.  Upon chat I've checked the Cloudtrail logs, and found a 'StopInstances' call made to the above mentioned instance at 2021-04-08T13:57:23Z at Event ID (dbe932f8-2958-4c40-b2c4-1f8734172c94). Please see find the link to the Cloudtrail event below:   https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudtrail/home?region=ap-south-1#/events?StartTime=2021-04-06T07:15:57.392Z&EndTime=2021-04-09T07:15:57.392Z&EventName=StopInstances  After further review of the instance, I noticed that the CPU of the EC2 instance reached and stayed at 100% which can be seen from the Cloudwatch metrics below:  https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22CPUUtilization%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-0cd325021dfc8e4d6%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Maximum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-08T07%3A28%3A50.750Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-09T07%3A28%3A50.750Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22ap-south-1%22%7D  This indicates that something on the operating system was consuming more CPU capability than usual which can result in the EC2 instance to become unreachable. As we do not have visibility into your server's operating system, we're unable to determine the exact reason and increased CPU utilization. I suspect this could be why the instance would have been stopped, as usually a reboot or stop/start of the server can forcefully terminate processes consuming the CPU and help recover access. However, it's best to check with the user that initiated the stop from the console as to why the the instance was stopped.   As discussed on chat, I will be setting the case to resolved. If you need our assistance again, do not hesitate to reach out. We will be happy to help.  It was a pleasure working with you today

comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Himanshu and I will be assisting you with the case today.   From the case description, I understand that you are having timeout issues between the Source and Destination EC2 Instance. Please correct me if I misunderstood something.  Source: i-033cccf0d32bd5065  Destination: i-002b77beb31639e0f,  i-07585e58cd6b62ba1 and i-080fcf11c7f001b4d  After checking the AWS Account from the backend, I found that the source EC2 Instance "i-033cccf0d32bd5065" was terminated by the AutoScaling Group on 2021-04-09T15:06 in UTC.   I will not be able to examine the Network Configuration of that Instance as it is terminated. Could you please confirm if you are still encountering the issue with connectivity.   Make sure ICMP traffic is not blocked on the EC2 Instances   - Security Groups of Destination Instances must allow traffic from IP CIDR or IP Address of the Source Instance. - Ensure that the ICMP traffic is allowed in the Firewall and Antivirus (if any) - You could test by disabling firewall on the destination Instances by running the command in command prompt (run as Administrator): NetSh Advfirewall set allprofiles state off  If you are still encountering any issues please share the Instance ID or Security Group ID, NACL ID (Network Access Control List) for us to examine the rules.  Looking forward to hearing from you.  In the meanwhile, please feel free to write back to me if you have any further queries or if I can provide any additional assistance on this case, I will be happy to help.  Have a great day ahead!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Himanshu R. comm_body: Hello Ritesh,  Paul here again from AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure chatting to you earlier.   Below is a brief summary of our session.  You had encountered issues with your application whereby 4xx errors have been reported intermittently when trying to reach the instance metadata endpoint.   During my initial analysis I was able to see that the instance metadata endpoint was reachable from the EC2 instance 'i-0ff8274a74e161e6c' using the following 'curl' command:   $ curl -ILkv http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/  I also checked on the underlying host and could see that there were no health issues reported.  On further checking, we were also able to note that during the time of the issue (April 10 20:02 UTC +05:30), there were spikes in the network metrics on your EC2 instance. Kindly refer to the following CloudWatch metric graphs:   - Network In   https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22NetworkIn%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-0ff8274a74e161e6c%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Maximum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-09T12%3A11%3A39.467Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-11T12%3A11%3A39.467Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D   - Network Out   https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22NetworkOut%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-0ff8274a74e161e6c%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Maximum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-09T12%3A12%3A16.274Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-11T12%3A12%3A16.274Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D   - Network Packets In   https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22NetworkPacketsIn%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-0ff8274a74e161e6c%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Sum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-09T12%3A13%3A05.270Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-11T12%3A13%3A05.270Z%22%2C%22r

comm_body: Hello Mayur and team,   Brice here.   Thanks for chatting with me today. Here is a summary of the case and chat.   The initial issue was that the NVME devices were not reachable not only the swap device. We were able to see these errors through the console log, in the related case from this morning (8208958021), and during the call.   Eventually we decided to do a stop and start to move the instance to different hardware which is because it was not just one NVME device that was throwing an error but 3 or more. If it were one device it would make sense to investigate just that one EBS volume but since it was different devices I suspected that there was an issue with the underlying hardware. There was no way for me to know at the time if it was truly an underlying hardware problem but the start and stop is a way to test that. The results of the stop and start yielded no device errors and so it is likely the other host had hardware issues and I have let the other team I was working with know.   I did not forget that we had a swap partition issue but I did not count that among the errors above because we found that the device name had changed and that means the incorrect EBS volume was attempting to be mounted as a swap device. The fix for this was to identify the correct block device that mapped to the swap volume with blkid and then modify /etc/fstab to have the UUID of the file system instead of the block device name. The UUID will never change by itself so this is a good way to identify a specific file system the same can be said for file system Labels too.   If there are any questions or concerns at all please let us know.   We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Brice T. Amazon Web Services  =============================================================

comm_body: Hello Ashok,   Thank you for chatting in with AWS Premium Support. It was an absolute pleasure to be chatting with you today.   You reached out requesting assistance in order to upgrade Python Installation from version 2.7 to Python 3.0 on EC2 Instance ID "i-0d6b673f1046d8778".  During our chat session we confirmed the installed version  of 2.7.6 and I also quickly executed a test on my lab environment running the same Windows Server 2012 R2 as your source instance for the task, Instance ID "i-0d6b673f1046d8778".  As a best practice, prior to executing the change you created a Custom Windows AMI[1] of your instance. Meanwhile, I confirmed on my test environment that downloading the Python package for Python 3.0 from [2] allowed the installation to be executed over the current 2.7.6, however, it was required to execute a change on the Windows System Environment Variables[3], as presented below:  From: C:\Python27 To: C:\Python 30  After executing this change, the command "python -v" reported the newly installed version 3.0.  Please note, as identified during the Environment Variable changes, there were two additional variables on Python 2.7:  1 - C:\Python27\Scripts  2 - C:\Python27\google-cloud-sdk\bin\  If your Development Team needs to adjust both tools to Python 3.0, the required versions should be installed on C:\Python30\ folder and then change the environment variables on the same steps as before, with the values below:  From: C:\Python27\Scripts  To: C:\Python30\Scripts   From: C:\Python27\google-cloud-sdk\bin\  To: C:\Python30\google-cloud-sdk\bin\   As agreed over chat, as your request was achieved, I am marking this case as resolved.   Thank you again for reaching out to AWS Premium Support, it was great working with you. If you encounter any further queries or concerns, please let me know, I will be glad to help.  Have a great day ahead! Thank you!  References [1] Creating a Custom Windows AMI: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/Creating_EBSbacked_WinAMI.html [2] Python 3.0 Direct
