comm_body: Hi Ashok,  Francois here again,  Thank you for taking the time to chat with me today.  As per our discussion, you have been experiencing some issues when attempting to upgrade the nginx application on your instance.  As per our troubleshooting the error you had received is this:  ============== sudo add-apt-repository ppa:nginx/stable Cannot add PPA: 'ppa:~nginx/ubuntu/stable'. ERROR: '~nginx' user or team does not exist. ==============  I had investigated this on my end, by running the same command on a freshly created instance in my personal lab. The command succeeded on my end. I then found some discussions describing that a proxy might be the reason for the commands failing.  I then did some further research, in order to find a workaround for the issue, and found the nginx documentation here[1], for upgrading nginx on Ubuntu.  I applied the same steps listed in the mentioned documentation to my own instance, and I had been able to successfully upgrade my nginx application from version 1.10, to version 1.18.0. comm_body: Hello,  I have reviewed your instance i-05535da2dbcc6d0c4 and see that it started to fail instance health checks at 2021-04-20 15:22 UTC.  You can also view the StatusCheckFailed_Instance CloudWatch metric to confirm this: https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22StatusCheckFailed_Instance%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-05535da2dbcc6d0c4%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Average%22%2C%22period%22%3A60%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-19T15%3A56%3A23.201Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-20T15%3A56%3A23.201Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D  I observed that the CPU Utilization was stuck at 100%, starting at 14:45 UTC, which can indicate a process on the instance causing it to hang: https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22CPUUtilization%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-05535da2dbcc6d0c4%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Average%22%2C%22period%22%3A60%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-04-19T15%3A56%3A23.200Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-04-20T15%3A56%3A23.200Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D  I then reviewed the console output, which shows several kernel stack traces due to kworker.  I will attach those logs at the bottom of this correspondence for your reference.  I also checked the EBS volumes attached to the instance but did not observe any abnormalities or limits being reached.  In this case, I would recommend reviewing your log files to determine what could have caused your operating system to hang, along with what processes were running on the instance to determine the cause of this issue. comm_body: Hello Shammi,  Thank you for your reply. I have checked within my team and I have found that removing python3 from the instance will break the instance. Further, I would like to inform you that removing python3 package will remove the cloud-init  and several other packages dependent on python3.6 on your operating system. Cloud-init and netplan packages are actually responsible for bringing up the network on ec2-instance and since they have been removed as part of python3 removal, the instance has lost its automatic network loading capability due to missing packages.  On screenshare we have already tried checking the networking configuration and tried fixing the issue however the issue didn't get fixed as it removal of python3 package has broken the instance. Further I would suggest you to create a new instance and copy all your data to this new instnace.  I have also joined the same chime meeting now, so we can connect on call to discuss the same.  Thank You!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Arti R. comm_body: Good day,  Thank you for reaching out on chat today. Here is a recap of our conversation.  Issue: You received an alert that one of your instances has inbound security group rules allowing traffic from any source IP address to any port posing a security risk on your environment.  Steps Taken:  We removed the inbound rule on the VPC default security group allowing traffic to any destination port (0-65535). As discussed , your AWS account automatically has a default security group for the default VPC in each Region. If you don't specify a security group when you launch an instance, the instance is automatically associated with the default security group for the VPC [1]. This explains why the elasti-cache ENI has the VPC default security group.  I hope this was helpful. Have a pleasant day further.  References: [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/default-custom-security-groups.html#default-security-group  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hello,  I am Bhavini from AWS Premium Support. I hope this email finds you well!   It was a pleasure having a conversation with you today. This email is a summary of our conversation over chat and screenshare session.  You reached out to us as your instance 'i-063e8c98ade5c66a9' was failing 1/2 status checks.  As discussed on chat, I went ahead and investigated the aforementioned instance and following is what I observed:  1. Status Checks:  ------------------------  System Status Checks are caused due to issues on the hardware. I could see that there were no System Status check failure at the said timestamp,from this I can confirm that there was no issue on the underlying hardware of the System as the system status checks passed and you can also see it from your CloudWatch metrics   The instance status check started to fail at 2021-04-23T06:47:00 UTC for instance 'i-063e8c98ade5c66a9 ' . As you might be aware that Instance Status Checks monitor the software and network configuration of your individual instance. Amazon EC2 checks the health of the instance by sending an address resolution protocol (ARP) request to the ENI. These checks detect problems that require your involvement to repair. When an instance status check fails, typically you will need to address the problem yourself (for example, by rebooting the instance or by making instance configuration changes).  The following are examples of problems that can cause instance status checks to fail:  ===== Failed system status checks.  ------->> This was not the reason here.  Incorrect networking or startup configuration  Exhausted memory  Corrupted file system  Incompatible kernel =====  For more information regarding the Status Checks you can refer to the following AWS Public Documentations :   [+] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring-system-instance-status-check.html#types-of-instance-status-checks [+] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/TroubleshootingInstances.html  2. CPUUtilization : I checked that the CPU Util

comm_body: Hello,  I understand you will be performing in in-place upgrade from 2012 to 2019 on 4/24/21 @ 7AM IST (4 AM UTC). You would like to have someone from support on the call in case there are any issues.  In regards to pre-requisites, these are all listed in the documentation mentioned in the case already. It is highly recommended to take a backup AMI prior to starting for backup incase anything happens during the upgrade.  I would like to mention that we also have an automation for these types of upgrades [1] that will handle all of the necessary tasks to upgrade. Once this automation successfully finishes, your instance should be the upgraded OS. Be sure to login to it and ensure proper functionality with any applications installed as some older applications may need upgrading as well.   In regards to getting an engineer on the call, this timeframe would fall outside my normal working hours (I'm based in the CST time zone). Typically the quickest and easiest method to have an engineer join a call is to initiate a call via the case. I'd recommend opening the call via the case about 15-20 minutes prior to the scheduled meeting to ensure you get an engineer on the phone in time.   Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns. Have a great rest of the day.   References: [1] Perform an automated upgrade - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/automated-upgrades.html  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for reaching out to AWS.  I understand that you observed issue with network drop once again for the following time frame: UTC time frame: 12:35 to 12:40, 13:40 to 13:45  I reviewed the similar information from the EC2 like CPU utilization, network in, network out and status check failure and they seem fine.   At approximately at 13:40 UTC (19:10 IST), there was a transient 3% drop between ap-south-1a and ap-south-1b. However, I did not find any such drops for the  12:35 to 12:40 UTC time frame. All the TCP connections can handle transient packet drop with retransmission. Thus, we need more information about the nature of communication and drop being detected from your side.   In order to troubleshoot further, can you please provide the following information:  1. Where is the network graphs collected?  - I do not see specific mention of any instance id, unit like byte or packets to know what the graph actually refers to. Can you provide detailed description of the provided graphs?  2. How does the packets flow for the specific instance ids provided?  - What is the packet flow in your AWS architecture? Does the provided instances communicate with the same target machine? Are they expected to receive packets from up-stream?   3. Check up stream  - If the instances are configured as the targets of the load balancer, check with load balancer and up stream to see if there is any issue reported there. comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for your time on the chat.  Let me summarize what we discussed.  You had a GuardDuty finding "UnauthorizedAccess:EC2/TorRelay" for outbound access to IP address 217.155.40.118.  On the chat we checked on the running processes and current network connections to confirm if there was anything still connected to that IP and we did not find anything suspicious.  As discussed on the chat to review network connection there is need to log network traffic with tools like tcpdump on the instance at the OS level or VPC flow logs[1] at the network interface(ENI) level.  During the chat I confirmed that the domain pyro.eu.org has the IP address 217.155.40.118 and access to that domain, for example to a project like https://pyro.eu.org/projects/html2pdf, would trigger this finding as the IP address is also associated with the Tor network.  On the chat you confirmed that you will check with your team if there was any access to that domain or project.  If you confirm that there was access to this domain and you need to continue to access it, you can implement a suppression rule[2] based on the criteria - finding type "UnauthorizedAccess:EC2/TorRelay" and the remote IP address "217.155.40.118".   I trust this additional information is useful and please do reach out back on the case with your findings and we can continue with the investigation and troubleshooting if required.  Reference Links: [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/flow-logs.html [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/findings_suppression-rule.html  Thank you again for your time on the chat, stay safe and have a pleasant day further.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. comm_body: Hello Amrutha,  Vediyappan here from AWS premium support. It was my pleasure assisting you on this case today.  Please refer to the brief summary of our discussion.  You have contacted us that application running on the production instance "i-0f7b2e7735aa0387e" was affected when you try attempt to fix application level issue on the another instance "i-0812e232104f2f48f" today. You need to get assistance to narrow down this issue.  Firstly, I confirmed both the mentioned instances [i-0f7b2e7735aa0387e, i-0812e232104f2f48f] are running on the two separate Availability zone and the security group doesn't allow the connection between each other.   You had mentioned that instance "i-0812e232104f2f48f" was launched from backup image of instance " i-0f7b2e7735aa0387e", it was running for long. The instance "1-0812e232104f2f48f" gets stop/started automatically via the lambda function. When the instance started today morning, you found that some of the Application services were not started on this machine "i-0812e232104f2f48f". But, when try to resolve the issue by restarting the service, that seem caused the issue on the production server "i-0f7b2e7735aa0387e" application.   As we don't have any specific logs for the application side, we tried to review the system logs (/var/log/messages) and observed the application going to unresponsive state for some reason which correlated to the time you tried restart the service on backup instance.  Doing some research, we found that EFS file system was not mounted on the backup instance that could have caused the issue with backup instance "i-0812e232104f2f48f" application. And we were able to mount the filesystem manually now. However, we could not pinpoint the exact issue occurred on the production instance.   Since, we did not get the more reason for the issue, you will replicate the issue and see if the issue reproduces during non-business hours. If the issue replicates again, I request you to please reach us via the phone or chat support so that, we can live troubleshoot the

Connected to 3.226.169.2.  telnet 3.226.169.2 8181 Trying 3.226.169.2... Connected to 3.226.169.2.  ===========================  During that chat, you asked me if there were any security concerns. comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for coming on chat with me.  You came through requesting increasing the volume size of your EBS disk. comm_body: Greetings Prakash,  Thank you for contacting AWS support. My name is Vibhum and it was a pleasure chatting with you today. This is the summary of our chat.  I understand you were unable to access the instance and you were receiving the "Network error:connection timeout". Following are the reasons for the same [1]:  1. Firewall blocking the connection. 2. The SSH service is running on the instance. 3. The SSH tcp port 22 is in the listening state.  Checking the console logs, I see the ssh service has started as seen follows log:  --------------------------------------- [  OK  ] Started OpenSSH server daemon. ---------------------------------------  but I also see firewalld daemon running on the system which might have some rules that may be conflicting with the ssh access as seen below:  ----------------------------------------------------- [  OK  ] Started firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon. -----------------------------------------------------  Since AWS support engineers are not technically sound in third party OSes (such as Oracle) and since system administration tasks are out of scope (for reference please go through the link [2]); as a best effort guidance we followed the steps in the link [1] mentioned under the section "Method 4: Use a user data script". We tried disabling firewalld service but it was still running. Also, tried using ssm (as mentioned in method 2) but looks like the ssm agent version was not updated.   To move further, I suggested the following steps:  A]. If you have a similar instances running on the same configurations, then you can take an AMI of that instance and launch a new instance in that VPC/subnet. B]. If you just a need the data from the instance then you can launch a new instance and attach the volumes from this instance to the newly launch instance. C]. comm_body: Hello Sai,   Thanks for contacting AWS Premium Support.   First of all, I apologize on behalf of AWS for the delay in getting back to you, this is due to the influx of cases we had recently.  On reviewing the case, I understand that the instance i-0a1012613da387a5a has been detached from the auto scaling group (ASG) jp-envoy-webserver-asg-v2 at 2021-04-16T03:24:43 UTC (2021-04-16T08:54+5:30) in response to a user request, shrinking the capacity from 5 to 4.  However, it is found later that the instance was still attached to the load balancer ec-webserver-prod-apsouth1-elb after the ASG detach event. You would like to know why this instance was not attached to the ASG but registered with the load balancer.   Please let me know if I missed or misunderstood anything.   I reviewed CloudTrail event history [1] by filtering Resource Name as the ELB name "ec-webserver-prod-apsouth1-elb". Then I checked all the events whose name is "RegisterInstancesWithLoadBalancer" since the above ASG detach event at 2021-04-16T08:54+5:30. This is because RegisterInstancesWithLoadBalancer is the API used to register an EC2 instance to a load balancer [2,3].   For each event "RegisterInstancesWithLoadBalancer", I look at the section called "Request Parameters" which gives instance ID(s) to be registered under this API call [3].   I found after the instance was detached from the ASG at 2021-04-16T08:54+5:30, the instance was registered several times by a user named gaurav.ranjan. For example: --------------------------- At 2021-04-23T18:44:07.00 UTC, the user gaurav.ranjan registered the instance i-0a1012613da387a5a to the ELB ec-webserver-prod-apsouth1-elb; Event ID: b075f19e-75c8-4b14-b973-5ff88066555e   --------------------------- At 2021-04-23T19:10:33.00 UTC, the user gaurav.ranjan deregistered the instance from the ELB.  Event ID: 3711c4ca-ccac-4c6e-b14e-1b3f8f87f098    --------------------------- At 2021-04-23T19:11:48.00 UTC, the user gaurav.ranjan registered the instance to the ELB again.  Event ID: e6c52577-407b-4c34-aef5-ed70

comm_body: Hi Prathamesh,  It was a pleasure chatting with you today. I just wanted to send a short follow up summarizing what we spoke about today on chat.  You opened the chat because you launched a new instance from the community AMI "ami-0b3acf3edf2397475", which has the description below:      "SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 Service Pack 2 (HVM), EBS General Purpose (SSD) Volume Type. Amazon EC2 AMI Tools preinstalled; Apache 2.2, MySQL 5.5, PHP 5.3, and Ruby 1.8.7 available."   Hence, you are expecting to have "Apache 2.2, MySQL 5.5, PHP 5.3, and Ruby 1.8.7" package preinstalled. However, upon checking the description closely, it says that:      Amazon EC2 AMI Tools preinstalled;     Apache 2.2, MySQL 5.5, PHP 5.3, and Ruby 1.8.7 available.   Therefore, it means that Amazon EC2 AMI Tools are preinstalled, while those packages (Apache 2.2, MySQL 5.5, PHP 5.3, and Ruby 1.8.7) are available for installation.  Last but not least, I've launched a test instance based on the same AMI (ami-0b3acf3edf2397475) on my own account, and I confirmed that those package are not preinstalled, however they are available for installation.  Moreover, in order to install those packages you can use zypper command, as you can see in the example below:      sudo zypper install -y apache2 apache2-mod_php7 php7 php7-mysql mariadb ruby   Finally, if you want to have an AMI with those packages preinstalled, you can launch a new instance from this AMI (ami-0b3acf3edf2397475), then, run the zypper command above to install those package, and finally create a new AMI from launched instance. For more information regarding to create new AMI from your instance, please refer to the link below:    - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/creating-an-ami-ebs.html#how-to-create-ebs-ami   I hope you find the above information useful. As discussed, I'm going to mark this case as "Resolved". If you have any further questions or concerns regarding this issue, you can always reopen the case at any time via the Support Dashboard. Have a great day!

comm_body: Hello Elizabeth,  Thank you for your time over chat today. It was a pleasure talking to you.  You reached out to us as you were unable to ssh into the instance i-029330b72dff0065b after resizing it due to connection refused error.   I went ahead and inspected the console logs for the instance and I could see the below error:  [FAILED] Failed to mount /anon-ci_mountpoint1.  Such errors are usually seen due to automount failures because of incorrect or erroneous entries in /etc/fstab. More details regarding this can be found in below document: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-linux-emergency-mode/  So, you suspected that this issue could be due to changing the instance type and you tried changing it back to the original type c4.8xlarge and you were able to connect via telnet. However, for ssh you were receiving a different error related to key. So, the earlier connection refused error was no longer occurring. So, you mentioned that you will check with your team who works on this instance to check if they are able to connect and reach back in case of any issues.  I hope our session helpful. Please feel free to write back in case of any other queries or concerns and we will be happy to help, as always.  Have a nice day ahead!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi,  Kennedy from AWS support and I will be assisting you regarding a case where you are getting permissions denied when connecting to instance i-02c44bea58e33455c via SSH.  "Permission denied (publickey)" and "Authentication failed, permission denied" errors occur if[1]: - You're trying to connect using the wrong user name for your AMI. - The permissions are incorrect on the instance. - The incorrect SSH public key (.pub) file is in the authorized_keys file.  Resolution  1. Verify that you're using the correct user name for your AMI  I see that it is a Red hat instance. For a RHEL AMI, the user name is ec2-user or root by default[2]  2. Verify that the instance's permissions are correct and that the correct SSH public key is in the authorized_keys file  You can address this issue by using 2 options listed in the link [1]. That is: - Method 4: Use a user data script to repair SSH permissions and add the correct SSH public key to the authorized_keys file - Method 2. However for method 2, you will need to use SSH instead of SSM, Please find the details below: ----------------------- 1. Stop the current instance i-02c44bea58e33455c (assume Instance A)  2. Detach the root volume 'vol-0fa036de67a5d5d22 ' (sda1) from instance A.     a. Go to "Volumes" in navigation pane.     b. Select the relevant volume.     c. "Action" -> "Detach Volume".  3. Launch a temporary/recovery new instance ( assume instance B) (Amazon Linux2 will work) from AWS console in the same AZ as the target machine.   4. Attach root volume of Instance A to Instance B as secondary volume .     a. Select the volume detached in Step 2.     b. "Action" -> "Attach Volume".     c. Specify the Instance B and "/dev/sdf" as device and hit "Attach" button.  5. SSH into the to the temporary instance and Mount the secondary-volume using the following command:  run the command to see the device name:  lsblk   Mount the secondary volume. If the volume name is dev/xvdf1 you can mount it like this:  sudo mount /dev/xvdf1 /mnt  6a. Use the ls -ld command to make s

comm_body: Hello Sudipta,  Thank you for your time on call. It was my pleasure speaking with you today. Below you can find a short summary of our call for future reference.  You had contacted AWS Premium Support as your userdata script stopped working suddenly and aws CLI was not getting installed.  During the chat and call we discussed that you have an autoscaling group that spins up instances for you and the same usedata script that was use to spin up instance on April 30 is no longer work and AWS CLI is not getting installed.  During the call we reviewed the output of cloud-init log of the working and non working instances.   Working - i-08623fde573f8da98  Not working - i-0704ff3a1a4063c99  We could see that the pip on both the instance was version 10.0.x while the latest version was 20.x.x. We could also see errors in updating pip. Hence we manually update pip using the following commands.  # /bin/curl -O https://bootstrap.pypa.io/pip/2.7/get-pip.py  # python get-pip.py  Since the latest version of AWS CLI v1 was having issues in installation, we reviewed the version of AWS CLI on the working instance and installed the specific version of AWS CLI using the following command.  # pip install awscli==1.19.69 --upgrade  You were able to update the userdata script with the above commands which resolved all issues. As discussed, I was able to reproduce the same issue on my end hence I will be submitting feedback to our internal team on this.  Please let me know if you have any additional questions or need further clarification, I would be happy to help.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Ravsaheb,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure chatting with you. This is a summary of our conversation we had earlier today.  You reached out to us because you were unable to successfully mount a file system created on the EBS volume vol-054b9eef24f47d548 attached to your EC2 instance i-0cd24d5b57ee63d21. You needed to delete this volume but before deletion you wanted to confirm if any data resides in the volume or not, but the the mount command was failing to mount the filesystem on the volume.  We initiated a screen-share session to troubleshoot the issue.  Before proceeding, I advised that this activity is a system admin task and is out of scope of support [1], AWS is responsible for protecting the infrastructure that runs all of the services offered in the AWS Cloud, but customers are responsible for patching and configuration of their OS and applications. Please see the shared responsibility model for more details [2]. However, I was happy to help but the suggestions provided by us should be considered on a best-effort basis only.  We tried to mount the filesystem in read-only mode, also tried to perform a filesystem check, but all attempts failed.  [root@ilcvpgsql ~]# mount -o ro /dev/xvdj2 /test2 mount: mount /dev/xvdj2 on /test2 failed: Structure needs cleaning  [root@ilcvpgsql ~]# xfs_repair /dev/xvdj2 Phase 1 - find and verify superblock...         - reporting progress in intervals of 15 minutes Superblock has unknown compat/rocompat/incompat features (0x0/0x4/0x0). Using a more recent xfs_repair is recommended. Found unsupported filesystem features.  Exiting now.  Based on the error messages, I suggested updating the xfsprogs package on your instance (running RHEL7), which contains the xfs_repair tool. As that was not feasible at the moment, I suggested to try mounting the filesystem on another instance with a recent package that could support all XFS features, such as Amazon Linux 2. You had an AMI with RHEL8 at your disposal and launched a new instance from it.  Yo

comm_body: Greetings Utkarsh,  It was a pleasure chatting with you today. Below I will provide a summary for our conversation.  You contacted us because you file '2021-03-31_01-00_databackup_3_1' was deleted from your EC2 instance 'i-0afa4e63db1bf8743' and you would like us to help get information about same.  Via our screen sharing session, you shared with me you did not find relevant message for deleting the file in messages log files, that was around 14-05-2021. We checked command history for root user (hdpmaster) using below commands:            - set date format for history commands using below command:          export HISTTIMEFORMAT=%F %T"       - search for rm command in command history with below command:             history | grep rm            that showed rm command for file '2021-03-31_01-00_databackup_3_1', however tha was for couple of months ago.   We checked command history for ec2-user (default user), but we could see last modification time for ~ec2-user/.bash_history is old (last year) that make sense as you mentioned you do not use ec2-user for login to the instance.  Additionally, we checked if the file might be moved to another path using command `sudo find / -name '2021-03-31_01-00_databackup_3_1 2>/dev/null` but it return nothing. I checked instance details and I could not find EBS snapshots created for LVM volume mountpoint /backup.  As you know, per privacy and security concerns[1] AWS Premium Support Engineers have no visibility to running applications nor files exist inside EC2 instance for our customers, however I tried to help based on my best effort. I shared with you links[2,3] that could help with using xfs_undelete that tries to recover all files on an XFS filesystem marked as deleted. As best practise, I would recommend you to create instance AMI[4] or EBS snapshots[5] as a backup before install and work with xfs_undelete.  In order to tarck coming user activity, you can consider work with Auditd[6] service that collect and write log files of audit to the disk as a background service for

comm_body: Hello,  It was pleasure assisting you on call today.  To summarize our conversation, you reached out to us as ?hostname" command was giving the IP instead of the static hostname which was set inside the instance i-05ac93838148c4c25.  During troubleshooting the issue, we noticed that /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-eth0 file was modified inside your instance with an additional entry ?#DHCLIENT_SET_HOSTNAME='yes'?  # cat /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-eth0  BOOTPROTO='dhcp' MTU='9000' REMOTE_IPADDR='' STARTMODE='auto' CLOUD_NETCONFIG_MANAGE='yes' #DHCLIENT_SET_HOSTNAME='yes'  In order to fix the issue, I suggested you to comment the ?DHCLIENT_SET_HOSTNAME='yes?? inside the file /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-eth0 which you did in your one of the test instance and after that you performed the reboot and we noticed that ?hostname? command started giving the static hostname ?partnerapi? which was set.  Further, I confirmed you that ?DHCLIENT_SET_HOSTNAME='yes?? this actually reset the hostname during when system boot and it will set the hostname using the DHCP setting.  I checked your instance i-05ac93838148c4c25 which you have launched using a ?SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP3? based public AMI ?ami-00831fe0c42624267? and in order to configure a static hostname inside the ?SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP3? OS you can refer the below command:  # hostnamectl set-hostname new-hostname - replace new-hostname with your hostname  In case if you want the configured hostname to be resolved on loopback IP such as 127.0.0.1, then you can edit /etc/hosts file and find the localhost string and append the new hostname as you can see below. Again, replace?new-hostname with your hostname.  127.0.0.1 localhost new-hostname  We also noticed that, you started getting the static hostname when you were running the ?hostname? command in your test instance, However you were getting the multiple IPs when you were running ?hostname -i? command. We tested couple of scenario and concluded that you were getting the multiple IPs through your DN

comm_body: Hello Siddi, it was a pleasure talking with you today. Following the call session, I'm sending you the recap of our conversation.  You reached us because you observed DB fail-over due to network issue and would like to find out the root cause of the issue. Also From the latest correspondence, I see the instance system event logs is reporting the following records:  "The network interface "Amazon Elastic Network Adapter" has begun resetting.  There will be a momentary disruption in network connectivity while the hardware resets. Reason: The network driver detected that its hardware has stopped responding to commands. This network interface has reset 1 time(s) since it was last initialized."  "Amazon Elastic Network Adapter: Adapter reset has been started"  First of all, I do apologize for the inconvenience this must have caused to you.   ====> Troubleshooting analysis I carefully checked the DB instance ID's "i-080e0a0bbee9e76b3 and i-0f3978f645fb3ac66" which are deployed in "ap-southeast-2" as instance type "r5a.large" and Microsoft Windows Server 2019. Going one step further, I confirmed the instances are experiencing 2/2 health status checks passed, which means both underlying hardware [1, 2] and OS are reporting healthy status.  As we confirmed no issues happened in the underlying hardware, therefore I am suspecting something on the OS side caused the reset on network adapters, causing DB to fail-over. Please note that this can be caused due to several factors, such as:  - High network utilization.  - Primary SQL utilization, plus backup running.  - Antivirus  - Network drivers  Digging further, I checked the instance ID "i-080e0a0bbee9e76b3" which reported the DB fail-over issue recently experienced a high traffic in the network utilization [3, 4], whereas the instance ID "i-0f3978f645fb3ac66" which is working fine did not experienced network spikes [5, 6] . From the network graphs mentioned, we can see the instance which experienced network issues was operating fine and utilizing around 1,6 MBps of network

comm_body: Hi Shruti,  Thank you for your valuable time on call and screenshare today. Please find a brief summary of our discussion below:  You reached out to us as you wanted to replace current ext4 filesystem with LVM+XFS filesystem. We ran the below commands to do the same:  # fdisk /dev/xvdb  we deleted the three partitions present on this /dev/xvdb device by pressing d option. Then we re-created partitions with LVM type by pressing n and t options.  After recreating the partitions SSH service did not come as /var/empty directory was deleted. So, we created /var/empty directory temporarily on the root filesystem by running below commands:  mkdir /var/empty cd /var/empty mkdir sshd mkdir sshd/etc cd /var/empty/sshd/etc ln -s /etc/localtime localtime  We also added these commands to /etc/rc.local file. We also modified /etc/fstab file and commented entries for /tmp, /var, /var/log. Then we rebooted the instance so that kernel takes new partition table.  We then created physical volumes out of /dev/xvdb1, /dev/xvdb2 and /dev/xvdb3:  # pvcreate /dev/xvdb1 /dev/xvdb2 /dev/xvdb3 # vgcreate osVG /dev/xvdb1 /dev/xvdb2 /dev/xvdb3  ----->> created volume group # lvcreate --name tmp --size 2G osVG # lvcreate --name var --size 30G osVG # lvcreate --name var_log --size 3.98G osVG      # mkfs.xfs /dev/osVG/tmp  ------------------>>>>> created logical volume for /tmp # mkfs.xfs /dev/osVG/var # mkfs.xfs /dev/osVG/var_log # mount /dev/osVG/tmp /tmp # mount /dev/osVG/var /var  Then we copied data from the volume created from backup snapshot snap-046ab6c4a87508dfb to newly created  /dev/osVG/tmp and /dev/osVG/var by running: # cp -fR /<src_tmp/*> /tmp # cp -fR /<src_var/*> /var  Then we mounted /var/log as well and copied the data by running: # mount /dev/osVG/var_log /var/log # cp -fR /varlogtemp /var/log  We also modified the /etc/fstab file and mentioned UUIDs of new LVM+XFS filesystem there. We removed additional entries for /var/empty from /etc/rc.local as well.   After rebooting the instance, the instance came up and /tmp, /var, /

comm_body: Hi there!  This is Francisco again, and I would like to thank you for your time on the phone today. I am here to provide a recap of our conversation alongside my findings and next steps.  After reviewing the logs for instance i-0ef724ab7fc1b2e69, I have found that the instance have had a series of ENA reset events 5007 which is caused when the OS doesn't receive a keep alive signal from the ENA in time.  This may happen in different workloads, but we have observed SQL clustering workloads are more prone to present this behavior. This way, I would like to propose the following action plan:  === INVESTIGATION ===  In the OS logs, I have verified the following:  i-0ef724ab7fc1b2e69 -  ENA Driver version: 2.2.2  Event logs show (and not limited to the entries below) evidence indicating the OS sent a ENA reset, which in servers may interpret as malfunction.  For the Windows Error Reporting I couldn't find any additional issues.  === NEXT STEPS ===   1. Update the ENA driver on instance - As we discussed, this is a very important step as version 2.2.3 fixes an issue with false-positive HW unresponsiveness:   {+} https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/enhanced-networking-ena.html#ena-adapter-driver-versions     2. Set the ENA to increase the Receive buffers, and also to prevent RSS from running on CPU 0 - We have identified that instances can present this behavior depending on the workload, causing the OS to log ENA resets and ena events 5205, and 5007.     Due to that, we recommend setting the ENA as we described in our documentation, which you can do in a maintenance window for your server:   {+} https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/aws-sql-clustering.html#sql-clustering-ena  Please verify the information above, and apply the recommendation above, which is intended to solve the issue you are experiencing with the instance.  I hope this information helps, and as always, if you have questions, or if there is anything else you would like to add, feel free to reply through this case at a

comm_body: Hello Rahul and Abhilash,  Vediyappan here from AWS Premium support. It's my pleasure assisting you on this case today.  Please refer to the brief summary of our discussion.  You have contacted us that, after performing the package upgrade via the yum command, the instance not booting normal and failing the instance status check, there were around 8 machines had same issue which are launched from same base AMI.  To begin with, we have checked the console logs for the instance and noticed that instance entered into the emergency mode and reported failed to find the root and swap device. So, we have attached the volume to recovery instance and reverted the kernel to previous working kernel and booted the instance, however, the instance was failing with same error.  - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/revert-stable-kernel-ec2-reboot/  Since the instance [i-071dee28150a78d15] was new and no application configured, you have replaced the root volume from working instance and we had performed the yum update again. Then, we confirmed the new initramfs (initramfs-4.18.0-305.el8.x86_64.img) was created and included the nvme and ena drivers. But, checking the yum update logs, we found the below error.  *********************  Line is not an assignment at '/etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf:11': (null) warning: %triggerin(systemd-239-45.el8.x86_64) scriptlet failed, exit status 1  Error in <unknown> scriptlet in rpm package systemd *********************  You had mentioned some custom configuration on the file /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf, so we went ahead and removed those additional entries.  Then, checked /etc/default/grub file entries and noticed there were some additional GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX entries which referring to the swap and root device. So, we have reverted the entries by comparing with working instance launched from public AMI.  # cat /etc/default/grub GRUB_TIMEOUT=1 GRUB_DISTRIBUTOR="$(sed 's, release .*$,,g' /etc/system-release)" GRUB_DEFAULT=saved GRUB_DISABLE_SUBMENU=true GRUB_TERMINAL_OUTPUT="c

comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for your time on chat earlier. It was a pleasure speaking with you.  You wished ot understand whether it was possible to run IIS on a Linux EC2 instance. Unfortunately, this is not possible: IIS is only supported on the Windows operating system.  Depending on your use case, there are alternatives available. As discussed on our call, Apache is not suitable. However, if your needs involve running .NET applications, then it is possible to run .NET core applications on Linux, for example with nginx, as described in Microsoft's article below:  ## Host ASP.NET Core on Linux with Nginx [+] https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/linux-nginx?view=aspnetcore-5.0  Alternatively, if your needs involve running a reverse proxy as you mentioned may be the case, then nginx is more than capable of doing that.  I hope this helps to resolve the issue, but if you have any additional questions, please feel free to update the case and I will be happy to help.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Joe D. comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for your patience.  I'm sorry about the inconvenience of your sudden instance outage. Taking a look at the underlying hardware, I notice that there was a hardware inadvertent failure at 2021-05-23 18:05 UTC, causing the stopping of your instance at 2021-05-23 18:06:06 UTC (2021-05-23 23:36 IST), which is around the time you provided.  As you know, hardware equipment will never enjoy 100% up time, and from time to time there are system failures. We make every commercially available effort to make sure Amazon Web Services is secure and resilient, giving you reliability and massive scale. However, hardware and network failures will inevitably occur in any environment.  To avoid prolonged downtime for an instance in future in case of a underlying host issue, I would highly recommend setting up Auto Recovery for your instances, which allows AWS to automatically perform a stop/start when an underlying hardware failure occurs. You can find more information in our documentation at [1] and [2], and the steps on how this can be achieved.  On behalf of AWS, again I sincerely apologize for the inconvenience this issue has caused you. I hope the above information is useful for you.  Should you have any additional questions or concerns, please feel free to reach back to us and we will be happy to assist you.  ~References:~ [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-instance-recover.html : Recover your instance [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/UsingAlarmActions.html#AddingRecoverActions : Create alarms that stop, terminate, reboot, or recover an instance  - Add recover actions to Amazon CloudWatch alarms  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Jacobo R. comm_body: Hello Paytm Team,  Good Day!  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Rakesh and I am happy to assist you with this case today.  From the case description, I understand that, You would like to know if you can allow outbound traffic from security group attached to EC2 instance to specific FQDN's. Please let me know if I have misinterpreted.  A security group acts as a virtual firewall for your instance to control inbound and outbound traffic. On EC2 instances, Security groups are attached to the Elastic Network interfaces(ENIs).  The source/destination in case of Security group inbound/outbound rule respectively can be either of the below > security group,  > an IPv4 or IPv6 CIDR block,  > a single IPv4 or IPv6 address, or a  > prefix list ID.   It does not accept FQDN. Please refer [1] for the public document statement of the same.  We completely understand your requirement, but we regret that the feature is currently not available. I would certainly consider this scenario and raise a feature request internally, but I will be not be able to provide an ETA for the same. Please be assured that out internal team continuously works on making the user experience better and this is only possible by the feedbacks provided by our customer.  However, in a case if you would want to use a FQDN filtering service, we recommend using a 3rd party solution to achieve this for now[2].  References:  [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_SecurityGroups.html  [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/wellarchitected/latest/financial-services-industry-lens/use-fully-qualified-domain-name-fqdn-ingress-and-egress-filters.html  We look forward to hearing back from you soon. I hope the shared information was useful, In case you have any other concerns, please always feel free to reach out to us and we would be more than happy to assist you. comm_body: Hello Prathamesh and Santosh ,   Thank you for your time on call and chat today . Please find below a brief summary of same:  Ask: ========= Need to understand if sysprep can pull software licenses off OS .   Discussion on call and chat: ===========================  1. I explained to you that Sysprep removes PC-specific information from the Windows image, including the PC?s security identifier (SID). This allows you to capture the image and apply it to other PCs. This is known as generalizing the PC.The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from a Windows installation so that you can reuse that image on different computers. It also uninstalls PC-specific drivers from the Windows image. 2. The Sysprep tool runs only if the PC is a member of a workgroup, not a domain. If the PC is joined to a domain, Sysprep removes the PC from the domain.  3.   I have never heard off sysprep taking off license from software but it essentially depends on how license binds itself to OS or hardware . It can only be known to developer of applications as to how they have coded license to attach .   4. You explained to me that you want to have a golden image that can be redeployed on multiple instances with software installed and domain joined as they deploy . I explained to you that best way to achieve that is to use the answer file with sysprep or use DISM command to inject software to image.   There are many ways to customize an image before deployment , its automation is the tricky part . Every environment has its own requirements and hence custom tailored solutions.  For example , a lot of customers use SCCM /MDT to create a customized golden image that can be run with sysprep +answer file while deployment .    Links I referred during our discussion : ======================================== https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/sysprep-create-install-ec2-windows-amis/  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vm-import/latest/userguide/vmimport-image-import.html  https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardw

comm_body: Hi Anitha,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Ghulam. It was a pleasure chatting with you. I am sharing a brief summary of our discussion on the chat.  You reached out to us because you were having issues while accessing the instance using SSM session manager.   During the chat we discussed that in order for the instance to be accessible using the session manager, below conditions should be met. [1]   1- SSM agent should be installed. 2- IAM role attached to the instance should allow SSM access. 3- Instance should be able to connect to the SSM endpoint over port 443.  I checked and found that all conditions were being satisfied. The IAM role attached to the instance did have the required permissions. While on the chat, you confirmed that issue has been resolved after waiting for few minutes.   Since the issue was resolved and as agreed over the chat, I will be marking this case as resolved. comm_body: Hello Praful,   Thank you for your time on call and it was pleasure talking to you.  Here is the summary of the discussion that we had:   - You were unable to connect to the EC2 instance "i-04b79b1950011a0a2" and the SSH connection was failing with below error:  ~~~~~~~~  No supported authentication methods available (server sent: publickey)  ~~~~~~~~  - But still, you were able to access the instance via systems manager, hence we have logged into the instance via systems manager and performed below activities:   * Checked for the keypair availability.   * Set all the "ssh" related file permissions properly by executing below set of commands:     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~     # chown root:root /home     # chmod 755 /home     # chown ec2-user:ec2-user /home/ec2-user -R     # chmod 700 /home/ec2-user /home/ec2-user/.ssh     # chmod 600 /home/ec2-user/.ssh/authorized_keys     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~   * Now, tried to perform the ssh again, but the issue was still present.   - Then, upon checking internally with the team, we got to know that you are logging into the instance via "username" and "password" and not using SSH keypair.   - Hence, we have further checked through the ssh configuration file "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" and we could see the "Password Authentication" was set to "no", so just to login using the password, we have changed the setting to "yes" and restarted the "sshd" service.  - Now, after trying to "SSH" again you are facing the error "Access Denied" and we suspect the password that you are entering might be incorrect.  - Just to confirm this, we have created a test user with "test" password and tried logging in and confirmed that the login was success.  - So just to resolve the problem, we have reset the password for "ec2-user" with the required password and tried logging in again and confirmed that everything is working as expected.  As concluded, just to understand who made these changes, kindly check with the in-house system administrator as we AWS Support Engineers do not have any access or visibility to customer's

comm_body: Hello Rahul,  Vediyappan here from AWS Premium support. It was my absolute pleasure assisting you on this case today.  Please refer to the brief summary of our discussion.  You have contacted us that, as you observed the scheduled event for the instance ID "i-0b525f5106eebb334" and need to get more clarity on the events.  Using the internal tools and I confirmed that instance was scheduled for the retirement due to underlying host degradation and it was advised you to stop/start the instance before the retirement date  2021-06-17 12:00:00 UTC, so that, the instance will be migrated to new healthy host. Further, I recommended you to perform the stop/start of the instance immediately as possible as your instance was running on the degraded host and underlying host may go unresponsive before the scheduled maintenance.  Below is the "EC2 persistent instance retirement scheduled" event details.  EC2 has detected degradation of the underlying hardware hosting your Amazon EC2 instance associated with this event in the us-east-1 region. Due to this degradation your instance could already be unreachable. We will stop your instance after 2021-06-17 12:00:00 UTC. Please take appropriate action before this time.  You can find more information about retirement events scheduled for your EC2 instances in the AWS Management Console https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/v2/home?region=us-east-1#Events  For more information about stopping and starting your instance, and what to expect when your instance is stopped, such as the effect on public, private and Elastic IP addresses associated with your instance, see Stop and Start Your Instance in the EC2 User Guide (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/en_us/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Stop_Start.html).   Moving further, you had some query about the AMI copy charges from one region to another. I mentioned that, there are no charges for copying an AMI. comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure to chat with you today, below is a recap of our conversation.  You reached out to AWS Premium Support as you could not SSH into your instance and you observed an increase in CPUUtilization and IOPS.  I checked instance from my side and I could see spike on the CPUUtilization[1] as well as root volume hitting throughput limit of 128Mb/s. You root volume size is 50Gib which means it has a throughput limit of 128 MiB/s[2].   Further, you were pushing IOPS[3] above the baseline provided by your root volume. Baseline for your root volume is 150 IOPS and you were pushing above 600 IOPS, causing burst balance[4] to drop. The same pattern I can see on 3rd and 4th of June.  As mentioned on the chat, further investigation is required from OS level to find out which process is causing the high CPU and pushing the IOPS to the EBS volume. You mentioned that you have monitoring tools installed on the instance and the issue seems to be with wordpress and you are checking further on the application side.  You already upgraded instance type from c5 to r5a which provides more memory. If you would like to get a higher IOPS baseline, you can also increase your EBS volume. You can see all volumes types and their characteristics from [5].  I checked further, for any issues with underlying hardware and EBS volume and there is no issue.  I have also checked CPUUtilization for the last month and I could see there are spikes reaching around 85%, however, regarding the IOPS, it started increase from 1th of June.  I hope you will find this information useful at your end, please do let me know if you have any further queries or concerns. I will be more than happy to assist.   Have a good day ahead!  ~ References/Further reading ~ [1] https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=~(metrics~(~(~'AWS*2fEC2~'CPUUtilization~'InstanceId~'i-083d74abc54657bcd))~stat~'Maximum~period~300~start~'2021-05-01T14*3a03*3a44.240Z~end~'2021-0

comm_body: Dear Amazon Web Services Customer,  Thank you for contacting Amazon Premium Support. My name is Nikitha and I will be assisting you on this case today.  From your case correspondence, I understand that you are not able to connect to your Web Server from Bastion Server.  It seems that our chat got disconnected abruptly. With that being said, for me to troubleshoot the issue further, could you please provide the following information:   1. The instance ID of the Web server and the Bastion server in question.  2. What is the error message received, when trying to connect to the web server?  3. Are you able to telnet to the webserver instance from bastion over port 22.                     # telnet <webserevr IP> 22   4. Could you please confirm if there was any changes done with respect to OS configuration or SSH configuration before you started to face this issue.   Alternatively, kindly provide a phone number (with country code) so that I can call you and we can troubleshoot the issue further.  Awaiting your response. Meanwhile, if you have any other questions or concerns please let me know and I would be happy to assist you further.  Thank you. Have a great day further!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello  Thank you for providing the logs. This is Anusha again from the AWS Premium Support.  I have analyzed the logs and would like to provide my findings below: ====================================  Application logs: =============== The description for Event ID 3011 from source Microsoft-Windows-LoadPerf cannot be found. Either the component that raises this event is not installed on your local computer or the installation is corrupted. You can install or repair the component on the local computer. If the event originated on another computer, the display information had to be saved with the event. The following information was included with the event:  WmiApRpl WmiApRpl 8  System logs: ============ Volume L: (\Device\HarddiskVolume163) needs to be taken offline to perform a Full Chkdsk.  Please run "CHKDSK /F" locally via the command line, or run "REPAIR-VOLUME <drive:>" locally or remotely via PowerShell. A corruption was discovered in the file system structure on volume L:. The exact nature of the corruption is unknown.  The file system structures need to be scanned online. Status 0x00001069 determining that device interface \\?\PCI#VEN_1D0F&DEV_8061&SUBSYS_80611D0F&REV_00#3&13c0b0c5&0&9  I noticed memory dumps were created which means the server was experiencing random reboots.  Memory Dump: ============ BUGCHECK_CODE:  d1 BUGCHECK_P1: ffffd0002a20501d BUGCHECK_P2: 2 BUGCHECK_P3: 0 BUGCHECK_P4: fffff800caefe5d1 READ_ADDRESS:  ffffd0002a20501d  PROCESS_NAME:  System  An attempt was made to access a pageable (or completely invalid) address at aninterrupt request level (IRQL) that is too high.  This is usually caused by drivers using improper addresses.  SYMBOL_NAME:  AWSNVMe+105d1 MODULE_NAME: AWSNVMe IMAGE_NAME:  AWSNVMe.sys STACK_COMMAND:  .thread ; .cxr ; kb BUCKET_ID_FUNC_OFFSET:  105d1 FAILURE_BUCKET_ID:  AV_AWSNVMe!unknown_function OS_VERSION:  8.1.9600.19880 BUILDLAB_STR:  winblue_ltsb OSPLATFORM_TYPE:  x64 OSNAME:  Windows 8.1  System log: ========= 2021/05/31 13:45:58Z: Driver: AWS NVMe Driver v1.3.0

comm_body: Hello Himanshu and Ankit,  Tahriqh here again, thanks again for your time earlier it was nice speaking with you.  You needed some assistance with details on the RCA of why a number of your instances were rebooted.  During our call, I've informed you that this was due to a maintenance window (mw-0b3f3f7816280c48a) configured to run on a weekly basis as per the following cron expression, set when it was created on 2021-01-13 at 20:10:00 UTC:  cron(30 16 ? * FRI *)  The maintenance window has been set to run the AWS-RunPatchBaseline task on a number of instances in it's target group. This is why the instances were rebooted and we navigated to the maintenance window and task details during our call where these details can be seen.  We also briefly discussed CloudTrail logs. By default, CloudTrail provides data events of up to 90 days. For details further than that, you will have to make use of custom CloudTrails that you configure within the service. More information on this can be found here [1].  As requested, I have left this case open but you are welcome to close it if there is no further assistance required.  Alternatively, I will gladly assist if you have any further questions.  ========= References:  [1] Creating a trail for your AWS account: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/awscloudtrail/latest/userguide/cloudtrail-create-and-update-a-trail.html  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Tahriqh A. comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for your valuable time on chat and screenshare session today. Please find a brief summary of our discussion  below:  You reached out to us as you are unable to launch instances using IAM role: tis-l3-role and are getting Unauthorized error. I informed you that to troubleshoot the issue we need to decode the error message and for that we need aws-cli: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/sts/decode-authorization-message.html and https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/aws-backup-encoded-authorization-failure/ .   I also informed you that SCP is enabled for your organization which may be causing the issue. Hence, I requested you to login to your account: 307455894664 using your IAM user and disable the SCP. You were facing some issue while logging in using IAM users and mentioned that you will check this with your team.  I also created a test IAM user in my test account with exact same IAM policies as  tis-l3-role and was able to launch an instance in my account successfully. Hence, I suspect that the issue can be with SCP only. Please try to launch an instance after disabling SCP one and please feel free to re-initiate if you continue to face the issue: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_enable-disable.html  I hope the above information helps. In case you have ay follow-up query then please let us know and we will happily assist you.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Raksha C. comm_body: Hello Rishabh,  Thank you for the logs. In the logs I noticed multiple occurrences of following messages  Jun 16 21:07:39 bastionbastionserver-infra-v1-580 cloud-init: 2021-06-16 15:37:39,630 - DataSourceEc2.py[WARNING]: Calling 'http://169.254.169.254/latest/api/token' failed [0/1s]: bad status code [403] Jun 16 21:07:40 bastionbastionserver-infra-v1-580 cloud-init: 2021-06-16 15:37:40,644 - DataSourceEc2.py[WARNING]: Unable to get API token: None/latest/api/token raised exception ('Connection aborted.', gaierror(-2, 'Name or service not known'))  As per [1], for requests made using Instance Metadata Service Version 2, the  HTTP error code 403 which means "Forbidden  The request is not allowed or the instance metadata service is turned off." - Can you please execute following CLI command on instance and see if instance can curl metadata using IMDSv2:  TOKEN=`curl -X PUT "http://169.254.169.254/latest/api/token" -H "X-aws-ec2-metadata-token-ttl-seconds: 21600"` \ && curl -H "X-aws-ec2-metadata-token: $TOKEN" -v http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/   - If it is not successful, first check if the http-endpoint is enabled for metadata using AWS CLI: aws ec2 describe-instances --instance-ids  i-08472656b8dc716e0 --query Reservations[0].Instances[0].MetadataOptions  - If its disabled, can you run following command:  aws ec2 modify-instance-metadata-options \     --instance-id  i-08472656b8dc716e0  \     --http-tokens optional \     --http-endpoint enabled  - and again try running following command:  TOKEN=`curl -X PUT "http://169.254.169.254/latest/api/token" -H "X-aws-ec2-metadata-token-ttl-seconds: 21600"` \ && curl -H "X-aws-ec2-metadata-token: $TOKEN" -v http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/   If this returns successful operation, retry changing instance type and see if the same error messages appear again.  If the issue still persists, please provide results of above operation and: - can you please confirm if there are any IPTables, firewalls configured on your instance that restrict access to the metada

comm_body: Greetings Santosh,  This is Mohammad again and it was a pleasure chatting with you today!  To summarize the conversation, you reached out today for assistance with instance i-03f4a1bdd1dc3c945 as instance reachability status checks were failing.  Looking at the EC2 instance underlying hardware I can confirm that the underlying hardware reported as healthy. [1]  Instance status checks monitor the software and network configuration of your individual instance. Amazon EC2 checks the health of the instance by sending an address resolution protocol (ARP) request to the network interface (NIC). These checks detect problems that require customer involvement to repair. [2]  To note, our Scope of Support [3] and our Shared Responsibility Model [4] documents outline - troubleshooting issues at the OS layer is out of scope for AWS Premium Support, and any troubleshooting provided would be on a best-effort approach.  The following are examples of problems that can cause instance status checks to fail:     - Failed system status checks     - Incorrect networking or startup configuration     - Exhausted memory     - Corrupted file system     - Incompatible kernel  AWS values the security and privacy of our customers. Because of this, our visibility of OS level resources is very limited, therefore I offered a screen-share session to assist you in investigating the OS level of the EC2 instance.  While beginning the investigation over screen-share, we noticed that another user on your team (surabhi.yadav@ext.icicilombard.com) stopped the instance and detached the root volume and you decided to hold off on any action until you could verify with that user. After checking with this user, you mentioned that they were able to get the instance started back up with passing instance status checks.  As requested, I have provided the reference documentation for viewing CloudTrail events in the console. [2] We filtered the event history by Resource name = i-03f4a1bdd1dc3c945 and were able to see actions performed by other users on i-03f4a1

comm_body: Hi Suhas,  Thank you for reaching back to AWS Premium Support! My name is Daniel and I will be assisting you today. From reading over your case, I understand that as per VAPT, when TLS 1.0 that needs to be disabled and TSL 2.0 enabled, RDP to i-01b6d29c227798991 fails and you would like guidance on ensuring required VAPT precautions are taken into account.  To set expectations straight, please note that this request is to be performed at OS level is part of System Administration tasks which AWS Support does not provide support, I will however attempt to assist as a best effort basis [1]. When specific security layer for remote (RDP) connections is enabled and SSL security layer is used, the SSL method required for use is TLS 1.0 to authenticate to the RD Session host. If TLS is not supported, the connection fails [2]. While attempting to disable TSL 1.0 and enabling TLS 2.0, you can verify and attempt changing the security layer value to 0 as described below [3]: 1. Run Regedit as an Administrator. 2. Navigate to here: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\WinStations\RDP-Tcp 3. Review the value for 'SecurityLayer.' If the value is '2', then the server may be requiring TLS for RDP authentication, but failing to do so, as TLS has been disabled. 4. Try and change the value to 0 and attempt connecting to the instance while TLS 2.0 is enabled and TLS 1.0 is disabled.  Please note the shared url are not AWS public documentation, review and make appropriate changes based on your company and security policies.  I hope this information helps, however please feel free to reach back for any additional assistance we offer, or if you have any questions about the above information.  References ~~~~~~~~~~ [1] https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/faqs/ [2] Local Computer Policy > Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Remote Desktop Services > Remote Desktop Session Hosts > Security     "Require use of Specific security layer for remote (RDP) connections" [3] htt

comm_body: Hello Akshay,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Duane and I will be working with you on this case.  I understand you would like us to open SMTP port 25 on the instance i-00f293cbda61abc2e.  I had a look on the backend and can confirm port 25 is not being throttled for this instance or for any of your instances in the ap-south-1 Mumbai region.  You could use the netstat command to find all active and listening ports as long as there is a service listening on those ports, below is the netstat command in cmd:  netstat -ano  If you have port 25 configured on your security groups and firewall and there is a service listening on the port you could run the below PowerShell command as well:  tnc 172.27.70.231 -p 25  I hope you find the above information helpful, if you do have any further questions could you please clarify your issue in more detail, if the above answers your question you may resolve the case at your leisure.  Wishing you a great and safe day further!  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Duane O. comm_body: Hi Prathamesh,   It's Mawande here from AWS Support, Thank you for contacting us today.   You wanted to know how you can get mirror credentials for the SUSE Linux for your instance(s).  On your instance, we've confirmed that the "billingProducts" value is "bp-6ca54005", meaning your instance has the necessary entitlements.  "accountId" : "7920XXXX3430", "architecture" : "x86_64", "availabilityZone" : "ap-south-1a", "billingProducts" : [ "bp-6ca54005" ], "devpayProductCodes" : null, "marketplaceProductCodes" : null, "imageId" : "ami-0b3acf3edf2397475", "instanceId" : "i-0af56ebdb3f966626", "instanceType" : "t3.small", "kernelId" : null, "pendingTime" : "2021-05-07T13:25:09Z", "privateIp" : "172.22.168.147", "ramdiskId" : null, "region" : "ap-south-1", "version" : "2017-09-30"  We've also determine if the instance is connected to the Public Cloud Update Infrastructure by running "zypper lr --uri". The URI column is suppose to list either "https://smt-ec2_susecloud_net" or credentials "plugin:/susecloud?credentials=SU". In your case these were missing, as it only showed the following URIs:  https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/Apache/openSUSE_Leap_15.2/ https://download.opensuse.org/repositories/editors/openSUSE_Tumbleweed/ http://download.opensuse.org/update/leap/15.2/oss/ http://download.opensuse.org/repositories/devel:/languages:/php/openSUSE_Leap_15.2/  As a next step for you, I would like to share some additional guidelines which you need to perform for instances that already have the "billingProducts" code.   Firstly, just to give some background on this. On June 1st 2020, SUSE made an improvement to the regional Public Cloud Update repository servers, where they got rid of old IP address-based access restrictions and moving to an Instance "billingProducts" code based restrictions. SUSE has implemented this change for all the Cloud Providers, that means AWS customers are also affected by this change, which may prevent them from accessing SUSE's repositories. As we have seen in your case earlier, you wer

comm_body: Hello,  Greetings of the day. Hope this email finds you well. I am John from AWS Premium Support and I will be assisting you today.  From the case details, I understand that your instance i-0673eeca2555335a7 has failed the system status checks and the instance status checks and you would like to know the reason for the same. Please feel free to correct me if I am mistaken.   I have reviewed your instance and I can see that the instance started failing the system status checks at 2021-06-20 18:10 UTC. Using my internal tools I can see that the underlying host on which the instance was present experienced an unexpected hardware failure which system health checks[1] also showing a failure. The underlying host has been isolated using our internal automation tools and removed from production. I can see that you have stopped the instance on 2021-06-20 18:52 UTC and started the instance at 2021-06-20 18:56 UTC. The instance was migrated to a healthy hardware during this stop-start and thus there is no further action required at your end.  Kindly accept my sincere apologies on behalf of AWS for inconvenience caused to your business due to the hardware failure. I want to assure you that we make every commercially available effort to make sure Amazon Web Services is secure and resilient to provide you high reliability and massive scale. There are some best practices that are suggested to avoid/minimize downtime due to a hardware failure. I would like to take this opportunity to inform you about them.  Perhaps you may have come across them before, but I would like to share them just in case you want to review best practices and reference architecture design whitepapers that discuss the aforementioned topics, It will help increase fault tolerance and high availability for your application to ensure resiliency over issues similar to this..   - Auto Recovery for Amazon EC2[2]    - Run instances in two or more Availability Zones[3]   - Examine and consider expanding your use of Amazon Route 53[4]  - Use Elastic Load Balancing

comm_body: Hello Prakash/Team,  Thank you for contacting AWS, It was a pleasure talking to you over the chat session. Kindly find below the chat summary.  You have initiated a chat session as you were facing issues with launching a new instance from the AMI "ami-0927c59bde20bd3d0".  As the current instance is "i-01a3dbae6889d0389" we have taken a look into the OS level logs by attaching the root volume to a rescue instance and we could see the below error.    Jun 24 10:18:48 finaclesitiap NetworkManager[792]: <info>  [1624510128.0691] audit: op="connection-activate" uuid="5fb06bd0-0bb0-7ffb-45f1-d6edd65f3e03" name="System eth0" result="fail" reason="No suitable device found for this connection (device eth0 not available because profile is not compatible with device (permanent MAC address doesn't match))."   Jun 24 10:18:48 finaclesitiap network: Bringing up interface eth0:  Error: Connection activation failed: No suitable device found for this connection (device eth0 not available because profile is not compatible with device (permanent MAC address doesn't match)).  Kindly note that this is due to Cloud-init not working and replacing the MAC address in the "/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0" file. So in order to bring the instance up we updated the MAC address to 02:a0:f6:d3:21:34 which is the MAC address of the ENI attached to the instance, which resolved the network issue of the instance and you were able to ssh into the instance.  Kindly note that this is a work around that will not cause any issues with the current instance "i-01a3dbae6889d0389" but in order to resolve the issue related to Cloud init you will have to look into the errors and resolving them. You can run cloud-init manually by using the below command.    # sudo cloud-init clean   # sudo cloud-init -d modules  You can verify id cloud-init is enabled to run at boot by using the below command.    # sudo systemctl is-enabled cloud-init  As discussed I will go ahead and resolve the case, please feel free to get back to us in case of additional queries

You contacted AWS Support as you were unable to release EIP's from your account with the error, and this was preventing you from provisioning a new Coudformation stack. comm_body: Hi Ashok,  Thank you for your time on call today, it was a pleasure speaking to you.  From our investigation, you were having issues with userdata execution for instances associated with your autoscaling group matrix-mrs - your Server 2019 instances were receiving the following error:  2021/07/02 01:32:11Z: Userdata execution begins 2021/07/02 01:32:11Z: Failed to get metadata: The result from http://169.254.169.254/latest/user-data was empty 2021/07/02 01:32:14Z: Unable to execute userdata: Userdata was not provided 2021/07/02 01:32:14Z: Userdata execution done  When this happens, it usually means the EC2Launch script was not set to initialize[1] after boot. In order to remedy this you followed option 2 in [1] to use the EC2Launch GUI to initialize your instance after every boot.   Afterwards, a stop-start showed that your userdata was executing as expected. As discussed, you will wait for the nightly AMI to be created, then test with it in the morning to verify that the setting persists in your new AMI. If you face any further difficulties, please reply here including the test instance launched from the new AMI, and the userdata log located at C:\ProgramData\Amazon\EC2-Windows\Launch\Log\UserdataExecution.log.  During our screenshare, we also found that your configuration instance was set to GMT instead of IST. You can also fix this in userdata using tzutil by adding this line to your script:  tzutil /s "India Standard Time"  Thank you for your time and patience with this matter. I look forward to hearing from you again.  Reference: [1] Configure a Windows instance using EC2Launch - Schedule EC2Launch to run on every boot - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ec2launch.html#run-on-every-boot  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Se

comm_body: Hello,  Greetings for the day!!  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support, I hope you are doing well, myself Saneesh from EC2 Linux team and I will be happy to help you with this case.  From the case description, I understand that, You received an email on 12:28AM IST about your EC2 persistent instance retirement scheduled, But the instance got rebooted before the scheduled date mentioned in the email. Please correct me if I misunderstood your query.  To investigate this issue, I have went ahead and looked at your instance 'i-05838a351448cacae', I can see that currently this instance is running on a healthy hardware and passing both instance and system level health checks. However, when I look at the metrics for last 24 hours, I could see that your instance was showing 'System status checks' [1] failure from 18:45 UTC to 21:04 UTC on 18-Jul-2021.  As you might be aware that 'System status checks' monitor the AWS systems on which your instance runs [2]. These checks detect underlying problems with your instance that require AWS involvement to repair. When a system status check fails, you can choose to wait for AWS to fix the issue, or you can resolve it yourself. For instances backed by Amazon EBS, you can stop and start the instance yourself, which in most cases results in the instance being migrated to a new host.  The following are examples of problems that can cause system status checks to fail:      Loss of network connectivity     Loss of system power     Software issues on the physical host     Hardware issues on the physical host that impact network reachability  On order to find the cause of the instance reboot, I have looked at the CloudTrial logs for your instance 'i-05838a351448cacae', I can see that the instance stop start has performed by the IAM user 'shraddhesh.rao', I am adding the details below, also you can find this link [3] to get more details about this stop-start event.  StopInstances - i-05838a351448cacae - 2021-07-18 20:52:21 UTC user - shraddhesh.rao  StartInstances - i-05838a351448c
