comm_body: Hello!  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Mike, and I will be assisting you with this case.  I understand that you are seeing an issue with the TempDB database size after migrating from SQL Server 2016 to SQL Server 2017.  I looked into the health of i-0db723240239391fa, as well as its underlying hardware, and did not find any issues. The volume performance statistics for vol-0e4bb61e99080e749 also look in-line for the gp3 volume type.  As we do not have any insight into the operating system, troubleshooting will be on a best-effort basis. [3]  TempDB growth can happen for a variety of reasons, including the features used, workload, and differences in SQL Server versions/editions.  You can reference these guides for best practices on monitoring, adjusting, and investigating what is happening with TempDB. [1] [2] Do note that any third party links are not tried nor tested by AWS.  If you need to modify the size of vol-0e4bb61e99080e749, you can do so by following these steps. [4]  Please let me know if you have any further questions, and I look forward to hearing back.  References: [1] https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/databases/tempdb-database?view=sql-server-ver15 [2] https://www.sqlshack.com/how-to-detect-and-prevent-unexpected-growth-of-the-tempdb-database/ [3] https://aws.amazon.com/compliance/shared-responsibility-model/ [4] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/requesting-ebs-volume-modifications.html  We value your feedback. comm_body: Greetings Kavit,    Ahmed Hassaan here again from AWS Premium Support. Here is a recap for what we have did to bring instances i-02b0cab52abe4fb12 back online.   I have classified below each section with its needed steps that covers what we have did to bring instance back online.  Note: For instance   i-02b0cab52abe4fb12:                   1- Both drivers were installed and loaded into kernel.                   2- Both drivers were loaded in the initial-ram disk.                   3- network interface name was changed and we have to disable network naming  by following the below section.                                    ======================================== + Disabling network interface renaming  + ======================================= The feature of "predictable network interface names" must be disabled. As if it is enabled the interface name may change from ethX to any other name like ensX and this can result in a failure in bringing network interface up.   Steps to Disable:     1- Edit the grub file /etc/defaultgrub :     $ sudo sed -i '/^GRUB\_CMDLINE\_LINUX/s/\"$/\ net\.ifnames\=0\"/' /etc/default/grub    2- Build the grub menu again by :    $ sudo grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg   Links :     - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/enhanced-networking-ena.html     - https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames/  As agreed, I'll go ahead and mark case as resolved. You are welcome to reach out to AWS Premium Support such you face any problem or need guidance and we will be happy  to assist.  Have a splendid day ahead.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Ahmed H. comm_body: Hi there,  I hope you are well.  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. My name is Mickhar and I will be assisitng you today.  Investigating this issue I see that the instance i-0bd86cefa36164591 is currently failing status checks, however from the screenshot I see that the instance is booted and on the login screen.  To further investigate this issue please can you perform the following:  1.Create a secondary ENI in subnet subnet-0d311207582ce0dc3, please also assign the same security groups assigned to ENI eni-06da563495fe6c9d4  For detailed steps on how to create a network interface please see the link below: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-eni.html#create_eni  2.Once the ENI has been created please attach it to instance i-0bd86cefa36164591.  For detailed steps on how to attach the network interface to an instance please see the link below: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-eni.html#attach_eni  Once attached please check to see that the instance passes status checks if it does please RDP to the instance using the IP address of the secondary ENI then check to see if the primary ENI is enabled on the instance. If the instance continues to fail status checks please let me know and we can continue to investigate this issue.  If you have any further questions please let me know and I will be more then happy to help you.  Have a great day further and stay safe.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Nandeesh,   Thanks for contacting AWS support. This is Sushil and was assisting you over the chat.  You reached out to us regarding "SSH was not working on the instance ". It was my pleasure to assist you on this and please find the summary of our conversation.   While being on chat , we checked below things .   telnet 10.10.128.12 22 Trying 10.10.128.12... Connected to ip-10-10-128-12.ec2.internal. Escape character is '^]'.  Telnet was working for 1 time and other time was not working. Then SSH worked and stopped working again. We tried to find the route which request is coming as well via VPN if any route changes.  traceroute and mtr also did not help much on this. We checked the other working instance which has similar settings in route tables and no issues.  Later it was fixed automatically without intervention and you were able to telnet and SSH for multiple session.   I hope above information was helpful and able to address your concern. I can confirm that there was no issue at instance level which we checked via running top command. Please do reach out to AWS VPN team if you see the similar issue again. As discussed, I will go ahead and mark this case as resolved.   Have a great day ahead.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi Brijesh,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Taha. It was nice working with you. I am following up regarding our discussion earlier.  To summarize, you had an instance i-09ec632a6120702cd failing reachability checks. I had a look at the instance.   I can see that the system status checks are healthy which means that the underlying hardware where your instance is running is healthy. Only the instance status checks are failing which is an indication of a problem inside the instance at the OS layer. Please note that we do not have visibility inside the instance for security and confidentiality reasons. Some typical reasons for instance status checks failures are resource exhaustion, broken network or startup configuration, kernel issues, or filesystem/device problems. For more information about EC2 status checks, please refer to this link [1].  To look at the system status checks metric, please refer to this link [2]. To look at the instance status checks metric, please refer to this link [3].  I checked the instance history and I can see it was launched about 2 hours ago. The instance never passed any status checks since it was launched. This means that the problem is in the AMI itself. You would need to fix those problems in the AMI first and then launch an instance from it. However, you mentioned that the instance that this AMI was created from was also already terminated. You mentioned you would be trying to launch another instance from a public Amazon Linux 2 AMI instead. If you need any data from this instance, you can simply attach the root volume to your new instance and copy the data over.  As discussed, I am going to mark this case as resolved. However, please feel free to reach out again in case of any other questions or concerns.  Have a good day!  ----- References ----- [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring-system-instance-status-check.html [2] https://ap-south-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=ap-south-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metr

comm_body: Hello Mathi,  Thanks for your time on the chat today, it was a pleasure working with you today. I am sending this email as a recap of our conversation.  You contacted us today because you were previously unable to connect to your instance i-0d8274b79c62e1e27 using the existing PEM key. Now you would like to launch a new instance using a backup AMI of this instance so that you can assign a new PEM key to this instance.  You also specified on chat that you want your new instance launched from the backup AMI of your instance to have the same primary private IP address as it.  To ensure that your new instance can be configured to use the IP address 10.26.1.119, it is first required that this IP address must not be tied to any other AWS resource, in this case meaning that you will have to terminate your instance i-0d8274b79c62e1e27 and ensure its ENI eni-0d56afccb9c335a86 using the IP address has been terminated also.   How do I assign a custom primary private IP address to my Amazon EC2 instance?  https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/custom-private-primary-address-ec2/  Before taking any further action here, I advise you to create an AMI [1] of your instance to have as a backup.  Once you have clarified that you have an up-to-date backup of your instance available, terminate your EC2 instance i-0d8274b79c62e1e27 [2].   The termination of your instance will also delete the ENI eni-0d56afccb9c335a86, making the IP address 10.26.1.119 available in your private IP address pool for your subnet subnet-788da00e.  Now that the private IP address 10.26.1.119 is available in your address pool, you can launch a new EC2 instance by following steps available in the below documentation.   Launch an instance using the Launch Instance Wizard  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/launching-instance.html   Ensure that on the 'Choose an Amazon Machine Image (AMI)' page that you are selecting your custom AMI, and that on the 'Configure Instance' page you configure your new instance to be in the same

comm_body: Hello Vaibhav,   It was a pleasure working with you, on chat. You reached out today, as you do not have the .pem key file used to encrypt the administrator password for the EC2 instance i-0acee79480715274b and you requested assistance in this regard.   Whenever the key pair used to launch a Windows instance is lost, the key pair needs to be replaced. To do this, there are two options, namely using SSM or performing the steps manually as illustrated in the article below:  [+] https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-windows-replace-lost-key-pair/  I have looked at i-0acee79480715274b and see that is a managed instance in the SSM console. So if you were to manually go through the process, this is how I would do it:  1. Connect to i-0acee79480715274b using a SSM Session Manager session from the console [1]. 2. Reset the local administrator password by running this command:  net user administrator <newAdminPassword> 3. RDP to i-0acee79480715274b using the administrator username with the new password specified in Step 2 4. Once connected, you can configure the Administrator password to be regenerated and encrypted by EC2Config [2]:  a) Open the XML file at the file path - \Program Files\Amazon\Ec2ConfigService\Settings\config.xml  b) At the top of the file, find the plugin with the name Ec2SetPassword and change the state from Disabled to Enabled and save the file. 5. Stop the instance and create an image of it [3]. 6. Once the AMI is available, launch an instance from the AMI created in Step 5. For Select a key pair, choose a key pair you do have access to. 7. Once this new instance is up and running, you can disassociate 13.229.187.44 from i-0acee79480715274b [4] and associate it to the instance launched from Step 6 [5].  You now have replaced the lost .pem file with one you do have and you should be able to retrieve the local Administrator's password from the EC2 console and connect to the instance.   If you require any further assistance, feel free to let me know and I will gladly provide it.

comm_body: Good day  Thank you for contacting AWS premium support, Its Jailosi again here. We got disconnected from the chat.  You reached out in order to find out why your instance was restarted.  During the investigation, We discovered that the instance was restarted through an API call. below are the API call event details.  eventId: 07cadcc0-463d-4dea-a560-7b3a9ed09e10 12:23:42 PM eventName: StopInstances 12:23:42 PM username: WIP_COR400@hdfcsldm.com 12:23:42 PM eventTime: 2021-07-11T19:30:25 UTC 12:23:42 PM  After reviewing this information, you wanted to know why the instance was started and if there was a problem on AWS side.  I mentioned that we would not know the reasons behind a reboot of an instance, however, I could check on my side to see if there was any problem with the underlying hardware during the time you specified  I looked into the system status check of the previous hardware and found that there were failed system checks on the hardware during the same period the instance was restarted. Perhaps this event influenced the restart of the instance as we have observed.  The following are examples of problems that can cause system status checks to fail:   * Loss of network connectivity? * Loss of system power? * Software issues on the physical host? * Hardware issues on the physical host that impact network reachability   I also discovered a notice about the detected degradation of the underlying hardware hosting your Amazon EC2 instance associated with this event in the ap-south-1 region which directly affected your instance. In the notice it was stated that due to this degradation your instance could already be unreachable.  You can find more details about the event as well as what you were expected to do from you end by checking the notice on the following link:   https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/v2/home?region=ap-south-1#Events  Ive included the CloudWatch link to the system status checks in the reference section below and some common causes of system status check failures for your convenience alo

comm_body: Hello Abhishek,  Dean here from AWS support. Pleasure chatting to you and Shivam on chat. Instance i-0b249e99c8b68b281 was unable to boot due to file system failures on the root volume vol-0d412d164102c1bb7 and the LVM volume vol-0517fdeffba0ac3f5.   We proceed to shutdown the failed instance, then attached the root volume vol-0d412d164102c1bb7  to a rescue instance you spun up. We perform a e2fsck file check on the root volume which was successful.  We then proceeded to mount the root volume back to the failed instance. However we were still unable to boot.    I noticed in the console logs that that its was failing to load the LVM volume vol-0517fdeffba0ac3f5 as well. We proceeded to mount the LVM volume onto the rescue instance and ran through e2fsck on each of the LVM mappings for the volume. We then attached the volume back to the failed instance however the instance was still failing to boot.  We then proceeded to launch a new rescue instance based of Amazon Linux1 in order to further check the grub configuration for the instance. We noticed that selinux is not enabled however in the /boot/grub/grub.conf that the option that selinux was set to 1 which means enabled. We then edited the grub.conf to selinux=0, in order to disable the use of selinux. We then unmounted the failed root volume back onto the original instance.   We then started the failed instance again and could confirm that the instance was passing status checks and you could access the instance via SSH.  As per our conversation , I will mark this case as resolved on my end. Pleasure assisting you once again Abhishek.  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Dean D. comm_body: Hello Team,  Thanks for contacting AWS premium support. My name is Romesh & I will be assisting you with case today. From case description I can understand that you would like to know about how to keep Ec2 instances sync with time and how timesync is managed at Ec2 level. Kindly correct me if I misunderstood your query as there was not much information present in case.  I would like to give information about Amazon Time Sync Service which provides a highly accurate and reliable time reference that is natively accessible from Amazon EC2 instances.  Built on Amazon's proven network infrastructure, the service utilizes a fleet of redundant satellite-connected and atomic reference clocks in AWS regions to deliver current time readings of the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) global standard. The service is designed to be highly available with a continuously monitored time infrastructure and provides a low variance reference time source. Leap seconds are known to cause application errors, and can be a concern for developers and system administrators. The Amazon Time Sync Service automatically smooths out (smears) leap seconds that are periodically added to UTC, so that customers do not have to worry about application errors due to their addition. In the future, we will also provide mechanisms for accessing non-leap smeared time. EC2 instances running in Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) can access this service at a universally reachable IP address. .  https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2017/11/introducing-the-amazon-time-sync-service/  You can access the Amazon Time Sync Service service via the link local 169.254.169.123 IP address. This means you dont need to configure external internet access and the service can be securely accessed from within your private subnets.  You can follow below documentation to find more information about how to use amazon tiemsync service on ec2 .  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/set-time.html  In case if you your query is not about Amazon Timesync service &

comm_body: Hello Harsimran,  This is Colin with AWS Premium support. It was a pleasure speaking with you today.  I would just like to recap our discussion regarding your performance difference in your load testing from your Logstash i-011231f80b92e3e75  & i-0bd29c55d070d104d instances running in the us-east-1a region.   You have performed load testing by modifying the exact same logstash configriation  to point to seperate elasticsearch clusters which have  been configured on i3en.2xlrage instance types detailed below.  Good Performing cluster instances: i-0094e0144d79a7013 & i-0094e0144d79a7013 Poor Performing cluster instances: i-0360d43edb554c991 & i-05f6d2f1fd272114f  As you have stated, the only difference in these clusters is that the poor performing cluster has 1 node in the us-east-1a AZ. The instance types, AMI, and configuration are identical  aside from the 50GB root partition difference in your EBS gp3 volume.   During our call, you also confirmed that you have a RAID setup on your ephemeral devices that the application is using. We confirmed that via iostat that drive utilization was not impending operations on either cluster as utilization ranged between 20-30%.  We could also see from monitoring the resouces via htop that the problematic servers were not being heavily utilized.  The CPU utilization between these two clusters showed differences as the good cluster was able to take more CPU load and showed more elevated CPU activity. We could see this on our CloudWatch CPUUtilization metrics referenced below [1][2]. We then focused on network utilization to see if there wereany bottlenecks impacting your Kibana request rate and request time metrics observed. We could see that the network utilization was higher on the good performing cluster [3][4].  We ran network traces from your logstach instances [5] via iperf benchmark tests and confirmed the instances were able to achieve close to the 25Gps throughput levels to all destination cluster instances. comm_body: Hello Saumitra,  Thank you for your time on chat earlier. It was a pleasure speaking with you. I'm following up with a short summary of our discussion.  As you confirmed, the termination of instances was due to a intentional and manual decrease in the desired number of instances for that AutoScaling group. This decrease was issued due to an unexpected and unexplained scaling event, and you wish to know what caused the scaling event.  I reviewed the AutoScaling group and found that there was an scaling policy attached to it, set to trigger a scale-out of 10 instances whenever the OutboundProxyActiveFlowCount CloudWatch alarm was triggered. This alarm triggered whenever ActiveFlowCount rose above a certain amount, however there was no corresponding scale-in event. This meant that every time the alarm triggered, the AutoScaling group would scale-out by another 10 instances, again and again until the maximum 80 instances was reached.   From the AutoScaling group side, only 6 instances were terminated due to failing health checks; the same 6 mentioned by my colleague. I reviewed the UnhealthyHostCount metric as requested, and saw that although there were several occasions during which there were unhealthy hosts, these were preceded by scale-out events which helped to handle the increased loads, leading to the instances apparently returning to a healthy state.  I hope this helped to clear matters up, but if you have any additional questions, please don't hesitate to update the case and I will be happy to help.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting Premium Support and providing us with notice regarding the vulnerability tests being performed. My name is Gilbert and it will be my pleasure to be of service with this request.  For most security assessments or penetration tests, advance notice is not required as long as the tests being carried out do not fall under certain prohibited activities, such as DNS zone walking, port, protocol or request flooding and carrying out actual or simulated DoS or DDoS attacks. For complete guidance on tests that can be carried our freely, along with prohibited activities and how to specifically submit a request to carry out other simulated events, please refer to the following page:      [1] AWS Customer Support Policy for Penetration Testing - https://aws.amazon.com/security/penetration-testing/  For DDoS and other simulated events, a form has to be submitted that requests additional information regarding the event and how potential abuse complaints and false positives may be addressed during these tests. comm_body: Hello Ansh,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure to talk with you. Daniel here with a short summary of our call.  --------------------  You have reached out to AWS Premium Support as you would like to know why instance i-06f2bb42e9c5f6d02 was rebooted.  Underlying hardware was rebooted due to intermittent issue.   On the call you have shared with me details related to your issue.  Instance i-06f2bb42e9c5f6d02 has been rebooted yesterday, around 08:20 UTC. You have checked CloudTrail logs however you were not able to find any API calls related to this instance.   I have begun by checking the CloudTrail from my end and I can confirm the same - there were no API calls made on this instance.  Next, I have checked instance status checks. As I can see, both system and instance status checks were failed:   StatusCheckFailed_Instance  https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22StatusCheckFailed_Instance%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-06f2bb42e9c5f6d02%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Sum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-07-17T06%3A46%3A18Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-07-17T10%3A46%3A18Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D    StatusCheckFailed_System  https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/deeplink.js?region=us-east-1#metricsV2:graph=%7B%22metrics%22%3A%5B%5B%22AWS%2FEC2%22%2C%22StatusCheckFailed_System%22%2C%22InstanceId%22%2C%22i-06f2bb42e9c5f6d02%22%5D%5D%2C%22stat%22%3A%22Sum%22%2C%22period%22%3A300%2C%22start%22%3A%222021-07-17T06%3A46%3A18.691Z%22%2C%22end%22%3A%222021-07-17T10%3A46%3A18.691Z%22%2C%22region%22%3A%22us-east-1%22%7D   As you may know, system status checks are related with the underlying hardware [1]. When they fail, it means that the issue is on AWS end.   In your case, the underlying hardware has experienced intermittent issue. As a result, it was rebooted and your instance was rebooted with it.    On behalf of AWS I would like to apologize for any disruptions this may have

comm_body: Good day Shruti,  Harun here from AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure chatting with you today.  To recap our conversation you reached out to us because the EC2 instance 'i-05a0fe5794df73345' was failing instance status checks.  We reviewed the instance and noticed it was failing to mount some mount points in '/efc/fstab'. We detached the root volume and attached it to a rescue instance. We commented out the entry for EFS and re-attached the volume to the affected instance.  We were able to successfully start and access the instance. We then tried to mount the EFS filesystem again but we were still getting an error. Upon mounting the EFS file system using the mount command, it was mounted successfully.  We reviewed the fstab entry and noticed the entry was as below   $ fs-1b1653ca:/ /efs efs defaults, _netdev 0 0   We updated the entry to the following and upon mounting it worked.   $ $ fs-1b1653ca:/ /efs efs defaults,_netdev 0 0   We also tested this by rebooting the instance and confirmed it worked.   As agreed on chat, I will mark this case as resolved since no further action is required from our end.  I hope you find this summary of the case helpful. If you have any other questions in this regard, kindly reach back to us and we will be happy to assist.  Thank you and have a great day ahead.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello,  It was a pleasure working with you today. I wanted to take this time to summarize out chat today.  When we connected you let me know that you had expanded your EBS volume but it was slow in updating the new size. By the time we connected on chat it was complete, but you were still seeing "Out of Space on Disk" errors from your application. I asked for the output of df -h and we could see that the OS was seeing the additional space, and that the volume was only at around 50% utilization:  Filesystem              Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on /dev/nvme0n1p1 118G 55G   59G  49%        /  From this we can summarize that the issue is likely with the application. You had mentioned that you believed the issue to be hardware, but I have looked into the hardware of both the instance and the attached EBS volume and both are reporting as healthy. I did let you know that you could stop/start (not reboot) the instance and it would be moved to new hardware, but you said you had already done that.   You then let me know that you were ok for now, but would update the case if you ran into any other issues. Please feel free to reach out if you have any other questions or concerns and I will be happy to assist.   We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi team,  Thanks for your time in the meeting earlier. You got in touch as you were no longer able to SSH into your EC2 instance "i-02ae29e6ce4d0c53d" as it was returning the error "Connection Refused".  This error typically suggests that SSH is not running. After reviewing the instance's console log[1], I was able to determine that the SSH service was indeed failing to start:    Starting OpenSSH server daemon...   [FAILED] Failed to start OpenSSH server daemon.   See 'systemctl status sshd.service' for details.  Using an Amazon Linux recovery instance, we re-mounted the problem instance's root EBS volume (vol-0ed83e4328c1380dc) to it and then mounted it:    $ lsblk   $ sudo mount /dev/xvdf1 /mnt  We then invoked chroot to /mnt using:    $ sudo mount -t sysfs /sys /mnt/sys   $ sudo mount -t proc /proc /mnt/proc   $ sudo mount -o bind /dev /mnt/dev   $ sudo chroot /mnt  At this point we were able to natively run commands on the problem root disk. We started off by checking the sshd config using:    $ sshd -t  This returned multiple errors relating to permissions under /etc/ssh/. After further investigation we found that the root file system permissions had been globally changed to "755". For example, using the command "chmod -R 755 /" which is not ideal at all.  We initially ran the following commands to manually fix permissions:    $ chmod 644 /etc/ssh/ssh_config   $ chmod 600 /etc/ssh/sshd_config   $ chmod 640 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ecdsa_key   $ chmod 644 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ecdsa_key.pub   $ chmod 640 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key   $ chmod 644 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key.pub   $ chmod 640 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key   $ chmod 644 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key.pub  However, we also needed to fix sudo permissions. We used the following command to fix all sudo permissions:    $ rpm --setugids sudo && rpm --setperms sudo  At this point you were able to re-attach the EBS volume back to the original instance, SSH in and execute sudo commands. However, as discussed it is likely that there may be other issues introduced by inc

comm_body: Hello Meghraj,  Thank you for your time on call and chat. It was pleasure talking to you.  Here is the summary of the discussion that we had:   - You had the query about maximum number of EBS volumes that can be attached to "r5.24xlarge" instance type.   - As mentioned over the call, "r5.24xlarge" instance type is a nitro based instance which has a maximum limit of 28 attachments including everything like EBS volumes, Network cards etc. Please see our AWS document that mentions the same[1].  - Further, you have asked whether there is an option to increase this limit. Unfortunately the maximum attachment limit for the Nitro system is a physical limitation dictated by the hardware itself, so it is not possible to increase this limit. EBS Volumes attach directly to the Instance through specialized NVMe Nitro Cards, bypassing the hypervisor itself and so there is a physical limitation in this regard. So we do not have an option to alter this limit in anyway.   Customer feedback is the main driver behind all of our service enhancements, so we really appreciate you reaching out to us with your feedback. I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and hope that I have answered all your queries.  Now, as concluded, currently, since there is nothing much that we could do here at the moment, and as all your queries are addressed, I am just marking this case as archived for now. But if you have got any queries/concerns, please feel free to get back to us by opening a new chat/case request and we will be more than happy to assist you in all possible ways.  Wishing you an AWSome day ahead.   References: ========= [1] Instance volume limits - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/volume_limits.html  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi Shammi,  It was a pleasure speaking with you today. I just wanted to send a short follow up summarizing what we spoke about.  You opened the chat because some of your instances was failing to resolve the domain name "dws-pp.hdfclife.com".  Therefore, since the issue is intermittent, I suspected of VPC DNS throttling, which you can confirm by following the article below:  - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/vpc-find-cause-of-failed-dns-queries/   Moreover, in case you confirm VPC DNS throttling, I suggested you to use a DNS cache, which usually avoid DNS resolution failures. Nonetheless, when you use a DNS cache to query external DNS resources, the cache answers most of the recurring DNS queries locally without interacting with the DNS resolver over the network. For more information regarding DNS cache, please refer to the documentation below:  - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/dns-resolution-failures-ec2-linux/   However, you mentioned that you also faced DNS issues to resolve your domain on Ubuntu instances, which is using systemd-resolve as DNS cache. Thus, in order to try to trigger the issue, I shared a loop command to query 10000 times the cache DNS and VPC DNS, however, we were not able to trigger the issue, and all queries run successfully.      for i in $(seq 10000);do dig @127.0.0.53 dws.hdfclife.com |grep -i "fail|nxdomain" ;done     for i in $(seq 10000);do dig @172.27.96.2 dws.hdfclife.com |grep -i "fail|nxdomain" ;done   Finally, we then disabled systemd-resolve from one of your Ubuntu instance (test instance), and you will monitor your application to see if the issue persist or not. In case you don't face the issue on the test instance, I suggest you to either disable systemd-resolve from the instances that you still face the issue, or use DNSMasq [01] as DNS cache.      rm /etc/resolv.conf     cp /run/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf /etc/resolv.conf     systemctl disable systemd-resolved.service     systemctl stop systemd-resolved.service     echo "option

comm_body: Hello Aditya Thank you for your time on the chat today. This mail is to summarize to our discussion.  You had reached us today as the instance i-0e93453f3d3980041 was stopping automatically by itself. You are looking for assistance on identifying the issue.  I began by checking the "System"[1] and "Instance"[2] status checks in cloudwatch and do not see any issues there. This indicates there are no EC2 AWS underlying systems level issues that could be causing this. I next checked Cloudtrail logs for any EC2 API call "StopInstances" which is used to bring down and stop EC2 instance. There were no such API calls issued.  From my internal tools I could see that the instance went into stopped state with the message 'Instance initiated shutdown'. Looking at this AWS API documentation[3], this message usually indicates the shutdown was initiated from inside the operating system.  Due to security, privacy and shared responsibility model, AWS Support doesn't have visibility or access to instance logs[4]. Appreciate your understanding here.  Having said that, I see that the instance is launched with a private customized AMI. As discussed in chat, i recommend to take a look at the operating system logs to garner further information to look into the reason for the shutdown. If the instance doesn't stay up long enough to go through the logs, the root volume can be attached to a rescue instance to collect the logs using the below steps.  1) Launch a new Amazon EC2 instance to be used as rescue in the same subnet. 2) Detach the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) root volume (/dev/xvda or /dev/sda1) from your impaired instance[5]. 3) Attach the EBS volume as a secondary device ( /dev/sdf) to the rescue instance[6]. 4) Connect to your rescue instance using SSH. 5) Create a mount point directory (/rescue) for the new volume attached to the rescue instance in step 3. $ sudo mkdir /rescue 6) Mount the volume at the directory you created in step 5. Use the lsblk command to view your available disk devices along with their moun

comm_body: Hello Akash,  Thank you for your time on the chat today! It was a pleasure assisting you. You reached out to us as you noticed an error "sudo: /etc/sudoers.d/90-cloud-init-users is owned by uid 1000, should be 0, sudo: /etc/sudoers.d/ssm-agent-users is owned by uid 1000, should be 0" while running "sudo su". Below is our chat summary for reference:  The error "sudo: /etc/sudoers.d/90-cloud-init-users is owned by uid 1000, should be 0" occurs when the /usr/bin/sudo or /etc/sudoers file is owned by a non-root user. The /usr/bin/sudo and sudoers file must have root:root as the owner.   We tried to fix the error by running the user-data script in link[1], however we got the same error. So, we decided to manually change it. We stopped the instance, detached the root volume and attached the volume to a test instance as /dev/sdf. Below are the steps we followed:   $ sudo mount /dev/xvdf1 /mnt  $ cd /mnt  $ ls -al    Here we noticed that the permissions for /etc/ itself was changed to ec2-user:ec2-user.   $ sudo chmod -R root:root /mnt/etc   We ran the above command to fix the permissions.   $ sudo umount /mnt  Once we followed the above steps, we detached the volume and reattached it to the original instance as /dev/xvda and started the instance back up. After this you were successfully connected to the instance.   On this note, we ended our chat session. As discussed on the chat, I'll go ahead and resolve this case on your behalf. Please feel free to let me know if you have any other questions or concerns and I'll be glad to assist.   [1] https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-sudo-commands/  We value your feedback. Please share your experience by rating this correspondence using the AWS Support Center link at the end of this correspondence. Each correspondence can also be rated by selecting the stars in top right corner of each correspondence within the AWS Support Center.  Best regards, Sravan R. comm_body: Hello,   Nthuseng here from the AWS Premium Support team, it was a pleasure chatting to you today.  From the case description and during our call, I understood that SSM agent on instance "i-05d4e471aa9d9b2b3" doesn't start.  I investigated this issue and please find the recap of our troubleshooting as follows:  - Reviewed instance and instance is passing both its status checks [1]. - Checked security gateway, ACL and route table. No issue found from these settings. - We tried uninstall and reinstall the SSM agent manually [2]. - Upon checking SSM logs attached, I found the following error" "Failed to start agent. failed to get identity: failed to find agent identity" This error is related identity issue and checked the metadata access by viewing following URL: http://169.254.169.254/latest/dynamic/instance-identity/document  I understand you cannot restart instance right now since its a production instance. I did some further research, Kindly stop the SSM agent from PowerShell by running the below command with elevated privileges:  Get-Process | processname -ssm-agent-worker | Stop-Process -Force; Restart-Service -Name AmazonSSMAgent   Once you stopped the ssm-agent-worker.exe process, could you attempt to start SSM agent service. If you are still not able to start it, then proceed with steps below once you can afford some down time.  I then checked your EC2 Config service version and you currently running version "v4.9.3519" which was released 18 June 2019. Please update to the latest EC2 Config version by following the steps below and then restart the instance.  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/UsingConfig_Install.html#ec2config-update-version  Once you have updated EC2 config and restarted instance, please start the SSM service. If you are still experiencing issues, please provide us the latest SSM logs and attach it to case for further investigation.  We look forward to hearing back from you.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi Darshana,   Were you able to run through the test that I suggested? I am interested to know the results of the test. Also, are you able to confirm that the script always produces consistent results? In other words, does the script produce the same result every single time it is run?   As I mentioned previously, AWS support does not cover the troubleshooting and debugging of custom scripts. The 'cron' utility in Linux is only a scheduler; so if there is a discrepancy, it is likely in the task that was configured in 'cron'. I would like to suggest that you involve a Linux systems administrator here as well so that they may review your script and cron configuration.   Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.   We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Anu,  Thank you for your patience.  As per the update from the internal service team, there were no issues with the underlying host during the time the instance CPU spiked, so to summarize the issue seems to have been triggered at the OS level itself. Also, if we see the number of processes that were running that time, there are 900+ processes initiated by Apache, so there is a possibility of Apache user ulimit being hit which is a configuration at the OS level and since the instance is terminated we cannot check those limits. Since the issue at host end has been isolated, the investigation further would require an access to the OS logs such as /var/log/messages and /var/log/dmesg and unfortunately we do not have this data available. The graphs that you shared were helpful in reaching out on a conclusion that there was high load average including the memory unavailability on the instance at that time which points that the root cause seems to be some culprit process hogging the server resources or some limits being hit at the OS level. As discussed on the call, I would suggest you to have the "ATOP" tool configured on the OS for a better analysis of the server resources and the processes running on it.   For more details on the tool here:  https://www.tecmint.com/how-to-install-atop-to-monitor-logging-activity-of-linux-system-processes/  Unfortunately, we are unable to dive deep for further investigation due to lack of OS logs and instance being terminated as of now. I completely understand that this might not be the exact response that you were looking for and we are really sorry for the same, however in such scenarios when there is no issue at the host/hardware level, we cannot provide an RCA and in this case the situation is a little different as well considering the instance is no longer available.  I hope you understand our limitations here and in case you want to discuss anything, please feel free to update the case and we can schedule a call.  Have a great day ahead!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Dear AWS customer,  Thank you for contacting the AWS Premium Support, my name is Abhilash and it was a pleasure talking to you today. Please find the brief summary of our conversation.  You contacted AWS support as you were getting the insufficient capacity error when launching the "r5a.2xlarge" instance type in ap-south-1a and ap-south-1b AZ .  As you might be aware, the Insufficient Capacity error means that the new instance was unable to launch due to the lack of unused r5a.2xlarge instance type in our pool in that specific AZ (ap-south-1a, 1b) at that time. The on-demand capacity is dynamic, may be different for different availability zones and different instance types and sizes and hence changes frequently and these changes cannot be predicted.   On behalf of AWS, I sincerely apologize about any inconvenience or business impact caused by this. I verified the capacity for in ap-south-1a, 1b AZ  when you faced the issues and confirmed that there was not enough capacity for r5a.2xlarge  instance type. I verified other AZ's in the ap-south-1 region and confirmed that, ap-south-1c had some capacity but you updated that you are not operating in that AZ.  However, I would like to bring to your attention that on-demand capacity is not guaranteed. The  "Insufficient Capacity"  error will resolve itself as we add capacity or turn over currently running instances, but we cannot estimate how long this will take. Because, as customers keep on adding resources on the fly and we have no insight as to how many resources and how long the resources will be occupied by customers. Due to this the capacity may change. Apart from this our  EC2 Capacity team would automatically be aware of low capacity issue and always try to increase capacity based on the demand, but the work flow would take substantial amount of time to get more capacity in. Due to this I will not be able to provide an ETA.  [R1].  In general there are certain things which are advised to do, if you receive such error (I understand that some of the below workaro

comm_body: Hello Rakesh,  Thanks for your time over the call today!  As per our discussion, you reached out to us to clarify what drivers needs to be installed on R5 instance type.  As discussed on the call, since R5 is a Nitro instance type, the required drivers would be ENA (Network drivers) and NVMe (storage drivers).  you also wanted to know the instances that run on AWS PV drivers. please find the list below.  > T2, G2 and M3 instance type utilize AWS PV drivers for both networking and storage.  > C4, D2, M4 (except m4.16xlarge), C3, I2 and R3 instance types utilize AWS PV drivers for storage and Intel 82599 VF for networking.  > Apart from the above mentioned instance types all other (Nitro instance type) utilizes AWS ENA (Networking) and NVMe (Storage) drivers.  I'm also attaching the docs in the references which will detail you more information with respect to AWS drivers.  References:  [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/instance-types.html#instance-type-summary-table  [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/enhanced-networking.html  [3] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/xen-drivers-overview.html  We look forward to hearing back from you soon. I hope the shared information was useful, In case you have any other concerns, please always feel free to reach out to us and we would be more than happy to assist you.  Thank you! comm_body: Hello Sankalp,  Greetings!  This is Karthik from AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure to work with you today over chat. Kindly find the summary of our conversation below.  You reached out to us today because you wanted to increase the disk size beyond 2TB for the Ec2 instance i-079b9cd6447034f31 vol-05653661bb1c6763c. The EC2 instance has Ubuntu 18.04 OS. You had a 2TB volume which you modified to 3TB but you were unable to extend it because of the MBR error.   I informed you that the reason for this error is that MBR doesn't support more than 2TB and the resolution would be to convert the EC2 Ubuntu instance's default MBR partitioning scheme to GPT in order to bypass the 2 TiB limit for MBR partitions on the EBS volume. I provided you with the document that I have listed in the references as [1] which has the detailed steps that need to be followed in order to resolve the issue.   Since making changes at the OS level was a system admin task, I agreed to provided you support on best effort basis. You were concerned about step 8 in the above document. To protect your critical data, I suggested you to take a backup of the instance and the volume using Amazon EBS-backed Linux AMI [2].   You had a question regarding nvme0n1p1 which is 2 TB and if you can create nvme0n1p2. This wasnt possible because in order to use more than 2TB on nvme0n1 you would need to convert default MBR partitioning scheme to GPT.   Followed by which you had a question regarding shrinking the EBS volume size from 3TB to 2TB as only 2 TB was mounted. I verified this on my test instance and confirmed that it is not possible to reduce the size of the EBS volume as I got this error The size of a volume can only be increased, not decreased.  I suggested you a work around by adding another 1TB volume to the EC2 instance as a secondary volume. You wanted steps to mount an EBS volume as a secondary volume for which I provided you with the documents  Step 1: Create a new volume [3]  Step 2: Attach it to the EC2 instance [4]  Step 3: Make th

comm_body: Hello Santosh,  This is Parth again from AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure talking to you earlier today. Please find the summary of our conversation below.  You reached out to us as you were unable to start the CloudWatch agent. We first went ahead and checked the agent logs using this command: cat /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/logs/amazon-cloudwatch-agent.log. In the logs we saw the following error:  2021/07/29 19:37:13 Reading json config file path: /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/etc/amazon-cloudwatch-agent.json ... /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/etc/amazon-cloudwatch-agent.json does not exist or cannot read. Skipping it. No json config files found, please provide config, exit now  2021/07/29 19:37:13 I! Return exit error: exit code=99 2021/07/29 19:37:13 I! there is no json configuration when running translator  From this error, I could understand that the agent configuration file was not configured. So we went ahead and configured the file using the configuration wizard [1]. Please find the commands we used below:  - To configure agent: sudo /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/bin/amazon-cloudwatch-agent-config-wizard. We then answered all the configuration questions.  - To stop the agent: sudo /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/bin/amazon-cloudwatch-agent-ctl -m ec2 -a stop  - To start the agent: sudo /opt/aws/amazon-cloudwatch-agent/bin/amazon-cloudwatch-agent-ctl -a fetch-config -m ec2 -s -c file:<configuration-file-path>. Here we replaced <configuration-file-path> with the path of the config.json file created by the wizard.  After doing this, the agent was successfully running. We then copied the config.json file to your second server and pasted it in the same location as the 1st one. We then stopped and started the agent again using the above commands and verified that the agent was running successfully.  As discussed on call, I will go ahead and resolve this case for you. However, if you have any further issues or concerns, please feel free to reach out, and we will be glad to assist you further

comm_body: Hello Sivaranchani,  Thanks for your time on the call today. It was pleasure talking to you. I wanted to summarize our conversation and provide you some resources.  You reached out to us for troubleshooting the instance status check failure for the instance (i-0269a0b0823d403b9).  An instance status check failure indicates a problem with the instance, such as [1]: - Networking or startup configuration issues - Exhausted memory - File system issues - Failure to boot the operating system - Failure to mount volumes correctly - Incompatible drivers  From the screenshot, I confirmed that instance was booted up and could see logon screen. If an instance becomes unreachable during logon [2], there could be a problem with your network configuration or Windows Remote Desktop Services. An instance can also be unresponsive if a process is using large amounts of CPU.  As a part of troubleshooting, we have done the following steps - Stop/start didn't fix the issue - Attached secondary ENI and soon after that, instance status checks were passing. - When login through domain credentials, you got ' There are currently no logon servers..' error. However, login through local 'Administrator' worked. - After RDP, we could see that primary ENI was disabled and we manually enabled it back. - After disabling the secondary ENI, we could see that primary ENI detected the domain 'airvistara.com' - However, user credentials for 'infrateam.tcs' didn't work for you. As discussed, please reset your domain credentials in the Active Directory and try again.  I hope the information provided today has been helpful. That being said, if you have any other questions please do not hesitate to reach out to me, I am more than happy to help.  On behalf of AWS, have a fantastic day!  References: [1] Why is my EC2 Windows instance down with an instance status check failure? - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/ec2-windows-instance-status-check-fail/ [2] Troubleshoot an unreachable instance - Log on screen (Ctrl+Alt+Delete) - https://d

comm_body: Hello Vipin,   This is Imran from AWS Support in Sydney, thanks for your time over chat. It was pleasure assisting you today.  You contacted us today as you wanted to get an instance availability report, specifically information on instance uptime and downtime per instance for the month.  From my investigation I have found that you can use AWS Cost Explorer to get the total amount of hours instances in that account were up and running for, along with the associated cost. You can filter per instance type and per Availability Zone etc. Cost Explorer will retrieve the data from the past 12 months.  To use Cost Explorer to find this data, please follow below: 1) Go to the Cost Explorer console 2) Go to Reports 3) Select Monthly EC2 running hours costs and usage 4) Filter by Tags or instance types.  Unfortunately, you cannot get the downtime of an instance as there is no metric for this.  More information on this can be found at the following link [1], filtering info can be found at the following link [2].  To get the instance up-time from last boot and see how long it has been currently running for, this can be achieved at the OS level. AWS does not have visibility into the OS of an instance for security and privacy as per the AWS Shared Responsibility Model [3]. This will have to be performed on the customers end as we do not have the visibility to do this.  To get the up-time of an instance at the OS level, from an administrative PowerShell session run the following command:       (get-date) - (gcim Win32_OperatingSystem).LastBootUpTime  The output of this command will tell you how long the instance has been running for since its last boot.  To get the last boot time for multiple instances or for a singular instance, you could use AWS Systems Manager Run Command [4] to run the above command across a number of instances. This would remove the need to log onto each instance to run this command individually.  I hope this has helped with your query and if you have any other questions or concerns regarding this issue

comm_body: Hi again Shubham,  Thanks for your time earlier on the chat, this is Jason with a followup from our conversation.  As I mentioned over the call, I will close the duplicate case 8651840051 shortly, since we looked at the issue on this case instead.  You got in touch as your instance i-0b82158c49bb4b062 was only seeing 8 vCPUs at the OS level, even though it is running an M5.4xlarge which has 16 vCPUs available.  I explained how an instance with 16 vCPUs is made up of 8 cores each with 2 threads, totaling 16 threads (vCPUs).  From Task Manager and the command line, you could see that only 8 logical processors were being recognised at the OS level.  I asked you to log in to the server to check the registry, so that we could make sure Hyperthreading was enabled.  The registry key in question is as follows:  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Memory Management  Within this registry key, saw the FeatureSettingsOverride key was set to 0x2048, indicating that Hyperthreading was disabled. This means that from the 8 cores, the machine could only make use of a single thread for each core rather than using both.  To enable Hyperthreading, this value had to be changed to 0, and the machine needs to be rebooted. I gave you the following command to run from an Administrator command prompt:  reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Memory Management" /v FeatureSettingsOverride /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f   You ran the command and confirmed the value was now 0.  The next step is to perform a reboot of the instance, which you will perform at your next convenience since this is a production server.   Additionally, the CloudWatch metrics were reporting CPU Utilization figures roughly half of the figures you were seeing at the OS level. This is because CloudWatch metrics for EC2 instances are taken from the underlying hardware level itself, not the OS. From CloudWatch's perspective, all 16 vCPUs are measured, while from the OS perspective only 8 were available due to Hype

comm_body: Hi Bala,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure to chat with you today. I am following up with a quick recap of our conversation.   You reached out to us as you are unable to RDP to instance  i-07bd2af7820d48785. On reviewing the instance details, I confirmed that the security groups and network ACLs allowed traffic from the source machine IP CIDR range (10.35.0.0/16). However, there was no route present in the associated route table rtb-318e6b57 to 10.35.0.0/16. Please add this route via a VGW  to enable traffic flow between this on-premise server and the  instance.  Next, when you tried to RDP into the instance  i-07bd2af7820d48785 from another instance, you were able to get the RDP prompt, however, you were unable to sign in due to the following error "An Authentication Error has occurred (Code: 0x800004005)".  As I mentioned, this could be due to various reason such as: 1. Incorrect credentials 2. Time skew between the instance and the DCs. 3. NLA issue due to server losing trust relationship with domain.  We were unable to determine which of the above reasons is the cause as you do not have permissions to make changes to the instance or AWS component. Here are some steps to begin troubleshooting  the issue.  1. Reboot the instance and retry RDP 2. Try logging in with local admin account instead of domain user. 3. If the above steps do not work, you will need to make the instance managed via SSM and troubleshoot it remotely.        a. Create an instance profile: https://docs.amazonaws.cn/en_us/systems-manager/latest/userguide/setup-instance-profile.html#instance-profile-add-permissions       b. comm_body: Hello Rinkesh,  Tahriqh here again, thanks for getting back to me.  I understand that you need a permanent solution for this issue.  Please note that this AMI is configured with the /etc/fstab file having an entry to automatically mount the device by it's device name "/dev/xvdb1". This means that if the AMI is launched and the device name is static as "/dev/xvdb1", it will work fine.   However, if the device name changes at any time - for example when changing the instance type to a Nitro based instance - the instance will not boot up.  A permanent solution would be to change the /etc/fstab file as suggested in my previous reply and then create a new AMI from that instance to be used going forward, there is no other solution.  If you do not want to use the UUID in the /etc/fstab file, you can also give the device a label and specify that label in the /etc/fstab file - labels also persist across instance types. Instructions:  ----- 1. First you will get the device name:  lsblk  2. Then, you add a label to that device (replace {label} with a label of your choice and {device_name} with the device name you got from lsblk):  sudo tune2fs -L {label} {device_name}  3. Next, add the following entry into your /etc/fstab file to mount the device by its label:  LABEL={YOUR-LABEL}  {/path/to/mount/point}  {file-system-type}  {options} 0 0 -----  This way, you will configure your instance to mount the device according to its label.  If you would like the extra device mounted automatically at boot across different instance types, you will have to specify the mount instruction either by its UUID or by its label, this is the permanent solution and there is no other way around this requirement.  If you have any further questions or need assistance, please let me know, I'm happy to help.  Have a great day further and keep well.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hi,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Ghulam. It was a pleasure chatting with you. I am sharing a brief summary of our discussion on the chat.  You reached out to us because you were not able to telnet from instance "i-0b3678aed26a78a7d" to instance " i-090c32c0cd0248281" on port 19001-19010  During the chat we discussed that Security groups for the instance were configured correctly to allow traffic from the source to destination and both the instances were in the same VPC and would communicate over the local route in the routing table.   We checked that the issue was for the port range 19001-19010 however the SSH was working fine. We checked if the application was running on the instance and if the port was listening using below command. We found that ports were not listening on the instance.                             $ sudo netstat -tulpen | grep 1900*  You started the application by working with your internal team however the telnet was still not working. We went ahead and checked the firewall on the instance and found that there was a rule to drop all traffic except the allowed rules. We went ahead and added another rule to allow specific for the port 19001 using below command which fixed the issue.                           $ iptables-save > IPtablesbackup.txt                           $ sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 19001 -j ACCEPT   As agreed over the chat, I will be marking this case as resolved. However, if you have any other query regarding the case, please feel free to ask and I will be happy to answer your query.   Have a Good Day Ahead!  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello,  It is Tomasz again from AWS Premium Support. I hope this email finds you well.  To summarize our calls, there was an issue with a lifecycle hook that has been deleted in one of your AutoScaling groups. Recreating the hook with the same settings as before caused new instances to enter the "Wait" state and be terminated after 600 seconds.   We established that the hooks are created automatically by the CodeDeploy service when an ASG is selected in the settings of a code deployment group. The EC2 Console does not allow to specify the "Notification target ARN" parameter when creating a new lifecycle hook, so we tried to use the "put-lifecycle-hook" command [1] with the "--notification-target-arn" parameter. This, however, did not solve the problem - even after specifying the same SQS queue, we still did not see any code deployments getting launched when new instances were created by the ASG.  After testing this in my lab environment, I found that the messages pushed to a CodeDeploy-managed SQS queue must contain a unique identifier that is generated when you associate a deployment group with an ASG. The identifier should be included in the optional metadata section of the given lifecycle hook. Moreover, the name of the hook must be the same as the one that was generated after associating the ASG with the code deployment group. The below command will correctly restore a deleted lifecycle hook:   aws autoscaling put-lifecycle-hook --lifecycle-hook-name GENERATED_NAME --auto-scaling-group-name ASG_NAME --lifecycle-transition autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING --notification-target-arn SQS_ARN --heartbeat-timeout 600 --notification-metadata GENERATED_UNIQUE_ID   I would recommend, however, recreating deleted hooks by editing the given deployment group, removing the associated ASG from the list in the "Environment configuration" section, then adding it again and saving the changes. We tested this in your environment and confirmed that performing the mentioned steps after deleting a code deployment lifecycle hook

Let me recap our conversation so that you have all the elements to review them offline.    As discussed on the call, the reason you received the notifications is because your AWS account currently has EC2-Classic enabled in AP-SOUTHEAST-2, AP-SOUTHEAST-1, US-WEST-2, EU-WEST-1,US-WEST-2 AND US-EAST-1 REGIONS, but does not currently have any AWS resources running in EC2-Classic. As part of the EC2-Classic retirement program, we will be turning off EC2-Classic for US-WEST-2 Region from your account on October 30, 2021.  However, there is no action needed on your part. We will turn off EC2-Classic from your account on October 30, 2021. We request that you do not launch any AWS resources on EC2-Classic going forward and use Amazon VPC for future needs. Once turned off, you will not be able to access EC2-Classic or launch any AWS resources on it. comm_body: Hello Venkata Rajesh,  Thank you for contacting Premium Support. I am Achilles and I would be one of the engineers assisting you with this case. From the case description I understand that your nfs-client (i-0780876421afc800f) is connecting to your nfs-server (i-08bae8a4f3b18d769). You suspect an issue with the network. Please correct me should my understanding be incorrect.  Ive analyzed the console logs via available to me via the internal tools. Ive also checked instance level statistics using my internal tools. There are two issues you are facing one on nfs-server and one on the nfs-client.  Please find my analysis below.   ## Analysis: ==========  o I checked your nfs-server and found the below logs in the console: ...     [47081846.651506] XFS: nfsd(30561) possible memory allocation deadlock size 131088 in kmem_alloc (mode:0x2400240)     [47081848.655518] XFS: nfsd(30561) possible memory allocation deadlock size 131088 in kmem_alloc (mode:0x2400240)     [47081850.659531] XFS: nfsd(30561) possible memory allocation deadlock size 131088 in kmem_alloc (mode:0x2400240) ...  o Please note that we have no visibility to customer instances at the OS level due to privacy [1] and security [2] reasons it would be difficult for me to point out as to what is exact issue from the OS end.  OS level troubleshooting is a system administration task[3], it is not within the scope of AWS Support. However, In any case, be assured that I will try best to give recommendations base on my analysis of the above logs.  o From the above messages it is evident that the nfsd process is facing issues. The stacks are printed by XFS, which means that nfsd is exporting XFS local filesystem. nfsd process is the nfs-server process which is responsible for fetching the data from the local filesystem and sending it over to the clients that request it. Therefore, issues with nfsd process can cause the issues that youre seeing on the nfs-client. This issue needs to be fixed along with instance level issues that Ive mentioned later in this up

comm_body: Hello Faijal,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was a pleasure assisting you today. I am sending this correspondence as a follow-up to recap what we discussed and to consolidate all the information into one email.  You reached us as you were not able to copy the AMI from your account to different account. We checked the Key policy in your account, and it seemed fine. Later we checked the AMI in the target account and it was successfully shared. We checked the permissions in the target account for your role and added below permissions to your role.   {     "Sid": "AllowUseOfCMKInAccount111122223333",     "Effect": "Allow",     "Action": [       "kms:Encrypt",       "kms:Decrypt",       "kms:ReEncrypt*",       "kms:GenerateDataKey*",       "kms:CreateGrant",       "kms:DescribeKey"     ],     "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:787935213539:key/<key name> }  Then we launched an instance out of the AMI and it was launched successfully. However, when you tried to copy the AMI again in the target account, you were shown the below error:   You do not have permission to access the storage of this ami.  We then added the CreateVolumePermission permissions to the snapshots of the AMI so that the target account is able to copy the AMI. After doing this via console, you again tried to copy the AMI and this time, you were able to copy the AMI.  With this we ended our chat on the note that I can close the case. Hence, Im marking the case as resolved. However, you can reach us again via Premium Support should you have any further queries and we will be happy to assist you further.  We value your feedback. comm_body: Hello Nasreen,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. It was pleasure talking to you today.  Please find summary of our conversation below :  I understand that one of your instances is failing instance level health checks i-027a1a3dbb36d7eb1. The instance was failing instance level health check and is passing system level checks indicating that the issue is on operating system level.   Upon checking the instance logs, I have noticed that the instance is failing to boot with below error :  Kernel panic - not syncing: Attempted to kill init! exitcode=0x00007f00  As previous engineer shivakumar mentioned below, these kind of kernel panic errors can be seen due to multiple reasons but the most common ones are listed below :  1. The initramfs or initrd image is missing from the newly updated kernel configuration in /boot/grub/grub.conf. Or, the initrd or initramfs file itself is missing from the /boot directory. 2. The kernel or system packages weren't fully installed during the upgrade process due to insufficient space. 3. Third-party modules are missing from the initrd or initramfs image. For example, NVMe, LVM, or RAID modules. 4. Failing to mount filesystems defined in /etc/fstab  During our chat, you have mentioned that the network configuration file was modified and instance started failing after that. I had suggested you to recover the root volume from a snapshot that was taken before the changes. You have created the volume from snapshot snap-0378100c464f6b1a7 that was created on august 7th. The instance was not able to boot from the August 7th volume with new error :  [[1;33mDEPEND[0m] Dependency failed for /s1/pcunica/archivelog. [[1;33mDEPEND[0m] Dependency failed for Local File Systems. [[1;33mDEPEND[0m] Dependency failed for Relabel all filesystems, if necessary. [[1;33mDEPEND[0m] Dependency failed for Mark the need to relabel after reboot. [[1;33mDEPEND[0m] Dependency failed for Migrate local... structure to the new structure.  It looks like there is a discrepancy with FSTAB entries an

comm_body: Hello,  Thank you for contacting AWS Premium Support. This is Shivakumar from Linux Support team, Sydney and I will be assisting you with your case today.  From the case notes, I understand that you would like to know the rootcause for the instance (i-027a1a3dbb36d7eb1) status checks failure.   Upon reviewing the instance console logs, I observed that the instance failed to boot due to kernel panic error below. I do not see complete boot logs, most probably your instance may not be redirecting all console output to ttyS0.   ------------------------------------------------------------------ [    2.801203] Kernel panic - not syncing: Attempted to kill init! exitcode=0x00007f00 [    2.801203]  [    2.803195] CPU: 0 PID: 1 Comm: systemd Not tainted 3.10.0-1127.8.2.el7.x86_64 #1 [    2.804803] Hardware name: Amazon EC2 m5.large/, BIOS 1.0 10/16/2017 [    2.806173] Call Trace: [    2.806727]  [<ffffffff9537ffa5>] dump_stack+0x19/0x1b [    2.807842]  [<ffffffff95379541>] panic+0xe8/0x21f [    2.808887]  [<ffffffff94ca2b46>] do_exit+0xa16/0xa20 [    2.809985]  [<ffffffff94ca2bcf>] do_group_exit+0x3f/0xa0 [    2.811164]  [<ffffffff94ca2c44>] SyS_exit_group+0x14/0x20 [    2.812354]  [<ffffffff95392ed2>] system_call_fastpath+0x25/0x2a [    2.813762] Kernel Offset: 0x13c00000 from 0xffffffff81000000 (relocation range: 0xffffffff80000000-0xffffffffbfffffff) ------------------------------------------------------------------  Your instance might fail to boot and show the kernel panic error message for the several reasons. Following are some of the reasons.  1. The initramfs or initrd image is missing from the newly updated kernel configuration in /boot/grub/grub.conf. Or, the initrd or initramfs file itself is missing from the /boot directory. 2. The kernel or system packages weren't fully installed during the upgrade process due to insufficient space. 3. Third-party modules are missing from the initrd or initramfs image. For example, NVMe, LVM, or RAID modules. 4. Failing to mount filesystems defined in /etc/fstab  The easies

comm_body: Hello,  This is Shubham again from AWS Premium Support. Thank you for your time over the chat today, it was a pleasure assisting you.  It looks like you were no longer available at your desk, hence I had to disconnect the chat at my end. That being said, please find a short summary of our conversation as below:  ============  -- You reached out as you wanted to know the reason behind the high network level data transfer usage corresponding to your instances for the month of July and were looking for an assistance on the same. Upon our conversation, we discussed the following:     -> Using my internal tools, I could confirm that indeed there were high data transfers happening in the mentioned instances i.e. i-017c6a212a27537ce and i-053233c00644a6c2d which is why you were being charged so much for the instance data transfers.     -> Following this, you wished to know of a way by which you can determine the cause of the data transfer (the applications performing this transfer). To this, we discussed that AWS Premium Support engineers dont have resource level access due to the data privacy policy we follow. Hence, in order to check this youll need to install network monitoring tools inside the instances and log the network data transfer data inside the instance so that you can access and identify the applications causing this data transfer.     -> Upon checking further, I could see that the instances in question were windows OS based instance. We discussed, that since Im from the EC2 linux team, I dont have an expertise in handling Windows instances and hence dont have much idea on the tools and techniques you can use to get this data from your instances.  That being said, I mentioned that it would be best for you to raise a case with the windows team as they would have a better expertise and visibility in assisting you with this query moving forward.  ============  Hope this helps. Please feel free to reach out in case you have any additional queries and/or concerns.  Have a great day ahead. Be safe  We value

comm_body: Hi Alisha,  It was a pleasure talking to you today. I'd like to send you this short summary of our chat.  You reached out to us because you enabled connection between source (i-001fab2de0801958c, 172.25.42.117) and destination (i-03919865fc513fed8, 172.24.16.197) instances, but the connection failed.  During our chat, we found that the direct connection between the instances was allowed, but the source instance has a proxy configured and was trying to use that. You were able to successfully connect to the destination instance with 'curl' using the following command: # curl -k -x "" https://172.24.16.197:8083 <!doctype html> <html lang="en" ng-app="twistlock"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <!-- safari rejects 3rd party cookies when running inside iframe so all client requests must include customer id in Saas mode --> <!-- this base href appends the customer id to all relative urls (resources, api requests etc.) --> <base href="/"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1"> <title>Prisma Cloud</title> <link rel="icon" href="css/prisma-cloud.svg"> ---snip---  Allow me to explain the options: -k : Disables SSL certificate check. This was necessary as the check failed. This is most likely because the certificate was created for the DNS name of the destination, but can be due to expired certificates or self-signed certificates. -x "" : Disables proxy for the connection.  Possible permanent fixes: 1) Adding the IP of the target to the "no_proxy" environmental variable on the source instance.    We discussed that your instance already uses this for other destinations.    This will make 'curl' to initiate the connection directly and not over the proxy.  2) Allowing connections from the proxy on the destination instance.    This would allow the source instance to initiate the connection over the proxy.   Please note, this will not affect the SSL certificate check. For that my recommendation is to install an SSL certificate on the destination that was configured to have the IP address as an alias.

comm_body: Hello Keerthan,  Thank you so much for your time. It was a pleasure to assist you today. Please find below a brief summary of our chat.  You had contacted us as you were receiving "packet_write_wait: Connection to 18.237.18.61 port 22: Broken pipe" when executing a script on the instance "i-073eb68b6ea0d102f".  The message that you mentioned is noticed when SSH connection (on port 22) was cut off due to a long period of inactivity. To mitigate this you can use the ClientAliveInterval and ServerAliveInterval i.e. in the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file in the instance, you can add the following lines:   ClientAliveInterval 300  ClientAliveCountMax 2   This will send a ping every 300 seconds (5 minutes) and disconnect after 2 failures. So the ping will keep the connection alive and active and will not time-out. For more information you can refer the following link:   https://www.digitalocean.com/community/questions/why-am-i-getting-packet_write_wait-connection-to-xxx-xx-xx-xxx-port-22-broken-pipe   To make this configuration changes, you launched a new instance "i-03e9cb67a56193d47", however, were not able to ssh.   =====================  # ssh -i /home/keeanu/testEMR.pem ubuntu@ec2-52-12-239-102.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com  Permission denied (publickey).  =====================   This is usually seen, if there is a permission issue or if you are using a wrong user name to login. From the system log, I see that it is an Ubuntu 18.04 instance, therefore, the default user-name is 'ubuntu' and you are using the correct key 'testEMR.pem'. However, to check the permissions and to correct them, you can run the following user-data script:   Stop the instance "i-03e9cb67a56193d47" -> Actions -> Instance Settings -> Edit userdata -> In plain text box copy paste the below script -> Save -> Start the instance.    ===============================================  Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="//"  MIME-Version: 1.0   --//  Content-Type: text/cloud-config; charset="us-ascii"  MIME-Version: 1.0  Content-Transfer-Encodin
